questions.text: A female patient presented with the following lesions that are soft on palpation and asymptomatic otherwise. She gives a history of angina.  Her elder sister also has similar complaints. The lipid profile reveals hypercholesterolemia, hypertriglyceridemia, and increased levels of remnant chylomicron and intermediate-density lipoprotein (IDL). A genetic study shows a defective ApoE gene. What can be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing xanthelasma palpebrum, along with the history of angina, and an increase in remnant chylomicron and IDL levels with defective apoE suggests the diagnosis of familial type III hyperlipoproteinemia.

Xanthelasma palpebra or xanthelasmas are plain xanthomas that commonly develop on the upper eyelids and the area around the medial canthus. They appear pale yellow to yellow‐orange in color and are soft on palpation.

Type III hyperlipoproteinemia is also known as broad β-disease, remnant removal disease, or familial dysbetalipoproteinemia.

Type III hyperlipoproteinemia is caused by a defective ApoE that causes dysbetalipoproteinemia. ApoE mediates the removal of lipoprotein remnants. It typically has three isoforms- E2, E3, and E4. Patients with type III hyperlipoproteinemia lack isoforms E3 and E4 and have only E2. This leads to defective clearance of lipoprotein remnants by the liver.

Clinical features include hypercholesterolemia, xanthomas, and atherosclerosis. There is an increase in remnant chylomicrons, remnant VLDL (i.e.Intermediate-density lipoprotein), cholesterol, and triglyceride levels.

Fibrates are effective in treating patients with type III hyperlipoproteinemia. Fibrate therapy in these patients leads to lowering of the elevated triglyceride and cholesterol levels, regression of xanthomas, and improvement in angina and intermittent claudication.

Other options:

Option A- Type I hyperlipoproteinemia(Hyperchylomicronemia) patients with LPL(lipoprotein lipase) or apo C-II deficiency show increased levels of chylomicrons in the plasma, after a fatty meal. There is no increased risk of coronary disease in this condition.

Options B and D- Type II hyperlipoproteinemia also known as familial hypercholesterolemia, is due to a defective LDL receptor or mutation in the ligand region of apo B-100. Defective LDL receptors cause a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and total cholesterol rise. Clinical features include the presence of tendon xanthomas, atherosclerosis, and coronary heart disease.

questions.text: A 68-year-old chronic smoker complains of cough, hemoptysis, and chest pain. The radiological investigations reveal a tumor arising from a major bronchus. Histopathology shows small cells with a salt and pepper pattern of chromatin and basophilic staining of the vascular walls. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 68-year-old chronic smoker presenting with cough, hemoptysis, and chest pain with radiological findings of a tumor arising from a major bronchus and histopathology showing small cells with a salt and pepper pattern of chromatin and basophilic staining of the vascular walls (Azzopardi effect) is most likely small cell carcinoma of the lung.

Small cell carcinoma of the lung belongs to the neuroendocrine tumors and originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells, Kulchitsky cells that lines the bronchial epithelium. It is a highly malignant tumor with a high association with cigarette smoking. They mainly arise from the major bronchi.

Histopathology of small cell lung carcinoma shows clusters of small cells which are round, oval, or spindle-shaped, and a prominent nuclear molding. These cells have scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. Azzopardi effect is described as basophilic staining of vascular walls due to coating by DNA from necrotic tumor cells.

Neuroendocrine markers seen in small cell lung carcinoma include:

  • Chromogranin
  • Synaptophysin
  • CD56

Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung are Cushing syndrome due to ACTH production and hyponatremia due to inappropriate ADH secretion. Small cell lung cancer-associated SIADH is due to the ectopic release of antidiuretic hormone. It is associated with increased thirst and hyponatremia. 

Other options:

Option A- Adenocarcinoma is a malignant epithelial tumor with differentiation in glands or mucin production by the tumor cells. These tumors are commonly found in women and in non-smokers. These tumors are more peripherally located and are smaller. On histopathology, the tumor shows a lepidic pattern of spread with tumor cells crawling along the normal-appearing alveolar septa. The tumor cells are positive for thyroid transcription factor 1 (TTF-1) and napsin A.

Option B- Squamous cell carcinoma is found to be more common in men and has a strong association with smoking. They have precursor lesions like squamous dysplasia, squamous metaplasia, or in situ carcinomas. On histopathology, it is characterized by keratinization and/or intercellular bridges. Keratinization occurs in the form of squamous pearls. It is positive for p40 and p63 markers. Hypercalcemia is the common paraneoplastic syndrome associated with this type.

Option C- Large cell carcinoma is an undifferentiated malignant epithelial carcinoma. On histopathology, the cells are large, with large nuclei, prominent nucleoli with a moderate amount of cytoplasm.

questions.text: Two sisters of age 25 and 18 years presented with bilateral painless progressive visual loss. After a detailed examination, a diagnosis of a rare inherited disease was made. The pedigree chart shown in the image below represents the pedigree chart of the family.  What is the pattern of inheritance seen here?
questions.solution:
The pattern of inheritance shown in the pedigree chart is mitochondrial inheritance.

The unique feature of mitochondrial inheritance is maternal inheritance. The mitochondrial DNA of the zygote is completely derived from the ovum. Therefore, when the mother is affected and the father is normal, all their children will be affected. 

However, children will not be affected if they are born to a normal mother and an affected father. Only the daughters of the affected mother will further transmit the disease to the next generations.

The condition described that shows this pattern of inheritance is Leber optic neuropathy. It is a neurodegenerative disease that leads to progressive bilateral loss of central vision. It is first noted between the age of 15 and 35 years and eventually leads to blindness.

 
Features of mitochondrial inheritance:
  • The mitochondrial DNA encodes enzymes required for oxidative phosphorylation. The organs of the central nervous system, skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, liver, and kidneys are affected as they are most dependent on oxidative phosphorylation.
  • Heteroplasmy is a phenomenon in which the individual has both wild-type and mutant type of mtDNA. 
  • Threshold effect is defined as a minimum number of copies of mutant mtDNA to be present in the mitochondria that can lead to oxidative dysfunction to manifest the disease.
  • The expression of the disease varies even among different cells of an organ. This is because there is a variable distribution of the normal and mutant mtDNA to the cells.

Other options:

Option A- Autosomal recessive pattern of inheritance is a type of Mendelian inheritance where both the alleles at a given gene locus are mutated. Characteristics of autosomal recessive inheritance:

  • Parents of affected individuals might not show the disease, however, the siblings might show the disease.
  • Heterozygous state individuals will be asymptomatic and the disease is manifested in the homozygous state.
  • The affected individual is most likely the product of a consanguineous marriage.
  • Examples of autosomal inheritance are cystic fibrosis, phenylketonuria, thalassemia, sickle cell anemia, etc.

Option B- X-linked recessive pattern of inheritance is a type of Mendelian inheritance where the mutant gene is present on the X-chromosome without a corresponding allele on the Y-chromosome. Characteristics are:

  • The affected male will not transmit the disease to the sons, but all his daughters will be carriers.
  • Sons of heterozygous females have a 1 in 2 chance of receiving the mutant allele.
  • Examples of X-linked recessive inheritance are Duchenne muscular dystrophy, hemophilia A and B, glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, etc.

Option C- X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance is a type of Mendelian inheritance where the dominant mutant allele is on the X-chromosome. It is characterized by:

  • An affected female transmits the disease to half of her sons and half of her daughters.
  • An affected male transmits the disease to all his daughters and none of his sons.
  • Examples of X-linked dominant pattern of inheritance are vitamin-D resistant rickets and Alport syndrome.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman is diagnosed to have cervical cancer. MRI and PET-CT imaging reveal tumour extension up to the pelvic wall and involvement of the para-aortic lymph nodes. It also shows features suggestive of hydronephrosis. Which stage is it according to the FIGO staging of cervical cancer?

PET-CT - Positron Emission Tomography/Computed Tomography
FIGO - International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics
questions.solution:
Cervical cancer involving the para-aortic lymph nodes is classified as Stage III C2 according to FIGO staging.

Cervical cancer is the most common gynecological cancer. The FIGO staging uses clinical, radiological, or pathological findings to stage cervical cancer from Stage I to IV.

Stage III cervical carcinoma involves the lower 1/3rd of the vagina, with or without pelvic wall extension, hydronephrosis, and lymph node involvement. It is further staged as follows:

  • Stage III A: Lower 1/3rd of the vagina involvement, no pelvic wall extension
  • Stage III B: Pelvic wall involvement with or without hydronephrosis or a non-functioning kidney
  • Stage III C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or paraaortic lymph nodes
    • Stage III C1: Metastasis to pelvic lymph node only
    • Stage III C2: Metastasis to para-aortic lymph nodes

Note: If the carcinoma had extended beyond the true pelvis, involving adjacent pelvic organs like the bladder or rectum, it would've been classified as Stage IV A.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

questions.text: A 51-year-old diabetic male patient presented with headaches and eye pain for a few months. He also reports difficulty in driving at night and frequent changes in presbyopic glasses. On examination, his intraocular pressure (IOP) was 22 mmHg, and fundoscopy showed the laminar dot sign. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the other fundus changes seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the finding of the laminar dot sign and raised IOP, is suggestive of primary open-angle glaucoma, and a cup:disc ratio of less than 0.5 is not seen in this condition.

Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is chronic, progressive optic neuropathy. It is mostly seen in more than 40 years of age, and it runs in family. The major risk factors are diabetes mellitus and myopia.

Most often patients having POAG present with headaches, frequent changes in presbyopic correction, and difficulty in dark adaptation. 

The fundus examination in glaucoma shows a cup:disc ratio of more than 0.5 and an asymmetry between the cup:disc ratio of two eyes of more than 0.2. 

Other changes:

  • Narrowing and notching of the neuroretinal rim (NRR)
  • Disc hemorrhages extending from the NRR onto the retina
  • Bayoneting sign due to the double angulation of a blood vessel
  • Loss of nasal NRR is characterized by developing space between the NRR and the central retinal vasculature
  • The laminar dot sign is the grey dot-like fenestration in the exposed lamina cribrosa as the NRR recedes.

Patients with affected first-degree relatives, diabetics, and myopes should be examined regularly after the age of 40 years to rule out glaucoma.

Medical Management includes:

Prostaglandin derivatives enhance the uveoscleral aqueous outflow and decrease IOP more than the other alternatives. They are preferred over beta-blockers as the first-line treatment for glaucoma because of the latter's potential systemic side effects. Some of the agents used are:

  • Latanoprost
  • Bimatoprost
  • Travoprost

Beta-blockers reduce IOP by decreasing aqueous production. They cause bronchospasm and can be fatal in asthmatics. In predisposed individuals, they can cause heart block, bradycardia, and worsening of heart failure. Agents include timolol, betaxolol, and levobunolol.

Alpha-2 agonists reduce IOP by decreasing the aqueous formation and increasing uveoscleral outflow. They can potentiate vascular insufficiency. Therapeutic agents used are brimonidine and apraclonidine.

Topical carbonic acid inhibitors reduce IOP by decreasing aqueous formation. They are slightly less effective than beta-blockers and contraindicated in patients with allergies to sulfa drugs. Some of the agents used are dorzolamide and brinzolamide. 

Miotics like pilocarpine were formerly used for open-angle glaucoma. 

Medical, laser, or surgical therapies can be used to achieve a target pressure of 16-18 mmHg, which results in the stabilization of POAG in most patients. Laser therapy for POAG consists of laser trabeculoplasty and is indicated only if the patient is refractory to medications and not compliant for surgery. 

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Bimatoprost
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor (Netarsudil)

Drugs that increase uveoscleral outflow

  • Prostaglandins (latanoprost)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine
  • Brimonidine
  • Apraclonidine

Drugs that decrease aqueous production

  • Alpha receptor stimulators in ciliary process (e.g., epinephrine, dipivefrine, clonidine, brimonidine, apraclonidine)
  • Beta-blockers

questions.text: Identify the fetal presentation shown in the following image :
questions.solution:
The image depicts anterior asynclitism where the anterior parietal bone is the presenting part.

The image shows the spine (dorsal part of the maternal body) and the pubic symphysis bone (ventral part of the maternal body) and it shows sagittal suture of the fetus deflected posteriorly towards the sacrum, thus making the anterior parietal bone the presenting part at the vaginal introitus.

Asynclitism refers to the position of a baby in the uterus such that the head of the baby is presenting first and is tilted to the shoulder, causing the fetal head to no longer be in line with the birth canal.

When the sagittal suture is deflected posteriorly, towards the sacral promontory the anterior parietal bone becomes the leading presenting part and is called anterior asynclitism.

When the sagittal suture is deflected anteriorly, towards the symphysis, the posterior parietal bone becomes the leading presenting part and is called posterior asynclitism. With extreme posterior asynclitism, the posterior ear may be easily palpated.

Moderate degrees of asynclitism are the rule in normal labour. However, if severe, this condition is a common reason for cephalopelvic disproportion even with an otherwise normal sized pelvis.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl was brought to the hospital after her parents noticed red blood in her stools. Physical examination showed the below finding. Small bowel radiography and histopathology showed multiple, small- to medium-sized hamartomatous polyps. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of red blood in stools, mucocutaneous pigmentation, and hamartomatous small to medium-sized polyps are suggestive of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple gastrointestinal hamartomatous polyps and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation.

The hyperpigmentation typically appears as dark blue to brown macules on the lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, palmar surfaces of the hands, genitalia, and perianal region.

Germline mutations in the gene STK11 are present in approximately half of the individuals with familial Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Histopathology shows the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by the normal-appearing intestinal epithelium.

Complications:

  • Peutz-Jeghers polyps can cause intussusception.
  • It is associated with a markedly increased risk of many malignant conditions. Regular surveillance is recommended from a very young age for sex cord tumors of the testes.
  • During later life, there is a risk for gastric and small intestinal cancers, and subsequently for colon, pancreatic, breast, lung, ovarian, and uterine cancers.

Below is the histologic image of the arborizing pattern seen in Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Juvenile polyps are the focal malformations of the epithelium or the lamina propria. They occur in children less than 5 years of age. Microscopy of the polyp reveals dilated glands filled with mucin and inflammatory debris. 

Option B: Turcot syndrome is a variant of familial adenomatous polyposis and constitutes colorectal polyps and brain tumors like medulloblastomas and glioblastomas.

Option D: Lynch syndrome, also called hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC) syndrome, is an autosomal dominant disorder associated with the cecum and colon carcinomas. It is a DNA mismatch repair defect. They are also at an increased risk of developing cancers of the endometrium, stomach, ovary, ureters, brain, small bowel, hepatobiliary tract, pancreas, and skin.

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man working in the mining industry comes with complaints of dyspnea.  A chest X-ray showed eggshell calcification in the hilar lymph nodes and the CT scan of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 42-year-old man who works in the mining industry presenting with complaints of dyspnea, chest X-ray showing eggshell calcification of the hilar lymph nodes and the given CT showing a “crazy paving pattern” is suggestive of silicosis.

Silicosis is an occupational disease caused by exposure to silica or crystalline quartz. It is seen in people who work in mining, stone cutting, sandblasting, and quarrying.

Silicosis presents as small rounded opacities in the upper lobe. There may be calcification of hilar lymph nodes which leads to the appearance of eggshell calcification. HRCT will show a characteristic crazy paving pattern due to interlobular septal thickening on the background of ground-glass opacity.

Other options:

Option A:  Asbestosis is an occupational disease and is characterized by diffuse interstitial fibrosis of the lung due to asbestos exposure. It is seen in people who work in shipbuilding, processing, construction, and mining industries. Irregular or linear opacities are usually noted in the lower lung fields and are the radiographic hallmark of asbestosis. HRCT will show the presence of pleural plaque, and subpleural curvilinear lines that appear parallel to the pleura.

Option C: Berylliosis is an occupational disease due to chronic exposure to beryllium. It is seen in people who work on processing alloys for high-tech industries. Chest radiography shows nodules along the septal lines with hilar and mediastinal lymph node enlargement. HRCT will show pulmonary nodules, diffuse interstitial fibrosis, and interlobular septal thickening. 

option D: Byssinosis is an occupational disease due to chronic exposure to cotton dust as in textile and rope-making industries. Chest X-ray shows hyperlucency, diaphragmatic flattening, and emphysema. A chest CT demonstrates ground glass opacities largely distributed in the basal regions with centrilobular nodules.

questions.text: A patient with a history of acute rhinosinusitis develops Pott's puffy tumor as a complication. Identify the correct statement regarding this complication:
questions.solution:
The true statement about Pott's puffy tumor is that it is a subperiosteal abscess of the frontal bone.

Pott's puffy tumor is a complication of sinusitis. The acute infection of the frontal sinus either directly or through the venous spread can lead to osteomyelitis of the frontal bone. Pus may form externally under the periosteum as soft doughy swelling (Pott’s puffy tumor), or internally as an extradural abscess. It is more often seen in adults. 

Treatment consists of large doses of antibiotics, abscess drainage, and trephining of the frontal sinus through its floor. Sometimes, the removal of sequestra and necrotic bone may also be required.

Given below is an image of Pott's puffy tumor.


Other options:

Option B: Mucocele of the frontal sinus is also a complication of sinusitis. The patients present with cystic, non-tender swelling, and egg-shell crackling sign may be elicited. It is usually seen in the superomedial quadrant of the orbit. The clinical features include headache, diplopia, and proptosis. Imaging of the frontal sinus shows loss of scalloping with clouding of the sinus due to the presence of fluid. Treatment includes frontoethmoidectomy with free drainage of the frontal sinus into the middle meatus.

Below is a CT image showing the frontal mucocele.


Option C: Orbital abscess is a complication of sinusitis. It usually occurs along the lamina papyracea or the floor of the frontal sinus. The clinical features would include edema of the lids, exophthalmos, chemosis of the conjunctiva, and restricted movements of the eyeball. Diagnosis is made by CT scan or ultrasound. Treatment includes antibiotics and drainage of the abscess.

Below is an image showing an orbital abscess.


Option D: Osteomyelitis of the maxilla is a complication of sinusitis. It is more commonly seen in infants and children than adults due to the presence of the spongy bone in the anterior wall of the maxilla. The clinical features include erythema, swelling of the cheek, edema of the lower eyelid, purulent nasal discharge, and fever. Bone sequestration may occur. Treatment includes antibiotics, drainage of any abscess, and removal of the sequestra.

Related Pearl: Symptoms of Sinusitis

Symptoms of maxillary sinusitis:

  • Pain over the upper jaw, aggravated by stooping, coughing & chewing
  • Constitutional symptoms like malaise and fever
  • Headache in the frontal region
  • Nasal and postnasal discharge
  • Redness and edema of cheeks
  • Tenderness on pressing over the anterior wall of the antrum

Symptoms of frontal sinusitis:

  • Frontal headache/ office headache with characteristic periodicity i.e. starts early morning and gradually increases and reaches its peak by about mid-day and then starts subsiding
  • Tenderness on pressing on the floor of the frontal sinus, just above the medial canthus
  • Nasal discharge
  • Edema of the upper eyelid

Symptoms of ethmoid sinusitis:

  • Pain over the bridge of the nose and deep to the eye that is aggravated by the movements of the eyeball
  • Edema of both eyelids,
  • Nasal discharge

Symptoms of sphenoid sinusitis:

  • Headache localized to occiput or vertex
  • Postnasal discharge

questions.text: A 65-year-old trumpet player presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and neck swelling as shown in the image below. The swelling increases in size on coughing and on performing Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the swelling, a gurgling sound is heard. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hoarseness of voice, cough, neck swelling that increases in size on coughing/ Valsalva maneuver, and a gurgling sound heard on pressing the swelling is suggestive of laryngocele.

Laryngocele is an air-filled cystic swelling in the neck due to dilatation of the saccule. It is more commonly seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to a raised transglottic air pressure in these people. It can be classified into internal, external, or combined types of laryngocele.

  • Internal laryngocele is limited within the larynx and appears as distension of the false cord and aryepiglottic fold
  • External laryngocele has a distended saccule that herniates through the thyrohyoid membrane and appears as a swelling in the neck
  • Combined or mixed laryngocele has both internal and external laryngoceles as its components

Given below is a diagrammatic representation of laryngocele:

Laryngocele presents with hoarseness of voice, cough, and airway obstruction (if large). External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck that increases in size on coughing or performing the Valsalva maneuver. On pressing the neck swelling, a gurgling sound is heard, indicating a positive Bryce's sign. Adult laryngoceles can be associated with carcinoma.

Diagnosis is based on an indirect laryngoscopy and CT scan. Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization and external laryngocele is managed by a surgical excision through an external neck incision.

Other options:

Option A: Branchial cyst develops from the vestigial remnants of the second branchial cleft. It presents as a swelling in the neck beneath the anterior border of the upper third of the sternomastoid muscle. It is smooth, soft, fluctuant, and often transilluminate. The below image shows a large right-sided branchial cyst.

Option C: Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum in which the pharyngeal mucosa is herniated through the Killian's dehiscence (a weak area between the 2 parts of the inferior constrictor). It usually occurs due to the uncoordinated contraction or the spasm of the cricopharyngeal sphincter during deglutition. Dysphagia is the predominant feature with a gurgling sound produced on swallowing.

The below image shows Zenker's diverticulum on barium swallow:

Option D: Cystic hygroma occurs due to obstruction of the jugular lymph sac. It is most commonly seen in the posterior triangle of the neck. More than 90% of the cases occur before the age of 2 years. It can result in stridor, respiratory difficulty, or feeding problems. It is partially compressible and brilliantly transilluminant.

The below image shows cystic hygroma in a child:

questions.text: A 16-year-old male patient who had been advised enucleation is brought to you for a second opinion. You would inform him that it is an absolute indication if his diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Retinoblastoma is an absolute indication for Enucleation operation.

Enucleation operation: It is the complete excision of an eyeball.

Absolute indications are:

  • Retinoblastoma
  • Malignant melanoma

Note: Indication for eye donation: Removal of eyes from the cadaver is presently the most common indication for enucleation.

Few other important definitions:

Evisceration operation:

It is the removal of the contents of the eyeball leaving behind the sclera. Frill evisceration is preferred over simple evisceration. In this, only about 3mm frill of the sclera is left around the optic nerve.

Indications of evisceration

  • Panophthalmitis
  • Expulsive choroidal hemorrhage
  • Bleeding anterior staphyloma

Exenteration is a mutilating surgery in which all contents of the orbits along with periorbita are removed. It is indicated for malignant tumors arising from the orbital structures or spreading from the eyeball.

Debulking involves reduction of as much of the bulk (volume) of a tumor as possible. Nowadays, debulking of the orbit is preferred over exenteration.

questions.text: An 18-year-old adolescent is being evaluated for primary amenorrhea. On examination, she has normal development of secondary sexual characteristics. Her ultrasound abdomen and pelvis reveal normal ovaries but an absence of the uterus and upper part of the vagina. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a girl with primary amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characteristics and ultrasonography showing normal ovaries and an absent uterus and upper of the vagina is suggestive of Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome. 

Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome or Mullerian agenesis is a condition wherein there is a congenital absence of the uterus and the vagina. The patients have a Karyotype of 46 XX, so the gonads present are ovaries. 

The patient's secondary sexual characteristics are well-developed with normal external genitalia. The ovaries are normal but have an absence of the uterus and the upper part of the vagina. The patients usually have a blind-ended vaginal pouch. 

Diagnosis is made with the help of pelvic sonography, MRI, and laparoscopy. Patients may have rudimentary Mullerian bulbs without an endometrial cavity. 

Other options:

Option A: Androgen insensitivity syndrome, also known as testicular feminization syndrome, has a karyotype of 46XY, so the gonads present are testes. Secondary sexual characteristics like the development of axillary hair and pubic hair are absent in these females. However, breast development is adequate due to the conversion of androgen into estrogen during puberty.

Option B: In Turner syndrome, short stature with poor development of secondary sexual characters will be seen. It has a karyotype of 45 XO. Female genital organs like the vagina, uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries are present.

Option C: Swyer syndrome is a type of male pseudohermaphrodite. As there is gonadal dysgenesis in these patients, they fail to secrete testosterone and antimullerian hormone (AMH). This results in the development of female genital organs i.e. uterus and cervix are developed. They present with primary amenorrhoea, absence of secondary sex characters, and female external genitalia.

questions.text: An obese and intellectually impaired patient whose hands are shown in the image below is brought by his relatives to the OPD. Blood investigations show low calcium, high phosphorous, and parathormone levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image showing short metacarpals (brachydactyly) and the accompanying clinical scenario of obesity and intellectual disability with low calcium, high phosphorous, and high parathormone levels are suggestive of pseudohypoparathyroidism.

Pseudohypoparathyroidism is an inherited disorder that is characterized by hypocalcemia and characteristic skeletal features, known as Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO). It is due to the loss of function mutation in genes encoding the alpha subunit of the stimulatory G-protein Gsα. This blocks the action of PTH, leading to reduced serum calcium and increased serum phosphate. AHO features include short stature, short metacarpals and metatarsals (brachydactyly), round facies, intellectual impairment, and heterotropic calcifications.

Although serum calcium is low and serum phosphate is high (like hypoparathyroidism), PTH levels are also found to be elevated, and thus this disorder is termed pseudohypoparathyroidism. Urinary cAMP excretion is low because PTH is unable to act on its downstream pathways.

Other options:

Option A: Vitamin D deficiency occurs due to inadequate intake of dairy products rich in vitamin D, lack of vitamin supplementation, and decreased sunlight exposure. It results in a mild decrease in calcium levels, elevated parathormone levels due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, and low phosphate levels.

Option B: Hypoparathyroidism is due to the decreased production of parathormone from the parathyroid glands. It is characterized by low calcium and low parathormone levels with elevated phosphate. Clinical features of hypocalcemia due to hypoparathyroidism include paresthesias, seizures, carpopedal spasm, bronchospasm, laryngospasm, and prolongation of the QT interval.

Option D: Pseudopseudohypoparathyroidism is also associated with AHO features. However, serum calcium, phosphate, and PTH levels are normal in these patients. Urinary cAMP is also normal.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency room with severe pain in his penis. Examination reveals retracted prepucial skin as shown below. Manual reduction was tried and hyaluronidase injections were given but unsuccessful. What is the next best step in the immediate management of this condition?

choices.text: Dorsal slit to relieve edema and compression

questions.solution:
The next best immediate management in this patient with paraphimosis is dorsal slit to relieve oedema and compression. 

The patient has paraphimosis - an inability to place back the retracted prepucial skin. This is an urologic emergency where the foreskin becomes trapped behind the corona creating a ring-like constriction. This circumferential ring of tissue can impair the blood and lymphatic flow to and from the glans and prepuce. As a result, the glans and prepuce may become swollen and edematous.

Paraphimosis only occurs in uncircumcised or partially circumcised males and must be distinguished from phimosis, a condition in which the foreskin cannot be pulled back and is not an emergency.

It is precipitated either after sexual intercourse or iatrogenically after procedures such as urethral catheterization or cystoscopy. Patients generally have penile pain and the glans appears enlarged and congested, with a collar of swollen foreskin around the coronal sulcus. A tight, constricting band of tissue appears immediately behind the head of the penis. The remainder of the penile shaft is flaccid and unremarkable.

Infants and children with paraphimosis may present with obstructive voiding symptoms and acute urinary obstruction when the condition is severe. If left untreated, penile gangrene and autoamputation may follow in days or weeks.

The first line of treatment includes manual reduction of the skin. Sedation and multiple hyaluronidase injection in 10 ml saline are injected to reduce the edema is another treatment modality.

In acute cases, an initial dorsal slit is made to relieve the edema and compression. Antibiotics and analgesics are given and circumcision is performed after 3 weeks.

Other options:

Option A: The glans can undergo necrosis or become gangrenous in this case. Hence, reassurance after giving analgesics is not the right option.

Option C: Circumcision is often the last resort for paraphimosis. It is deferred to a later time and not performed in acute conditions.

Option D: Urethral catheterization can precipitate paraphimosis. It is not the treatment.

questions.text: A young male patient visits the flu and fever clinic with a history of fever, anorexia, cough, and difficulty in breathing for the past 4 days. On examination, he is found to have a respiratory rate of 27 per minute and SpO2 of 88% on room air. He does not smoke cigarettes. His RT-PCR test was found to be positive for COVID-19 disease. According to the Ministry of Health and Family welfare guidelines, this patient has:
questions.solution:
SpO2 of less than 90% on room air is classified as severe COVID-19 infection according to Indian guidelines. 

Classification of COVID-19 infection severity (Indian guidelines):

Mild- patients with uncomplicated upper respiratory tract infection, may have mild symptoms such as fever, cough, sore throat, nasal congestion, malaise, headache. There is no shortness of breath or hypoxia.

Moderate- Patients have pneumonia with no signs of severe disease. Adults with the presence of clinical features of dyspnea and or hypoxia, fever, cough, including SpO2 90 to ≤93% on room air, Respiratory Rate more or equal to 24 per minute.

Severe- Adults show clinical signs of pneumonia with one of the following; respiratory rate >30 breaths/min, severe respiratory distress, SpO2 <90% on room air.

Severe infection further has:

  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome- patients develop new or worsening respiratory symptoms within one week of onset of the symptoms. There are opacities in the chest radiographs which are not due to effusions, lobar or lung collapse, or nodules. The patients develop respiratory failure which is not due to cardiac failure or fluid overload. The oxygen impairment in adults will be PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 300 mmHg (with PEEP or CPAP ≥5 cm H2O).
  • Sepsis- Life-threatening organ dysfunction caused due to an infection.
  • Septic shock- Persisting hypotension despite fluid resuscitation. Patients require vasopressors to maintain MAP ≥65 mmHg and serum lactate level > 2 mmol/L.

Mild cases can be managed at COVID care centres or home isolated. Moderate and severe cases will require hospitalisation in a dedicated COVID hospital.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with pain and tenderness around the base of her right thumb is diagnosed with de Quervain's tenosynovitis. The tendon of which of the following muscle is affected in this condition?
questions.solution:
The tendon of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis are affected in de Quervain's tenosynovitis.

The abductor pollicis longus runs under the first dorsal compartment of the extensor retinaculum and splits into two parts. One is attached to the radial side of the first metacarpal base and the other to the trapezium. The extensor pollicis brevis is medial to the abductor pollicis longus.

de Quervain's tenosynovitis is a condition characterized by pain, tenderness, and swelling over the radial styloid process which results from inflammation of the common sheath of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis tendons.

On examination, tenderness is localized to the radial styloid process. Finklestein's test may be performed where the patient's thumb is grasped and the hand is abducted in ulnar deviation. This maneuver results in excruciating pain over the radial styloid. The following image shows Finklestein's test. 

It is treated conservatively with a crepe bandage or slab. Analgesics and ultrasonic radiation can also be provided. Severe cases may need slitting and excision of the tendon sheath.

questions.text: The given image shows the posterior thoracic wall. Which of the following statements is false about the structure marked A within the intercostal space?

choices.text: It is located below the intercostal artery
Derivatives from T4 and T5 are typical in type
They lie between external intercostal and internal intercostal muscle
Derivatives from T7 to T11 supply the abdominal wall

questions.solution:
The structure marked A is the intercostal nerve. It doesn't lie between external and internal intercostal muscles, but lies between the internal and innermost intercostal muscles. 

Intercostal nerves are derived from the ventral rami of the thoracic vertebrae - T1 to T11. They lie between the internal intercostal and innermost intercostal muscles.

Typical intercostal nerves are those that only supply only the thoracic wall, e.g, 3rd to 6th intercostal nerves. All the other intercostal nerves supply other regions as follows:

  • Upper two intercostal nerves - supply upper limb
    • 1st intercostal nerve - does not have the lateral and anterior cutaneous branches.
    • 2nd intercostal nerve - gives off the intercostobrachial nerve
  • 7th to 11th intercostal nerves - supply abdominal wall, hence they are called thoracoabdominal nerves. 

In each intercostal space, the arrangement of the structures superior to inferior is vein, artery, nerve (VAN). In the 1st intercostal space, the neurovascular bundle lies superiorly, and the arrangement from medial to lateral is the Sympathetic trunk, intercostal Vein, superior intercostal Artery, intercostal Nerve. (SVAN).

questions.text: During triaging of casualties from a building collapse, you find a patient who is able to walk but has sprained his ankle along with abrasions on the legs and a laceration on the face. You would classify him under:
questions.solution:
This patient is classified under the green code, according to triage color coding. In triage, green signifies low-priority or ambulatory patients and those with minor illnesses.

Triage is done to categorize the need for priority of patients in cases of mass casualties. The aim of triage is the identify patients who would benefit the most by being treated earlier.

  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Profuse external bleeding
  • Hemothorax

  • Major intra-abdominal bleed
  • Extradural hematomas
Second (II) Yellow Urgent Critical, likely to survive treated  within hours
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Ruptured abdominal viscus
  • Pelvic fractures
  • Spinal injuries
Third (III) Green Non-urgent Stable, likely to survive even if treatment is delayed hours- days

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient came with complaints of weight loss, lethargy, polyuria, and polyphagia. During the blood sample collection for plasma glucose estimation in this patient, a vacutainer shown in the below image is used.  Which of the following glycolytic enzymes is inhibited by the content in the vacutainer?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a grey vacutainer. It is used to collect blood samples for plasma glucose estimation. Since it contains sodium fluoride, the fluoride will inhibit the glycolytic enzyme enolase.

Grey vacutainer contains sodium fluoride and potassium oxalate. Potassium oxalate binds to calcium and inhibits coagulation.

 Inhibitors of glycolytic enzymes:

  • Fluoride inhibits the enzyme enolase which is responsible for the conversion of 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate.
  • Iodoacetate inhibits the enzyme glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase which is responsible for the conversion of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate to 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate. This action of iodoacetate helps in anticancer activity.
  • Arsenate inhibits 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate kinase. 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate kinase converts  1,3 bisphosphoglycerate to 3 phosphoglycerates. Arsenate competes with inorganic phosphate (Pi) in this reaction to give 1-arseno-3-phosphoglycerate which undergoes spontaneous hydrolysis to 3-phosphoglycerate without forming ATP.

questions.text: An intern commits a negligent act in the hospital. You as his senior doctor will be held responsible for the negligent act as the intern is working under you. This is explained by _____.
questions.solution:
The senior doctor is responsible for the negligent act of a junior doctor, resident, intern, or assistant working under him by vicarious liability.

Vicarious liability is by which the employer is responsible for his employees’ negligence if such an act occurs in the course of the employment and within its scope. It is by the principle of 'respondeat superior' (let the superior answer).

When two doctors practice as partners, they are both responsible for each other's negligent acts. When 2 or more doctors independently attend a patient, each may be held liable for the negligence of others that he observes or in the ordinary course should have observed and allows it to continue without objection.

When an employee is being borrowed, the lending employer temporarily loses his control over this worker and the borrowing employer temporarily assumes control. This is known as borrowed servant doctrine.

Contributory negligence is any unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care from the patient's part or from the attendant. This act, along with the negligent act of the doctor has contributed to the injury. If there was no contributory negligence, the injury would not have occurred. The doctor's negligence is not the direct cause of the injury. Eg. refusal to take required treatment, getting discharged against the doctor's advice, etc.

Res ipsa loquitur in Latin means "the thing speaks for itself". If an untoward result happened that is thought to be due to deviation from the normal standards of care, or negligence, then the doctor should admit the problem. The doctor should take the responsibility to explain the issue to the patient and their family, and solve the problem by either initiating treatment or transferring care. There should be no charge for additional care or for further procedures.

questions.text: A patient develops a postoperative wound discharge. The culture of the discharge reveals infection with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Which of the following cephalosporins can be used in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ceftaroline, which is considered as anti-MRSA cephalosporin, is indicated for MRSA infections and can, therefore, be used in this patient. It is grouped as fifth-generation cephalosporins along with ceftobiprole.

Ceftaroline has gram-negative and also enhanced gram-positive coverage. It is effective against MRSA and penicillin-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Other options:

Option A: Ceftizoxime is a third-generation cephalosporin that is less active against S. pneumoniae and more active against Bacteroides fragilis. It has no action on MRSA.

Option B: Cefpirome is a fourth-generation cephalosporin that has antipseudomonal activity and activity against many organisms, such as Enterobacter and Pseudomonas, that are resistant to other cephalosporins, with no significant action on MRSA.

Option C: Ceftolozane is an anti-pseudomonal cephalosporin that is a structural analog of ceftazidime. It has enhanced activity against Pseudomonas, including activity against strains resistant to ceftazidime through β-lactamase overexpression, with no action on MRSA.

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male patient with emphysema was found to have elevated liver transaminases. His liver biopsy shows round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes which are PAS-positive and diastase-resistant. Which type of emphysema does this patient most likely have?

Periodic Acid–Schiff = (PAS)
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient with emphysema with a liver biopsy showing round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes, that are strongly PAS-positive and diastase-resistant is suggestive of α1 antitrypsin deficiency. α1 antitrypsin deficiency is associated with panacinar emphysema.

Panacinar or panlobular emphysema is associated with α1 antitrypsin (α1AT) deficiency. It is exacerbated by smoking. Panacinar occurs more commonly in lower zones and the anterior margins of the lung. In this type, the acini from respiratory bronchiole to terminal blind alveoli are uniformly enlarged. 

α1AT deficiency is an autosomal-recessive disorder of protein misfolding. Deficiency of α1AT protein results in excessive degradation of alveoli by neutrophil elastase causing panacinar emphysema. It also causes liver disease as a consequence of the abnormal accumulation of the misfolded protein within hepatocytes.  α1AT deficiency is characterized by the presence of round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes. These hepatocytes are strongly Periodic acid–Schiff positive and diastase resistant. 

Other options:

Option B- Centriacinar or centrilobular emphysema is the most common emphysema. It is predominantly seen in heavy smokers with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). In this type, the central to proximal parts of acini formed by the respiratory bronchioles are mainly affected. The distal alveoli are spared.  It is more common in the upper lobes, particularly in the apical segment.

Option C- Paraseptal or distal acinar emphysema predisposes to spontaneous pneumothorax in young adults. In this type, the distal portion of acini is mostly affected. The proximal portion of the acinus is normal.

Option D- In irregular emphysema the acini are irregularly involved. This type of emphysema is associated with scarring.

questions.text: During your rural posting in a district that is endemic for Japanese encephalitis, a 6-year-old completely unimmunized child was brought to your Primary Health Center. Which of the following vaccines can be given to this child now?
questions.solution:

For an unvaccinated child between the age of 5-7 years, the first, second, and third doses of the DPT vaccine are given at one-month intervals. The booster dose can be given at a minimum of 6 months after administering the third dose of DPT up to 7 years of age.

JE vaccine can be given to a child from an endemic district for Japanese encephalitis up to 15 years of age. 

BCG vaccine is given up to 1 year of age. This is because most of the children acquire natural clinical/sub-clinical tuberculosis infection by the age of one year. This will also protect against severe forms of childhood tuberculosis.

OPV can only be given up to 5 years of age.

Vaccines that can be given to an unvaccinated child between the age of 1 - 5 years are DPT-1, OPV-1, measles, and 2 mL of vitamin A. At one-month intervals, second and third doses of DPT and OPV should be given. The second dose of measles is given as per the schedule. questions.text: All of the following statements about fetal circulation are true except:

choices.text: Inferior vena cava carries oxygenated blood
Ductus venosus connects umbilical artery to inferior vena cava
Ductus arteriosus shunts blood from pulmonary artery to aorta

questions.solution:
All of the above statements about fetal circulation are true except option B. Ductus venosus connects the umbilical vein (not umbilical artery) to the inferior vena cava (IVC).

The fetal circulation is distinctly different from adult circulation. It allows the fetus to receive oxygenated blood from the placenta as the lungs do not provide a gaseous exchange. This is due to the vasoconstriction of the pulmonary vessels that divert the blood away from the pulmonary circulation. The umbilical cord consists of 2 umbilical arteries and 1 umbilical vein along with blood vessels of the placenta. The structures unique to the fetus for circulation are ductus venosus, foramen ovale, and ductus arteriosus.

Mechanism:

About 50% of the oxygenated blood from the umbilical vein enters hepatic circulation. The rest of the oxygenated blood from the umbilical vein bypasses the liver and enters the IVC via the ductus venosus. 

The right atrium receives the oxygenated blood from the IVC (option A) and superior vena cava (less oxygenated). The right atrial pressure is more than the left atrial pressure resulting in the major flow of blood from the right atrium to the left atrium via the foramen ovale. The blood from the left atrium flows to the left ventricle. The upper part of the fetal body (coronaries, cerebral arteries, and upper extremities) is exclusively perfused by the left ventricle via the ascending aorta.

Some oxygenated blood from the right atrium also enters the right ventricle which is ejected into the pulmonary artery. Only 5% of the right ventricular outflow enters the lung due to the high pressure from vasoconstriction of the pulmonary arteries (Option C). The major portion of this blood bypasses the lung and flows from the pulmonary artery into the descending aorta via the ductus arteriosus (Option D). This blood provides perfusion to the lower body and the placental flow via the 2 umbilical arteries.

Given below is a flowchart of fetal circulation.

Related Pearl: Concepts of Fetal Circulation

Concept 1:

Oxygenated blood from placenta to the fetus via the left umbilical vein.

Concept 2:

Most of the umbilical venous blood shunts via the ductus venosus to the inferior vena cava and gets mixed with deoxygenated blood from the lower part of the body and liver.

Concept 3:

One-third of blood from the inferior vena cava is directly pumped to the left atrium across the foramen ovale; then to the left ventricle; and ejected from there into the ascending aorta, where it supplies the upper body and the brain.

Concept 4:

A major portion of blood enters the right ventricle, mixes with blood from the superior vena cava, and ejects into the pulmonary trunk.

Concept 5:

Ductus arteriosus bypasses the lungs, and hence, a major portion pumps into the descending aorta to perfuse the lower part of the body and the umbilical arteries carry blood to the placenta for oxygenation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female patient presented with the following condition of toenails. The discoloration spread proximally as a streak in the nail and later the entire nail was affected. Now, the entire nail is brittle and has separated from the nailbed. On examination, no pits were present over the nails and biopsy shows numerous spores and hyphae. What can be the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Tinea unguium or onychomycosis is defined as the infection of the nail plate by fungus. Trichophyton rubrum accounts for most cases, but many fungi may be causative.

A yellowish discoloration occurs, which spreads proximally as a streak in the nail. Later, subungual hyperkeratosis becomes prominent and spreads until the entire nail is affected. Gradually, the entire nail becomes brittle and separated from its bed as a result of the piling up of subungual keratin.

  • Six distinct patterns of tinea unguium have been described.
    • Distal and lateral subungual onychomycosis (DLSO) - Most common form
    • Superficial onychomycosis (SO)
    • Proximal subungual onychomycosis
    • Endonyx onychomycosis
    • Totally dystrophic onychomycosis
    • Mixed onychomycosis
  • Diagnosis is made by KOH mount examination of clippings or curetting that include dystrophic subungual debris.
  • Spores and hyphae are seen very frequently in onychomycosis

Oral terbinafine is the treatment of choice for Tinea unguium or onychomycosis. Oral terbinafine at 250 mg/day is given for a duration of 6 weeks for fingernails infection and 3 months (12 weeks) for toenails infection.

           FIRST-LINE DRUG                   DURATION
 Oral Terbinafine - 250mg/day

Fingernails - 6 weeks.

Toenails - 12 weeks
Oral Itraconazole- 400mg/day for 1week

Fingernails - regimen repeated every month for 2 to 3 months

Toenails - regimen repeated every month for 3 to 4 months
  • Oral Griseofulvin dose 1 g/day for 4–8 months (longer for toenails) is used as a second-line treatment
  • Topical treatment with amorolfine or ciclopirox olamine can be used in mild infections affecting the distal nail plate only or non‐linear superficial onychomycosis.

Other options

Option A- In psoriasis, fingernails are more affected than toenails because they grow faster.  Nail pitting is the most frequent sign and it is formed due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix. Ten pits in one nail or more than 50 pits in all nails are suggestive of nail psoriasis. Subungual oil drop sign or salmon patch is a highly specific sign seen in psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil as shown below.

Option B- In arsenic poisoning, the nails show Mee's line. Mee's lines (transverse leukonychia) are single or multiple white transverse bands, in the finger or toenails due to arsenic deposition in the keratin-rich tissues. They also occur in thallium poisoning.

The below image shows a nail with Mee's line.

Option D- Lichen planus is an idiopathic inflammatory skin disease affecting the skin and mucous membranes, often with a chronic course with relapses and periods of remission.

Nail involvement occurs in up to 10% of cases, the majority of cases present during the fifth or sixth decades. Fingernails are affected more frequently than toenails. The most common changes are an exaggeration of the longitudinal lines and linear depressions due to slight thinning of the nail plate as shown below.

Related Pearl: Nail changes in psoriasis

Nail changes in psoriasis are present in about 40% of the cases at any point in time. Nail psoriasis is associated with more extensive psoriasis, longer disease duration, family history of psoriasis, and the presence of psoriatic arthritis.

Subungal oil drop sign or Salmon Patch is a highly specific pathognomonic sign seen in Nail psoriasis. It is a yellow-red discoloration in the nail bed resembling a drop of oil.

Nail pitting however is the most frequent sign. Individual pits are uniformly sized, deep and irregular in nature. These nail pits are also known as Thimble pits and are due to the involvement of the proximal nail matrix.

Nail Bed disease also causes subungual hyperkeratosis, splinter hemorrhages, and distal onycholysis.

Leuconychia may also be present.

Trachonychia or Twenty Nail dystrophy may be present in severe cases.

questions.text: A final-year microbiology resident plots a bacterial growth curve in relation to time for his thesis work, as shown in the image below. He would be able to observe secondary metabolic products like exotoxins during which phase of the bacterial growth curve?
questions.solution:
The secondary metabolic products like exotoxins are seen in the stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve, which is marked as 3 in the image.

Phases of the bacterial growth curve:

Lag phase (1)- Occurs immediately after the seeding of a culture media. There is no increase in cell number but cell size increases and maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase. This is the time required for adaptation to a new environment, during which there is synthesis and accumulation of enzymes and metabolic intermediates necessary for multiplication.

Log phase or exponential phase (2)- Cells start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially or by geometric progression with time. Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. 

Stationary phase (3)- Cell division stops due to depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products. It is a state of equilibrium, where the number of new cells formed equals the number of cells that die. Sporulation occurs during this phase. Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins and antibiotics.

The phase of decline (4)- The population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation, and the action of autolytic enzymes. Involution forms are common.

questions.text: The middle meningeal artery enters into the middle cranial fossa through which of the following foramina?
questions.solution:
The middle meningeal artery enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen spinosum, labelled as 3 in the image.

Foramina marked in the image are

1 - Foramen rotundum

2 - Foramen ovale

3 - Foramen spinosum

4 - Jugular foramen

The middle meningeal artery is a branch of the first part of maxillary artery, given off in the infratemporal fossa, where it first runs upwards and medially between the sphenomandibular ligament and lateral pterygoid muscle and then passes through a loop formed by the two roots of the auriculotemporal nerve.
Following this, it enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen spinosum, following which it has an extradural course. It runs forward and laterally, grooving the squamous temporal bone and gives rise to its frontal and parietal branches.

The frontal branch, also called the anterior branch, is closely related to the motor area of cerebral cortex and parietal branch, also called the posterior branch, ends in front of the postero-inferior angle of the parietal bone, by dividing into two branches. These branches are commonly involved in extradural hemorrhage following a head injury and resultant rupture of the blood vessels.

The middle meningeal artery is predominantly a periosteal artery which supplies the bone and red bone marrow in the diploe.

questions.text: You are a research associate working on clinical trials of a new drug for COVID-19. During which phase of a clinical trial would you receive feedback from practising clinicians about adverse effects of the new drug?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of a newly marketed drug are detected during Phase IV of a clinical trial.

Phase IV of a clinical trial involves postmarketing surveillance and data-gathering studies after a certain drug has been marketed for general use. This includes the unknown adverse effects of the drug, drug compliance, and drug interactions. This phase includes all the patients who are on treatment with the drug in question and has no fixed duration.

Other options:

Option B: Phase III of a clinical trial is also called a multisite trial. It is done on patients who have been diagnosed to have the disease which the drug claims to treat. This phase is done for the confirmation of the efficacy of the newly developed drug in a larger population. Phase III is randomized and controlled and may be blinded.

Option C: Phase II of a clinical trial also involves patients diagnosed with the disease for which the new drug has been developed. Efficacy and dose-ranging of the drug are assessed during this phase of the trial.

Option D: Phase I of a clinical trial involves testing a new drug on healthy volunteers to assess its safety and tolerability.

questions.text: A patient was referred to an endocrinologist for hormonal evaluation as he had been diagnosed with thrombosis of the vessels supplying the hypothalamus. All of the following anterior pituitary hormones are likely to be decreased in this patient except:
questions.solution:
Following ischemic damage to the hypothalamus, all the hormones secreted by the anterior pituitary will decrease except prolactin. 

The hypothalamus mainly stimulates the production of all the other anterior pituitary hormones, but it inhibits prolactin production. Therefore, following injury to the hypothalamus, levels of other anterior pituitary hormones are decreased, while prolactin levels are increased.

Prolactin is secreted by the lactotropes of the anterior pituitary and it is similar to human growth hormone and human chorionic somatomammotropin (hCS) structurally.

Levels of prolactin are increased during exercise, surgical and psychological stresses, stimulation of the nipple, sleep, pregnancy, thyrotropin-releasing hormone, thyroid-stimulating hormone, etc.

The important function of prolactin is to cause milk secretion and prevent ovulation in a lactating mother. It increases the production of casein and lactalbumin. Increased prolactin decreases the secretion of gonadotropin-releasing hormones, and subsequently decreases the secretion of gonadotropins. 

Additionally, dopamine released from the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus decreases the secretion of prolactin. Therefore, L dopa which is a precursor of dopamine, decreases prolactin secretion, and dopamine antagonists like chlorpromazine and antipsychotics increase the prolactin secretion.

questions.text:
A young male patient was brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. At the time of admission to casualty, his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was E2V2M4. After a few hours, it became E1V1M3. His CT brain was normal and an MRI of the brain is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

E- Eye opening
V- Verbal response
M- Motor response
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and a susceptibility-weighted MRI image (SWI) demonstrating hypointense foci of microhemorrhages are suggestive of diffuse axonal injury.

Diffuse axonal injury (white matter shearing) is the result of shearing forces, typically from acceleration, deceleration, or rotational forces. This causes damage in the microvasculature and disruption of axons in the subcortical parasagittal white matter, cerebellum, corpus callosum, and midbrain.

Most commonly, it occurs in automobile accidents. Patients are usually unconscious from the moment of impact and remain the same until death.

Diffuse axonal injury is characterized by multiple focal lesions with a characteristic distribution:

  • CT may be normal.
  • MRI is the modality of choice for assessing suspected diffuse axonal injury even in patients with entirely normal CT of the brain. It detects the micro-bleeds within the brain.

Other options:

Option B - Intraventricular hemorrhage occurs as a result of bleeding from the choroid plexus or rupture of germinal matrix hemorrhages into the ventricles. The germinal matrix is a site of neuronal proliferation during fetal development and disappears at term. Therefore, these hemorrhages are more common in babies. CT images showing intraventricular hemorrhages are given below.

 

Option C- Subdural hemorrhage is often due to the rupture of bridging veins that crosses the subdural space. In subdural hemorrhage, the CT shows crescentic opacity. 

The image below shows a CT of a subdural hemorrhage.

 

Option D- Extradural hemorrhage is mostly due to the rupture of the middle meningeal artery. Since the dura matter tends to adhere to the skull, the hemorrhage is seen in CT as a biconvex dense area. They usually do not cross cranial sutures.

The image below shows a CT of an extradural hemorrhage.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Axonal Injury

The mechanism of diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is primarily a non-impact rotational acceleration-deceleration injury. This leads to the deformation of the axons by stretching them.

Pathology of DAI:

  • Changes in permeability of the axolemma
  • Axonal swelling
  • Intracellular calcium accumulation
  • Proteolysis
  • The collapse of the cytoskeleton
  • 'Retraction balls or globes' - bulbous and clubbed axons. Seen earliest at 12-18 hours. The number of retraction balls begins to decrease after 2-3 weeks after injury and a cluster of microglial cells appears followed by astrocytosis and demyelination.
  • Immuno-histochemistry shows beta-amyloid precursor protein - the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours. 

Image shows scattered axonal retraction balls stained with Congo Red:

questions.text: As a senior resident in the OBG department, You would consider the following procedure as a treatment option in all of the following cases except

choices.text: Removal of placenta accreta in multiparous woman

questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the above image is uterine artery embolization (UAE). It is indicated in all the above-given cases except in a patient with calcified fibroids.

Uterine artery embolization is an angiographic procedure where polyvinyl alcohol microspheres are introduced into both uterine arteries, producing ischemia and necrosis of the fibroid. This technique is used preoperatively to reduce vascularity and thereby to reduce the size of the fibroid. It is best suited to control symptoms of pressure and menorrhagia in multiparous women.

A calcified fibroid does not shrink with the procedure. Pedunculated fibroids can fall off after the procedure resulting in intrauterine or peritoneal infections.

Hence, the calcified, submucous, and subserous types of fibroids are contraindications for this procedure. 

Other indications for uterine artery embolization include,

  • Postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Placenta accreta to reduce bleeding prior to placental removal, or caesarean delivery.
  • This technique is most suited for menorrhagia in a multiparous woman

Technique:

  • Under local sedation, bilateral UAE is ap­proached through percutaneous femoral catheterization.
  • It is done using polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), gel foam particles or metal coils.

Embolization reduces vascularity and the size of the fibroid in 3–4 months

Advantages of UAE:

  • No major surgery.
  • No intraoperative bleeding.
  • Short hospital stay.
  • Less abdominal adhesions.

Related Pearl: Contraindications to uterine artery embolization

Absolute contraindications:

  • GnRH agonist use
  • Asymptomatic fibroids
  • Pregnancy
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Uterine malignancy
  • Calcified fibroid

Relative contraindications:

  • Patient desirous of future pregnancy: UAE causes poor uterine perfusion and pelvic adhesions, decreasing fertility. 
  • Postmenopausal women: Fibroids regress naturally, after menopause. Fibroid enlargement post-menopause raises the suspicion of malignancy.
  • Subserosal or submucosal fibroids: Pedunculated subtypes may detach intraperitoneally or within the uterine cavity. This may lead to sterile peritonitis or intrauterine infection.
  • Size or number of fibroids: Large fibroids or a greater number of fibroids can cause large amounts of necrosis following UAE. This may lead to post-op pain or infection. 
  • Contraindications to radiologic contrast agents.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with nasal obstruction. She states that her friends make fun of her because she emits a bad odor. Physical examination reveals wide nasal turbinates filled with greenish-black dry crusts and a pale nasal mucosa. Which of the following is not a component of the Kemicetine solution used in the management of this disease?
questions.solution:
Phenylephrine is not a component of the Kemicetine solution commonly used in the management of this disease.

The clinical scenario with nasal obstruction, bad odor, wide nasal turbinates filled with greenish-black dry crusts is suggestive of atrophic rhinitis. The Kemicetine solution used in the management of atrophic rhinitis contains chloramphenicol, oestradiol, and vitamin D2.

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic nasal inflammation associated with atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. The etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis includes:

  • Hereditary
  • More commonly in females than males
  • White and yellow races are more susceptible
  • Nutritional deficiency- Deficiency of vitamin A, D, or iron
  • Infective- Causative agents include Klebsiella ozaena, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, etc.
  • Autoimmune process

The clinical presentation of atrophic rhinitis includes nasal obstruction, foul smell from the nose with merciful anosmia, crusting of the nasal passage, pale nasal mucosa, wide nasal turbinates, and epistaxis.

Treatment

  • Nasal irrigation and crust removal using warm saline or an alkaline solution composed of sodium bicarbonate 1 part, sodium bi-borate 1 part, sodium chloride 2 parts in 280 mL of water
  • Local antibiotics - Kemicetine anti-ozaena solution contains chloramphenicol, estradiol, and vitamin D2. 
  • 25% glucose in glycerine, estradiol spray, systemic use of streptomycin, potassium iodide, placental extract.
  • Surgical management includes the modified Young's operation or narrowing the nasal turbinates.

Related Pearl: Etiology of atrophic rhinitis

Etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Hereditary- Involves more than one member of a family
  • Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause
  • Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races
  • Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies
  • Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa
  • Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae

Etiology of secondary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy and, rhinoscleroma
  • Long-standing purulent sinusitis
  • Radiotherapy to nose
  • Excessive surgical removal of turbinates
  • Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

Atrophic rhinitis is more common in females and usually starts at puberty. It is a bilateral condition.

  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia).
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale.

questions.text: Anxious parents complain to the police that their daughter was allegedly kidnapped by a man. When police found her and produced her before the court she said she is a major and is married to the man. An X-ray image of her hand is given below. What is the approximate age of the girl?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray of the hand shows the appearance of pisiform (more than 10 years) but no fusion of base of 1st metacarpal (less than 17 years). Among the given options, the likely age of the girl is <17 years and she is not as major.

The base of 1st metacarpal appears at 2-3 years of age and fuses at 15-17 years of age. Since it is not fused in this case, the age is less than 17 years. If it has fused the likely age is >15 years. 

The lower end of the radius appears at 2 years of age and fuses at 18-19 years of age. The lower end of the ulna appears at 5-6 years of age and fuses at 17-18 years of age. Here, both remain unfused indicating further that the age is likely to be less than 18.

Pisiform ossification center appears at 10-12 years of age. If it had not appeared, the likely age is <12 years.

The appearance of ossification centers of carpal bones:

  • Capitate: 2-3 months
  • Hamate:  2 months
  • Triquetral: 3 years
  • Lunate: 4 years
  • Scaphoid: 5 years
  • Trapezium: 6 years
  • Trapezoid: 5 years
  • Pisiform: 10-12 years

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented to the dermatology department with lesions over the skin as shown below. On examination, the lesions were dry, scaly, and slightly shiny, with moderately diminished sensation. Which type of leprosy do these lesions indicate?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with dry scaly lesions and moderately diminished sensation, with the image showing moderately hypo-esthetic annular plaques which are punched-out, is suggestive of the borderline type of leprosy.

Borderline (BB) leprosy is the most immunologically unstable type. The characteristic lesions of BB leprosy are annular plaques with well-demarcated, punched-out inner margins and sloping outer margins. They appear as large plaques with islands of clinically normal skin within the center, giving rise to a Swiss cheese appearance.
