questions.text: A 50-year-old man with ischaemic heart disease is admitted to the hospital for coronary artery bypass graft (CABG). Before harvesting the artery planned to be used in the procedure, the surgeon performs the Allen's test which is found to be positive. Identify the artery planned to be used as a graft in this patient.
questions.solution:
The artery planned to be used as a graft in this patient is the radial artery.

Allen's test is done in a patient in whom a radial arterial harvest is planned and therefore, in this patient, the radial artery has been planned to be used as a graft for the procedure.

The radial artery runs along the lateral aspect of the forearm and distal to the wrist, where it splits into superficial and deep palmar branches; likewise, the ulnar artery runs along the medial aspect of the forearm and at the wrist splits into its deep and superficial palmar branches. These arches form the basis of collateral blood flow to the hands.

The Allen's test is used to assess collateral circulation in the hands, usually in preparation for a procedure that would disrupt blood flow in either the radial or the ulnar artery, which form the palmar arches. Examples of procedures include arterial punctures, cannulation, or the arterial harvest for a procedure like coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) or as part of a forearm flap.

A negative Allen's test means that the patient likely does not have an adequate dual blood supply to the hand; this means that either the planned procedure cannot be carried out or least suggests that further evaluation is necessary.

In this test, the patient clenches their hand by making a fist and the surgeon compresses the radial and ulnar arteries with his fingertips. The patient is then asked to relax his hand. If there is flushing of the thumb within 5 seconds after pressure on the ulnar artery is released, there is confirmation of collateral flow through the palmar arterial arch. This indicates a positive test.

Delayed return of normal color, taking about 5–10 seconds indicates an equivocal test or insufficient collateral circulation (>10 seconds). 

Related Pearl: Indications for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG)

Class I indications for CABG from the American College of Cardiology(ACC) and American Heart Association(AHA).

  • Left main disease
  • Three-vessel disease with or without proximal LAD disease
  • Two vessel disease with proximal LAD disease
  • Survivors of sudden cardiac death with presumed ischemia-mediated VT  

Other indications for CABG include the following:

  • Disabling angina
  • Ongoing ischemia in the setting of a non–ST-segment elevation (MI) that is unresponsive to medical therapy
  • Poor LV function but with viable, nonfunctioning myocardium above the anatomic defect that can be revascularized

questions.text: The district you are in charge of has a spike in the number of pediatric COVID cases. You are assigned the responsibility of setting up a Dedicated COVID-19 Health Centre (DCHC). Which of the following is not an ideal centre for establishing a DCHC?
questions.solution:
Medical colleges are not converted to dedicated COVID-19 Health Centres (DCHCs). They have the infrastructure to meet the needs of higher care and are used to establish dedicated COVID-19 Hospitals (DCHs). 

COVID-19 hospitals are categorized into three types. As per the management algorithm for COVID-19 cases, infrastructure and other health system requirements vary by symptoms. They are as follows :

  • Severe cases - dedicated COVID-19 hospitals (DCHs),
  • Moderate symptoms, particularly those requiring oxygen support - dedicated COVID-19 health centres (DCHCs) and
  • Mild or asymptomatic cases - home isolated / COVID-19 care centres (CCCs)

DCHCs have hospital beds with facilities to cater for Oxygen delivery with/without High Dependency Units (HDU) and are not equipped to take on severe COVID-19 cases.

DCHs typically have all components of hospital care including Intensive Care Units (ICU) and are usually the preferred centres for severe COVID-19 patients.

Examples where DCHC/Level 2 Care can be established :

  • Primary Health Centres (PHC),
  • Community Health Centres (CHCs)
  • Small District Hospitals (DH)
  • Urban Health facilities

These locations will have to be upgraded and mentoring by a higher centre is required.

Examples where DCH/Level 3 Care can be established :

  • Medical colleges
  • Large district hospitals

These have the infrastructure to meet the needs of higher care, but often need re-purposing of prevailing structure to cater for the special needs of pediatric COVID cases.

questions.text: A patient presented with symptoms of right-sided hemiparesis, marked hemisensory loss of the arm and face, aphasia, and homonymous hemianopia. He had no personality changes or impairment of memory. The occlusion of which of the following arteries could be responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The occlusion of the middle cerebral artery on the left side is responsible for these symptoms.

The middle cerebral artery is the largest branch of the internal carotid artery.

It runs laterally in the lateral sulcus and its cortical branches supply the entire lateral surface of the cerebral hemisphere except for the narrow strip supplied by the anterior cerebral artery, the occipital pole, and the inferolateral surface of the hemisphere, which are supplied by the posterior cerebral artery.

Therefore, it supplies the entire motor area except for the part representing the leg over the cerebral cortex. Its central branches enter the anterior perforated substance and supply the lentiform and caudate nuclei as well as the internal capsule.

Occlusion of the middle cerebral artery may produce the following signs and symptoms, with a clinical picture will varying according to the site of occlusion and the degree of collateral circulation present:

  • Contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss mainly involve the face and arm as it supplies the precentral and postcentral gyri 
  • Aphasia if the left hemisphere is affected 
  • Contralateral homonymous hemianopia due to involvement of the optic radiation
  • Anosognosia if the right hemisphere is affected 

Other options:

Option B: Anterior cerebral artery occlusion produces contralateral hemiparesis and hemisensory loss of the leg and foot. It also manifests as an inability to correctly identify objects, apathy, and personality changes. 

Option C: Posterior cerebral artery occlusion produces contralateral homonymous hemianopia with some macular sparing (due to collateral blood supply to occipital pole. It also produces visual agnosia and memory impairment. 

Option D: Vertebrobasilar artery occlusion produces

  • Ipsilateral pain and temperature loss of the face
  • Contralateral pain and temperature loss of the body
  • Attacks of hemianopia or complete cortical blindness
  • Ipsilateral loss of gag reflex, dysphagia, hoarseness
  • Vertigo, nystagmus, nausea, and vomiting
  • Ipsilateral Horner's syndrome
  • Ipsilateral ataxia and other cerebellar signs
  • Unilateral or bilateral hemiparesis
  • Coma

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presented with a breast lump categorized as BI-RADS 4. What is the next best step in management?

BI-RADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System
questions.solution:
The best option for further management would be tissue diagnosis by biopsy.

A BI-RADS category 4 is indicative of a suspicious abnormality with the likelihood of malignancy being 2% to 95%. Therefore, the next best step would be a tissue diagnosis by biopsy for ruling out/confirmation of the malignancy.

The Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) is used to categorize the degree of suspicion of malignancy for a mammographic abnormality. This is helpful when mammographic abnormalities that cannot be detected by the patient's physical examination include clustered microcalcifications and areas of abnormal density that have not yielded a palpable finding.

Other options:

Option A: Annual screening is usually done for BI-RADS categories 1 and 2. BI-RADS 1 means that there are no masses, suspicious calcifications, or areas of architectural distortion on mammography. BI-RADS 2 is consistent with benign findings including secretory calcifications, simple cysts, fat-containing lesions, calcified fibroadenomas, implants, and intramammary lymph nodes.

Option B: Bi-annual screening is done for BI-RADS category 3. BI-RADS 3 includes a non-palpable, circumscribed mass or a solitary group of punctate calcifications on a mammogram.

Option D: Surgical excision/lumpectomy is done for BI-RADS category 6 which indicates a known, biopsy-proven malignancy. 

Related Pearl: BIRADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System

Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) standardizes the reporting for mammography and ultrasonography and helps guide decision making:

questions.text: A physiologist studies a chemoreceptor that detects elevated sodium levels and decreases the glomerular filtration rate. In the given image of the juxtaglomerular apparatus, which of the marked structures represents this chemoreceptor?
questions.solution:
The chemoreceptors that detect elevated sodium and decrease the glomerular filtration rate are the macula densa cells in the distal convoluted tubule. These are marked as '1' in the given illustration.

Macula densa cells are chemoreceptors that detect sodium and chloride concentrations of the tubular fluid. In response to elevated sodium and chloride, the macula densa cells trigger the contraction of the afferent arteriole, resulting in decreased flow of blood to the glomerulus and reduced glomerular filtration rate (GFR). This vasoconstriction is mediated via increased sodium-potassium ATPase activity leading to increased adenosine formation resulting in calcium release. 

The given illustration shows:

1- Macula densa: These are specialized cells at the start of the distal convoluted tubule form the macula densa. 

2- Granular cells/JG cells: These are modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole; these are mechanoreceptors that secrete renin in response to a fall in blood pressure, which in turn, increases the blood pressure. 

3- Lacis cells: These are extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole. 

4- Proximal tubular cells: These are involved in sustaining glomerulotubular balance, a mechanism by which the percentage of the reabsorbed solutes is maintained at constant levels. This is achieved by increasing the reabsorption of the solutes and water in the proximal convoluted tubule in response to increased GFR.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man was diagnosed with hypertension 3 years back. He was started on ACE inhibitors and he takes them regularly. His blood pressure readings have been regularly monitored since and he has been on regular follow-up without any complications. His current blood pressure readings are 124/78 mmHg. This case will fall under ___________ in the given image below.

(In the given image, 1 represents the whole community/population)
questions.solution:
The above diagram depicts the rule of halves. The given scenario describes a patient that is being adequately treated. Therefore, it would fall under the cases depicted as 9 in the image.

The numbers in the diagram denote the following:

  1. Whole community
  2. Normotensive subjects
  3. Hypertensive subjects
  4. Undiagnosed hypertension
  5. Diagnosed hypertension
  6. Diagnosed but untreated
  7. Diagnosed and treated
  8. Inadequately treated
  9. Adequately treated

The rule of halves depicts that only about half of the hypertensive subjects in the general population of most developed countries were aware of the condition and only half of those aware are being treated and only half of those being treated are considered to be adequately treated.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient with multiple sclerosis presents with the complaints of visual difficulties and headache. Ophthalmologic examination of the patient is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptoms and the examination findings point towards a diagnosis of internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO).

The site of lesion in the case of internuclear ophthalmoplegia is medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF).

In INO, there is impaired adduction on the ipsilateral side of the lesion, and nystagmus on abduction on the contralateral side.

As seen in the image above, on the left gaze, there is impaired adduction of the right eye and nystagmus on the abduction of the left eye. This means that the lesion is in the right MLF. The right gaze is normal. 

A few causes of INO include demyelinating diseases (such as multiple sclerosis, Guillian Barre syndrome), strokes, and tumors.

When the gaze is initiated, the horizontal gaze center or the paramedian pontine reticular formation (PPRF) generates the eye movements.

The PPRF has two outputs. The first is to the ipsilateral 6th cranial nerve nucleus which causes abduction of the ipsilateral eye.

The second output is to the MLF which sends an impulse to the contralateral 3rd cranial nerve nucleus causing contralateral adduction.

These two outputs from PPRF lead to conjugate movement of the eyes to the same side. 

The following image shows the pathway for horizontal eye movements as described above. 

 
Features of unilateral INO include
  • Straight gaze in the primary position of the eyes
  • Impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye with the contralateral eye having nystagmus on abduction
  • Looking at the ipsilateral side has no gaze issues
  • Convergence may be intact if the lesion is anterior and discrete.
Bilateral INO would present with a limitation of ipsilateral adduction and nystagmus of the contralateral eye for both sides.
Other options: 
 
Option B - Cranial nerve VI palsy is characterized by double vision, esotropia, and limitation of abduction on the same side of the lesion. The affected eye would have normal adduction. The following image shows a left cranial nerve VI palsy.
 
 
Option C - Vertical gaze palsy is seen in Parinaud syndrome. It is characterized by supranuclear upgaze and downgaze palsy on the saccadic movement of the eye, impaired convergence, lid retraction, and convergence-retraction nystagmus. 
 
Option D - Cranial nerve IV palsy is characterized by ipsilateral hypertropia, extorsion, limitation of depression, and a compensatory head posture (depressed chin).

questions.text:
A 46-year-old male patient presented with acute renal failure. A dynamic radionuclide renography was ordered to assess the renal perfusion. Which of the following radionuclides are preferred?

99mTc-MAG3 - mercaptoacetyltriglycine 

99m-Tc-MDP - methylene diphosphonate
questions.solution:
99mTc-MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine) is used for performing dynamic radionuclide renography, to assess renal perfusion.

99mTc-MAG3 dynamic radionuclide renography is the simplest and safest way to assess renal perfusion in patients with renal failure. It helps in differentiating the reversible causes of acute renal failure such as acute tubular necrosis, from conditions like intrinsic parenchymal disease where it is severely impaired or absent.

Dynamic renography:

  • Used to assess split renal function and drainage from the renal collecting systems in suspected obstruction
  • 99mTc-MAG3 is the most commonly used isotope in dynamic renography. Its uptake reflects the tubular function
  • 99mTc-DTPA may also be used. Its uptake reflects the glomerular function and hence, it is commonly used to assess GFR

Indications for 99mTc-MAG3 Dynamic Renography:

  • To find divided renal function and urinary drainage where the collecting system is significantly dilated
  • To find differential renal function following surgery or procedure. Examples: post pyeloplasty or post removal of a double J stent
  • To assess for a urinary leak or possible obstruction following renal transplantation

Other options:

Option A- 99mTc-pertechnetate is used in the imaging of the thyroid, salivary glands, and Meckel's diverticulum imaging.

Option B- 99mTc-sulphur colloid is used in liver/spleen imaging, and prosthetic infection.

Option D- 99m-Tc-MDP (methylene diphosphonate) is used for bone scintigraphy.

questions.text: Which of the following recommendation was made by the Kartar Singh committee?

choices.text: Development of  primary health centers in 2 stages
Constitution of an All India Health Services

questions.solution:
Kartar Singh Committee recommended the feasibility of having multipurpose workers under health and family planning in India.

Kartar Singh Committee under the ministry of health and family planning recommended the following:

  • Structure for integrated services at the peripheral and supervisory levels
  • Feasibility of having multipurpose workers in the field and their training requirements 
  • Mobile service units for integrated medical, public health, and family planning

Other options:

Option A:  The development of primary health centers in 2 stages was recommended by the Bhore committee. Along with it the integration of preventive and curative services at all administrative levels was also recommended. The inclusion of 3 months of preventive and social medicine training in medical education was another suggestion put forward.

Option B: The development of a referral services complex was recommended by the Shrivastav Committee. This committee also recommended the establishment of a medical and health education commission.

Option D: Constitution of all India health services on the pattern of an Indian administrative service was recommended by the Mudaliar committee of 1962. It is also known as the health survey and planning committee. They found the services provided by the PHC are inadequate and advised strengthening of existing PHCs. It also recommended strengthening district hospitals with specialist services.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with an ovarian tumor. Histopathological examination of the tumor specimen is shown in the below image. This finding indicates which of the following tumors?
questions.solution:
The given image shows signet ring cells which are seen in Kruckenberg tumors.

Krukenberg tumors are secondary growth in the ovary and most often arise from primary carcinoma of the stomach (70%), large bowel (15%), and breast (6%).

Features:

  • Usually bilateral
  • Have a smooth surface
  • They retain the shape of the normal ovary.
  • There is no tendency to form adhesions with neighboring viscera and they are freely movable in the pelvis.
  • There is no infiltration through the capsule
  • Have a waxy consistency

Histologically, numerous signet-ring cells with pale cytoplasm are seen.

Other options:

Dysgerminona is a type of germ cell tumor and it corresponds to the seminoma of the testis. It secretes placental alkaline phosphatase (ALP), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and β-hCG. 

The image below shows the histopathology of a dysgerminoma, characterized by the arrangement of large tumor cells in bunches. Lymphocytes and giant cells are seen in between the tumor cells. Infiltration of fibrous septa by lymphocytes is an important diagnostic feature.

 


Endodermal sinus tumor/Yolk sac tumor is a type of ovarian germ cell tumor that is seen in premenarchal girls. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is commonly produced by this tumor, which is used as a tumor marker. 

Grossly these tumors appear as yellow, friable (hemorrhagic), solid mass. Microscopically, these tumors show Schiller-Duval bodies, which are seen as papillary projections composed of a central core of blood vessels and are lined by tumor cells. They are pathognomonic when present.

 

Mucinous cystadenoma is a mucin-containing epithelial ovarian tumor. These tumors are usually multilocular and are lined by single columnar epithelium. They are usually unilateral and are found along with a dermoid cyst or a Brenner tumor. Grossly they have a glistening surface, and the cut section reveals multiple loculi filled with mucinous contents. If the tumour ruptures, it may lead to formation of pseudomyxoma peritonei.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents with the following finding as shown in the image below. On further investigation, she is found to have reduced levels of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. Which of the following disorders is she most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
With the given clinical scenario and with reduced levels of enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, the patient is most likely suffering from Gilbert syndrome. 

Gilbert syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition characterized by decreased activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for the conjugation of bilirubin. This leads to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, that presents as yellowish discolouration of the sclera (icterus/jaundice) as seen in the given image.

Individuals with Gilbert syndrome are usually asymptomatic except for intermittent episodes of jaundice, which usually occurs for the first time during adolescence, due to changes in the concentration of sex hormones. Some patients may have complaints like malaise, fatigue, nausea, anxiety, loss of appetite, and abdominal discomfort. Symptoms are usually precipitated by triggers such as fasting, intercurrent illness, menstruation, and dehydration.

Administration of phenobarbital shows normalisation of the serum bilirubin concentration and hepatic bilirubin clearance.

Gilbert syndrome usually doesn't require any treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Type I Crigler-Najjar syndrome is characterized by a complete deficiency of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. It usually presents as severe congenital jaundice (serum bilirubin levels over 20 mg/dL) and accompanying brain damage.

Options C and D: Dubin Johnson and Rotor syndrome both have elevated conjugated bilirubin in the blood, and are due to defective secretion of conjugated bilirubin into the bile.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was admitted to your hospital with multiple pigmented papular lesions on his face, neck, forearm, and corneal injection following the exposure to the sun as shown below.  On further investigations, cutaneous malignancies like squamous cell carcinomas and basal cell carcinoma were found. Which DNA repair mechanism is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of multiple lesions on the sun-exposed area and multiple cutaneous malignancies are suggestive of Xeroderma pigmentosum. The DNA repair mechanism that is defective in this condition is nucleotide excision repair (NER).

Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) is a rare autosomal recessive genetic disorder characterized by defective DNA repair which leads to clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to ultraviolet (UV) radiation.

UV radiation leads to pyrimidine dimerization in DNA strands, preventing further replication by DNA polymerase. The nucleotide excision repair mechanism corrects the dimer formation in DNA. In XP there is an inability to repair DNA pyrimidine dimers caused by UV exposure.

In XP the skin is normal at birth. Initially, there will be diffuse erythema, scaling, and freckle lesions. As age progresses a characterized lesion called poikiloderma occurs. It consists of skin atrophy, telangiectasia, and mottled hyper and hypopigmented areas. By the age of 4 -5 years, they present with multiple malignancies including squamous cell carcinoma, malignant melanoma, basal cell carcinoma, and fibrosarcoma.

Most of the cases with XP have ocular manifestations. Initially, it appears as photophobia, conjunctivitis, ectropion, and symblepharon with ulceration. Accumulation of pyrimidine dimer causes corneal opacification and neovascularization. Ocular malignancies are common in the lids, conjunctiva, and cornea as they are exposed to as much as facial skin.

XP is ultimately fatal, and early detection of the skin lesions and their management with prevention of UV rays exposures prolong the life.

questions.text: You are informed that the country’s security agency suspects bioterrorism as there was a sudden surge in patients presenting with fever, severe headache, vomiting followed by convulsions, and altered sensorium. The transmission cycle of the likely causative agent is given below. To which bioterrorism category does it belong?
questions.solution:
The given history and the above image depicts the transmission cycle of the Nipah virus. It belongs to category C bioterrorism

Nipah virus is a zoonotic RNA virus that shows both animal-to-human (bats, pigs) and human-to-human transmission. The natural hosts are fruit bats.

Transmission:

  • During the 1999 outbreak among pig farmers in Malaysia, the transmission was from direct contact with sick pigs, or exposure to secretions from the pigs, or contact with the contaminated tissues of pigs.
  • In subsequent outbreaks (in 2001) in Bangladesh and India, the consumption of fruits or fruit products((such as raw date palm juice) contaminated with urine or saliva from infected fruit bats was the most likely source of infection.
  • Human-to-human transmission through close contact with people's secretions and excretions has also been reported.

Infected people present with fever, headaches, myalgia, vomiting, sore throat followed by dizziness, drowsiness, altered consciousness, and neurological signs that indicate encephalitis.

Bioterrorism is the deliberate release of an agent by attackers that causes one or more of a variety of different diseases.

The agents of bioterrorism are classified into 3 categories:

Category A bioterrorism agents are those which are easily transmitted from one person to the other and are associated with high mortality rates and thus have the potential to cause major public health impacts. Examples include Bacillus anthracis, Clostridium botulinum and Yersinia pestis.

Category B bioterrorism agents are those which are moderately easy to disseminate and are associated with moderate morbidity and low mortality rates. Examples include Coxiella burnetti and Brucella.

Category C bioterrorism agents are those which are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future due to ease of availability, high mortality and morbidity rates, and ease of production and dissemination. Examples include Nipah and Hanta viruses.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with periorbital swelling as shown below. She complains of significant visual impairment and a fungal etiology is suspected. What is the most appropriate drug for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of invasive mucormycosis in the form of orbital cellulitis. Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection seen in patients with diabetes mellitus, leukaemia, lymphoma and other immunocompromised states. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza. 

Invasive mucormycosis has recently emerged as a life-threatening complication of COVID-19 in India. It is an opportunistic infection seen even in mild to moderate COVID patients with strong predisposing factors like hyperglycemia / uncontrolled diabetes. Diabetic patients receiving corticosteroids / immunosuppressants for COVID-19 treatment are exceptionally vulnerable to develop mucormycosis due to the risk of steroid-induced hyperglycemia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with a swelling in the lower abdomen as seen in the image below. On examination, it is seen that the swelling was reducible and a CT scan showed the presence of a defect in the aponeurosis of the transversus abdominis muscle with the hernia lying deep to the external oblique aponeurosis. This presentation is typical of what type of hernia?
questions.solution:
This clinical presentation is typical of a spigelian hernia.

Spigelian hernias arise from a defect in the spigelian fascia, which is the aponeurosis of the transversus abdominis muscle. The fascia extends between the transversus muscle and the lateral border of the rectus sheath from the costal margin to the groin, where it blends into the conjoint tendon.

Most spigelian hernias appear below the level of the umbilicus near the edge of the rectus sheath. 

In young patients, these hernias usually contain extraperitoneal fat only and they present with intermittent pain due to pinching of the fat. A lump may or may not be palpable because the fatty hernia is small and the overlying external oblique is intact. In older patients, there is often a peritoneal sac and they can become very large in size. They generally present with a reducible swelling at the edge of the rectus sheath and may have symptoms of intermittent obstruction.

The diagnosis can be made from the location of the symptoms and is confirmed by CT. If the hernia is reducible, ultrasonography can be done.

Surgery is recommended for treatment because of the predisposition to strangulation, it can either be open or laparoscopic. In open surgery, a skin crease is made over the hernia, and the sac is usually visible once the external oblique is opened. The sac and contents are dealt with and the defect in the Spigelian fascia is repaired by suture or mesh laid deep to the external oblique aponeurosis. 

Laparoscopy is useful if no sac is palpable. However, in young patients with a hernia containing only extraperitoneal fat with no hernia seen from within the peritoneum, the peritoneum can be incised and the extraperitoneal plane explored for the small defect, which can then be closed by either suture or mesh. When an intraperitoneal sac is present, a laparoscopic repair can be performed using either the intra-peritoneal onlay of mesh (IPOM) or transabdominal pre-peritoneal mesh repair (TAPP) technique.

Other options:

Option A: Epigastric hernia arises through the linea alba anywhere between the xiphoid process and the umbilicus. They begin with a transverse split in the midline raphe. Epigastric hernia defects are usually less than 1 cm in diameter and commonly contain only extraperitoneal fat, which gradually enlarges, spreading in the subcutaneous plane. More than one hernia may be present and it usually occurs in men between the second and fourth decades. They can become very painful, due to the partial strangulation of the contents. A soft midline swelling can often be felt and it may be tender. It is unlikely to be reducible because of the narrow neck.

The image below shows an epigastric hernia.

Option C: Incisional hernia arises through a defect in the abdominal wall in the region of a postoperative scar. Incisional hernias have been reported more commonly after laparotomy incisions than laparoscopic port-site incisions. Predisposing factors include patient-related factors like obesity, malnutrition, immunosuppression or steroid therapy, wound factors like wound infection, and surgical factors like the use of inappropriate suture material, and incorrect suture placement. They appear as a localized swelling involving a portion of the surgical scar. The skin overlying large hernias may become thin and atrophic so that peristalsis may be seen in the underlying intestine. Vascular damage to the skin may lead to dermatitis. Most incisional hernias are broad-necked and therefore the risk of strangulation is low.

The image below shows an incisional hernia.

Option D: Obturator hernia occurs through the obturator canal between the superior pubic ramus and obturator membrane. It is seen mostly in elderly females and patients usually present with features of intestinal obstruction, which is often confirmed only on laparotomy. In a few cases, it is seen as a swelling in Scarpa's triangle deep to the pectineus muscle, with the limb kept in flexed and abducted position and any movement of the limb resulting in pain. Howship-Romberg sign is positive in about half the cases; this involves referred pain in the knee joint through the geniculate branch of the obturator nerve, which not only signifies an obturator hernia but also strangulation.

questions.text: A 33-year-old patient comes for a routine evaluation. She asks for contraceptive methods. You advise the following intrauterine contraceptive device for her. Which of the following statements about this device is incorrect?

choices.text: Can be used in women with menorrhagia

questions.solution:
The given IUCD is Mirena. It is not contraindicated in women on tamoxifen.

Mirena is used in woman, who is on tamoxifen therapy for breast cancer, as it suppresses endometrial hyperplasia caused by estrogen. 

Mirena IUCD is an effective and reversible contraceptive. It contains 52mg levonorgestrel in a silastic reservoir in its vertical arm.

  • It does not suppress ovulation.
  • It acts mainly on the endometrium and cervical mucus.
  • It reduces menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea and it can be used in patients with abnormal uterine bleeding and endometrial hyperplasia.

Advantages of Mirena 

  • One-time insertion 
  • Effective for 5 years 
  • Compliance 
  • Reduces menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with COVID-19 has been started on a treatment regimen called "REGEN COV/ Ronapreve", consisting of the monoclonal antibodies Casirivimab and Imdevimab. What is the mechanism of action of this regimen?
questions.solution:
The REGEN COV/Ronapreve regimen acts as an entry inhibitor.

REGEN-COV/Ronapreve is a "cocktail" of two fully human non-competing, neutralizing antibodies : Casirivimab and Imdevimab.

Casirivimab and Imdevimab are a combination therapy of two recombinant human IgG1 monoclonal antibodies, which are unmodified in the Fc regions, where each antibody targets target the receptor binding domain (RBD) on the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein and blocks normal virus entry via the human angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (hACE2) receptor, which has high affinity for the spike protein's RBD.

Their combination not only helps safeguard against the rapid emergence of drug-resistant variants and provide wide coverage against existing viral variants but additionally, in vitro studies have shown that the "cocktail" combination protected against rapid escape of the virus, which was seen with its individual components were given separately.

Additionally, the benefit of this combination approach is that it retains effectiveness and potency against emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants associated with increased infectivity (like the UK B.1.1.7 variant), as well as those associated with reduced vaccine-induced neutralization titers or vaccine efficacy (like South Africa B.1.351); and this is made possible by REGEN COV even when one of its components has partially reduced activity.

The dosage in adults and adolescent patients 12 years of age and older, weighing ≥40 kg is 600 mg of casirivimab and 600 mg of imdevimab administered as a single intravenous (IV) infusion or by subcutaneous (SC) injection. Casirivimab with imdevimab should be given within 7 days of the onset of symptoms of COVID-19.

For post-exposure prophylaxis the dosage in adults and adolescent patients 12 years of age and older weighing at least 40 kg is 600 mg of casirivimab and 600 mg of imdevimab administered as a single IV infusion or by SC injection. Casirivimab with imdevimab should be given as soon as possible after contact with a case of COVID-19.

The commonly reported signs and symptoms for these reactions included nausea, chills, dizziness or syncope, rash, urticaria and flushing, hypersensitivity reactions when given as an intravenous infusion, while it can give rise to injection site reactions, urticaria and lymphadenopathy when given subcutaneously. It should be avoided in pregnancy and in breastfeeding mother as enough data regarding its safety / toxicity to the fetus / infant is not available.

Other options:

Option B: Protease inhibitors include Lopinavir and Atazanavir, which is active against HIV-1 and HIV-2 and can be given to adults and children >14 days and > 3 months respectively.

Option C: Reverse transcriptase inhibitors include Nevirapine and Efavirenz which are used to manage HIV-1 infection in children.

Option D: Integrase inhibitors include Raltegravir and Dolutegravir which are used in the management of HIV-infected adults and children.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man is referred to the dermatology department with the following pruritic skin lesions that have been present for 4 months. The lesions are extremely painful. On examination, there are flaccid blisters that rupture easily with normal mucosal surfaces over the seborrheic area and a positive Nikolsky sign. Under which layer of the skin, does the bullous split occur in this condition?

Image: Histology of layers of skin.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pemphigus foliaceus. The blisters are formed due to a split at the subcorneal layer which is marked as 1 in the image.

Pemphigus foliaceus is a chronic blistering disease characterized by flaccid bullae with exfoliation mainly over the seborrhoeic area and with mucosal sparing. It is less severe than pemphigus vulgaris with antibodies against desmoglein-1.

The lesion in pemphigus foliaceus initially appears as small flaccid bullae which rupture as soon they appear leading to crusting. Lesions typically have a fine collarette of scale.

Most of the patients present with burning pain and pruritic lesions for a long period of time. Both the genders are equally affected and, mainly occur between 40 - 50 years of age. 

The histologic examination shows acantholysis in the upper epidermis and the stratum corneum will be separated from the underlying epidermis. 

On examination, it gives a positive Nikolsky sign. Dapsone and hydroxychloroquine can be used in treatment.

From superficial to deep, the layers of the epidermis are marked in the below image-

  1. Stratum corneum
  2. Stratum granulosum
  3. Stratum spinosum
  4. Stratum basale

In skin over the palmar and plantar surface, an electron-lucent additional zone called stratum lucidum is present between granulosum and corneum. 

The below image shows the blisters in pemphigus foliaceus.

Nikolsky's sign is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or perilesional skin. This leads to the separation of the normal‐looking epidermis from the dermis, producing an erosion. Lateral pressure on the normal skin around the blister results in separation between the upper and lower layers of the epidermis. Nikolsky′s sign is usually positive in diseases with epidermal acantholysis and negative in diseases with dermo-epidermal separation. This distinguishes pemphigus from bullous pemphigoid.

Nikolsky's sign is the pathognomic features of pemphigus, toxic epidermal necrolysis, and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome(SSSS).

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman is brought to your clinic by her friend who reports that the patient eats large amounts of food when she is alone and that food wrappers are often found hidden in her room. Once or twice a week, she vomits after having a large meal. On examination, erosion of teeth enamel is noted. Her BMI is found to be 19. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of binge eating, followed by self-induced vomiting, with normal weight, is suggestive of bulimia nervosa.

DSM 5 diagnostic criteria for bulimia nervosa are as follows:

  • A recurrent episode of binge eating characterized by
    • eating relatively a large amount of food in a short span of time
    • lack of control during the episode
  • Recurrent inappropriate compensatory behaviors in order to prevent weight gain, such as self-induced vomiting, misuse of laxatives, or excessive exercise.
  • This behavior is present at least once a week for 3 months
  • There is fear of becoming fat or wanting to lose weight
  • It does not occur during the periods of anorexia nervosa

It can be treated with cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and pharmacotherapy.

CBT involves disrupting the cycle of repeated binge eating-purging and changing the patient's beliefs about food, body weight, body image, etc. Drugs usually used in the treatment of bulimia nervosa are fluoxetine, imipramine, desipramine, trazodone, and monoamine oxidase inhibitors.

Other options:

Option A - Anorexia nervosa is diagnosed by the presence of

  • Restriction of food intake, leading to a significantly low body weight
  • Intense fear of gaining weight or persistent behavior that interferes with weight gain, even though at a significantly low weight.
  • Undue influence of body weight or shape on self-evaluation, or persistent lack of recognition of the seriousness of the current low body weight.

Patients with anorexia nervosa would have weight loss, whereas those with bulimia nervosa would have weight in the normal range.

Option C - Night eating disorder is characterized by the consumption of a large amount of food after an evening meal. Patients generally have a low appetite during the day and have insomnia. They are not overly concerned with their body image and weight, and the amount of food consumed is lower than that consumed during binge eating in bulimia and binge eating disorder. Patients have a high risk for obesity and metabolic syndrome.

Option D - Binge eating disorder is characterized by recurrent episodes of binge eating without the recurrent use of compensatory behaviors.

questions.text: You are a resident doctor who tends to a patient brought to the emergency room following a road traffic accident. He has an open fracture of the tibia, his limbs are cold and clammy and his BP is 90/50 mmHg, and pulse 130 beats/min. You start the patient on IV Plasma-Lyte. The true statement about this IV fluid is that:

choices.text: It is an isotonic electrolyte preparation
It does not have buffer action

questions.solution:
The true statement about Plasma-Lyte is that it is a crystalloid fluid with isotonic electrolyte composition.

The type of fluid administered to a patient depends on his/her volume status and the type of compositional abnormality present. Plasma- Lyte is isotonic and is useful in replacing gastrointestinal losses and correcting extracellular volume deficits.

Plasma-Lyte is an isotonic crystalloid preparation; it resembles the electrolyte composition of the human plasma very closely. In addition, Plasma- Lyte contains a number of additional buffers that create a favourable profile for helping with acidosis.

It consists of 140 mEq/L of sodium, 98 mEq/L of chloride, 5 mEq/L of potassium, 27 mEq/L of bicarbonate and 3 mEq/L of Magnesium.

These properties have resulted in Plasma-Lyte becoming one of the most popular isotonic fluids for use, especially in surgery. However, Plasma- Lyte contains small quantities of potassium; and though the likelihood of inducing hyperkalemia is very low, care should be taken when using Plasma-Lyte in patients at risk for renal impairment.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida of 32 weeks presented with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the uterus was tender and the cardiotocograph showed fetal distress. However, the mother is hemodynamically stable. What is the grade of placental abruption in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of grade 2 abruptio placenta.

Abruptio placentae refer to the premature separation of the placenta, either partially or totally from its implantation site before delivery. 

Depending upon the degree of placental abruption and its clinical effects, the cases are graded as follows:

Grade 1

Grade 2

Grade 3

Slight vaginal bleeding 

Mild to moderate vaginal bleeding

Bleeding is moderate to severe or concealed.

Minimal uterine tenderness

Uterine tenderness is  present

Marked uterine tenderness

Maternal BP and fibrinogen will be unaffected

Increased maternal pulse, but BP is maintained, fibrinogen levels may be decreased

 BP decreases, associated coagulation defect or anuria may complicate

FHS good

Fetal distress present

Fetal death occurs

 Maternal shock absent

Maternal shock absent

Pronounced shock

Note: In Grade 0 abruptio placenta, No clinical are present and it is usually diagnosed after delivery by inspecting the expelled placenta.

Management of abruptio placenta depends whether the patient is in labor or not.

  • If the patient is in labor, accelerate the process by amniotomy and oxytocin drip. Amniotomy initiates myometrial contraction and labor process and expedites delivery. It also reduces the risk of renal cortical necrosis and DIC
  • If the patient is not in labor and the if the there is continuous bleeding, then delivery is conducted either by induction of labor or cesarean section.

questions.text:
An elderly male patient is diagnosed with cardiac failure. On admission, his urine output is measured to be 200 ml/24 hours with an elevated creatinine level. Which of the following can be an indication for dialysis in this patient?

GFR- Glomerular filtration rate
questions.solution:
Uremic encephalopathy can be an indication of dialysis in this patient.

The above clinical features of oliguria (<400 ml/24 hours) and elevated creatinine levels are suggestive of acute kidney injury.

Dialysis is a form of renal replacement therapy in which the kidney's function of blood filtration is supplemented with artificial equipment to remove excess water, solutes and toxins. Dialysis broadly has 3 types that include hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis and continuous renal replacement therapy.

Indications for dialysis in acute kidney injury (AKI) or end-stage renal disease (ESRD) can be remembered by the mnemonic AEIOU:

  • A- Metabolic acidosis that is refractory to medical treatment
  • E- Electrolyte abnormality: Refractory hyperkalemia not responding to conservative treatment
  • I- Intoxication by drugs
  • O- Severe volume overload resulting in pulmonary edema and causing respiratory distress
  • U- Uremia- encephalopathy, pericarditis, asterixis, seizures, intractable nausea, vomiting, and git bleeding.
  • Bleeding diathesis.
  • Creatinine clearance or estimated glomerular filtration rate (GFR) <10 mL/min per 1.73 m2 (Option B)

Other options:

Option A: Non-refractory hyperkalemia can be managed by restricting the dietary potassium intake, insulin, calcium gluconate or calcium chloride, inhalational β-agonist therapy, and potassium binding ion-exchange resin.

Option C: Volume overload can be managed with diuretics, salt, and water restriction.

questions.text: A 16-month-old child is brought to the emergency room after sustaining a head injury from a fall. On examination, he is irritable and crying, withdraws his hand in response to touching it, and opens his eyes spontaneously. His score on the Glasgow Coma Scale is:
questions.solution:
His score on the Glasgow Coma Scale is 13.

As the child is irritable and crying, the verbal response score is 4. As the child withdraws its hand on touching it, the motor response score is 5 and as he opens his eyes spontaneously, the eye-opening score is 4. The total score would be 13 or can be expressed as E4V4M5.

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) assesses patients according to three aspects of responsiveness: eye-opening, motor, and verbal responses and this way, describes the extent of impaired consciousness in all types of acute medical and trauma patients.

The findings of each component of the GCS can aggregate into a total score which can provide a useful summary of the overall severity and status of the patient. The score is expressed as the sum of the scores as well as the individual elements. For example, a score of 9 might be expressed as GCS9 = E2V4M3. The pediatric GCS applies to children 2 years of age or younger.

questions.text: A baby born at 32 weeks of gestation developed tachypnea, grunting, and cyanosis. Chest X-ray revealed a ground-glass appearance and air bronchogram. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with chest x-ray showing ground-glass appearance and air bronchogram is consistent with the diagnosis of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).

Respiratory distress syndrome (hyaline membrane disease) is primarily seen in premature infants. It is commonly seen before 28 weeks, followed by 32-36 weeks, and is rare after 37 weeks.

Risk factors for RDS include:

  • Maternal diabetes
  • Multiple births
  • Cesarean section
  • Precipitous delivery
  • Asphyxia
  • Maternal history of previously affected infants

The primary cause of RDS is reduced production and secretion of surfactant. It leads to an increase in surface tension and alveolar collapse.

The clinical features include tachypnea, prominent expiratory grunting, intercostal and subcostal retractions, nasal flaring, and cyanosis. They usually appear within minutes of birth. 

Chest radiograph shows diffuse, fine reticular granularity of the parenchyma known as ground-glass appearance and air bronchogram.

Nasal continuous positive airway pressure (nCPAP) is the initial intervention in infants with RDS or in infants at risk of RDS without respiratory failure. Oxygen therapy with warm, humidified oxygen is provided to maintain a target SpO2 of 91-95%. 

Mechanical ventilation is indicated in infants with respiratory failure or persistent apnea. 

Prevention is possible by antenatal administration of betamethasone or dexamethasone before 37 weeks is recommended in preterm labor as it reduces the incidence and mortality of RDS.

Other options:

Option B: Transient tachypnea of the newborn (TTN) is a self-limiting clinical condition caused due to delayed clearance of fetal lung fluid. Early-onset tachypnea, expiratory grunting or retractions, and occasional cyanosis are the characteristic findings. 

The chest radiograph reveals prominent perihilar pulmonary vascular markings and fluid in the interlobar fissures. It is distinguished from RDS by its rapid recovery and the absence of radiographic findings of RDS.

The image given below is the chest radiograph seen in the transient tachypnea of the newborn.

Option C: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) occurs secondary to a structural defect of the diaphragm and is associated with pulmonary hypoplasia. Babies present with tachypnea, grunting, use of accessory muscles, cyanosis, and scaphoid abdomen. The chest radiograph shows bowel loops in the thorax and the contralateral mediastinal shift.

The image given below is the chest radiograph showing multiple gas shadows in the thorax indicating congenital diaphragmatic hernia.

Option D: Meconium aspiration syndrome is the passage of meconium into the amniotic fluid due to fetal distress and hypoxia that gets aspirated into the lungs. It usually occurs in term or post-term infants. The clinical features include tachypnea, retractions, grunting, and cyanosis. The chest radiograph reveals bilateral streaky densities, hyperinflation, flattening of the diaphragm, and atelectasis.

The image given below is the chest radiograph seen in meconium aspiration syndrome.

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby presented with hypertonia, irritability, and tonic spasms with light. These symptoms rapidly progressed resulting in the death of the baby. An autopsy was conducted and the histology of the brain parenchyma is shown below. Which of the following enzyme was deficient in him?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of hypertonia, irritability and tonic spasms with light and the image showing characteristic globoid cells are suggestive of Krabbe disease. The enzyme deficient in Krabbe's disease is beta-galactosidase.

Krabbe's disease or globoid cell leukodystrophy is a neurodegenerative disorder with severe myelin loss and the presence of globoid bodies in white matter.

It is an autosomal recessive leukodystrophy due to the deficiency of galactocerebroside β-galactosidase. β-galactosidase helps in the catabolism of galactocerebroside to ceramide and galactose. As a result, an alternative catabolic pathway shunts galactocerebroside to galactosyl sphingosine. Elevated levels of these compounds are cytotoxic and cause the destruction of oligodendroglia.

The onset of symptoms is between 3 and 6 months of age, dominated by motor signs such as stiffness and weakness. Patients also have irritability and tonic spasms with light or noise stimulation. They often don't survive beyond the age of 2 years. The brain shows loss of myelin and oligodendrocytes with a similar process affecting the peripheral nerves.

The characteristic and diagnostic feature of Krabbe disease is the aggregation of engorged macrophages called globoid cells in the brain parenchyma and around blood vessels.

Other options:

Option B: A deficiency of enzyme alpha-galactosidase results in Fabry's disease. It is characterized by painful acroparaesthesia, hypohidrosis, abdominal cramping, diarrhea, small petechiae around the umbilicus, lenticular opacities, and corneal dystrophy.

Option C: A deficiency of enzyme beta-glucosidase results in Gaucher's disease. It is characterized by joint pain mostly affecting hips and knees, pancytopenia, convulsions, and hepatosplenomegaly. It shows crumbled tissue paper appearance on microscopy.

Option D: A deficiency in enzyme arylsulphatase A results in metachromatic leukodystrophy. It is characterized by progressive regression of milestones, ataxia dysarthria, hypotonia, spasticity hypotonia, hyporeflexia, and optic atrophy.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the pediatrician for the evaluation of a neck mass. On examination, a painless, soft, fluctuating mass is found on the posterior triangle of the neck, as shown in the image below. The slip sign is negative and the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant. Which of the following is not a treatment option for this child?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing mass in the posterior triangle of the neck which is fluctuant and brightly transilluminant is suggestive of cystic hygroma. Sistrunk operation is not a treatment option for cystic hygroma. It is the surgery done for a thyroglossal cyst and limb reduction surgeries in patients with lymphedema.

Cystic hygroma/cavernous lymphangioma is a lymph filled sac that results from the obstruction of the lymph vessels during their development.

Clinically, it presents as a mass in the posterior triangle of the neck. The mass may be apparent at birth or may appear in early childhood due to the increased accumulation of lymph. On examination, it appears as a soft, fluctuating, and brilliantly transilluminant since the sac is filled with lymph.

Complications of cystic hygroma include respiratory difficulty, secondary infection, and chylothorax.

Management:

  • Primarily, the treatment includes aspiration (Option B) of the contents. Later once the sac or capsule gets thickened by fibrous tissue, it is excised.
  • Single cysts are treated with sclerosing therapy (Option C). Commonly used sclerosants include OK– 432 which is an inactive strain of group A Streptococcus pyogenes, pure ethanol, interferon α 2a, and doxycycline.
  • Multiple cysts are treated by complete excision of the cyst (Option D).

questions.text: A couple presents to you with complaints of inability to conceive despite staying together for 4 years and having unprotected intercourse. You advise them to come to the hospital within 2 hours after having sexual intercourse for post-coital test. Which of the following is false regarding this test?

choices.text: Ability of sperms to penetrate cervical mucous can be studied
Cervical mucus viscosity and quantity can be studied
Can detect presence of anti-sperm antibodies

questions.solution:
The test being advised for the above couple is the post-coital test and normally, the sperms should show progressive, but not rotatory movements.

Post-coital test (Sims’ or Huhner’s test):

The couple is advised intercourse close to the ovulation time, preferably in the early hours of the morning. The woman presents herself at the clinic within 2 hours after the intercourse.

The mucus is aspirated from the cervical canal and is spread over a glass slide. Another smear made from the posterior fornix serves as a control. Normally 10–50 motile sperms are seen per high-power field in cervical mucus.

The presence of antispermal antibodies in the cervical mucus imparts shaky or rotatory movements to the sperms or may totally immobilize them. The cervical mucus is simultaneously examined for its quantity, viscosity, and fern test.

The advantage of this test is that the cervical mucus can be simultaneously studied for oestrogenic effect and ovulation and its capability to allow sperm penetration and to look for the presence of any anti-sperm antibodies.

Note: The test is useless in the presence of cervical infection, which should be treated before performing the post-coital test.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient reports to a hospital for a yearly health check-up. On echocardiography, a decrease in cardiac output was observed. This finding is seen in which of the following conditions:
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Decrease in cardiac output is seen in Hypothyroidism.

In hypothyroidism, there is reduced tissue metabolic rate ,as a result of which the oxygen consumption and nutritional needs of the tissues will also be lower. This brings about a decrease in blood flow to the tissues, resulting in reduced cardiac output.

Other non-cardiac peripheral factors responsible for decreased cardiac output due to decreased venous return are:

  • Decreased blood volume, often from hemorrhage is the most common non-cardiac factor that leads to decreased cardiac output
  • Acute venous dilation, most often due to sudden inactivity of the sympathetic nervous system, like in syncope
  • Obstruction of large veins leading to the heart, like the inferior and superior vena cava
  • Decreased skeletal muscle mass, which is in turn associated with decreased oxygen consumption and blood flow needs of the muscles

The cardiac conditions which are associated with decreased cardiac output are:

  • Myocardial infarction due to severe coronary vessel blockage
  • Severe valvular heart disease 
  • Myocarditis
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Cardiac metabolic derangements

Other options:

Option A: Beriberi is caused due to lack of adequate amounts of thiamine (Vitamin B1) in the diet. Lack of thiamine causes decreased ability of tissues to use some cellular nutrients and this results in compensatory peripheral vasodilatation and the total peripheral resistance also decreases markedly, resulting in an increase in cardiac output and venous return.

Option B: When an arteriovenous (AV) fistula occurs between a major artery and a vein, there occurs the flow of a large volume of blood from the artery into the vein, which decreases the total peripheral resistance and as a result, increases venous return and cardiac output.

Option C: In anemia, there is reduced viscosity of blood as a result of decreased red blood cell concentration and simultaneously, there is diminished oxygen delivery to different tissues, causing local vasodilatation and as a result, there is a rise in cardiac output due to decreased peripheral resistance.

questions.text: The presence of which of the following bonds in starch makes it digestible by salivary amylase?
questions.solution:
Salivary α-amylase present in humans acts on α (1→4) glycosidic linkage binding the glucose molecules in dietary starch and glycogen.

Starch is a polymer of glucose that is linked by α(1→4) glycoside bonds, which are catalyzed by salivary and pancreatic amylases. It consists of two types of molecules, amylose (linear and helical) and amylopectin (branched).

Other options: 

α (1→6) linkage is found in glycogen. The primary glycosidic bond is an α (1→4) linkage, whereas the branch point contains an α (1→6) linkage. Salivary amylase can digest α (1→4) linkage but not α (1→6) linkage in the branching point, resulting in the production of a mixture containing short, branched, and unbranched oligosaccharides termed as dextrins.

β (1→4) linkage is found in cellulose. This bond cannot be digested by α-amylase, hence, cellulose doesn't give us energy but serves as a source of fiber in our diet.

Amylopectin  starch

α (1→4) glycosidic linkages with α (1→6) glycosidic branches every 24-30 glucose molecule. Hollow helix

Glycogen

questions.text: You were asked to perform fundoscopy in a patient diagnosed with hypertensive retinopathy. You notice arteriovenous nicking with tapering of veins on either side of the crossings on fundoscopic examination. This sign is known as _______
questions.solution:
Tapering of veins on either side of the crossings is known as the Gunn sign, which is seen on fundoscopy in a patient with hypertensive retinopathy.

Arteriovenous nicking is the hallmark of hypertensive retinopathy. It occurs where the arteriole crosses and compresses the vein, as the vessels share a common adventitious sheath.

These changes are also known as A-V crossing changes and they include:

  • Salu’s sign is the deflection of veins at the arteriovenous crossings.
  • Bonnet sign is the banking of veins distal to arteriovenous crossings, and
  • Gunn sign is the tapering of veins on either side of the crossings.

 

Grading of Hypertensive Retinopathy:

Grade 1: Mild generalized retinal arteriolar narrowing

Grade 2: Focal arteriolar narrowing and arteriovenous nipping. Opacified appearance of arteriolar walls as a copper wiring can be seen.

Grade 3: Grade 2 plus dot/blot/flame-shaped retinal hemorrhages, exudates, and cotton wool spots. Chronic retinal edema results in the deposition of hard exudates around the fovea as a macular star. 

Grade 4: Severe grade 3 plus optic disc swelling. It is a marker of malignant hypertension

questions.text: A 25-year-old football player is brought to the emergency room after falling on the field during a match. His X-ray shows the findings below. Which of the following peripheral blocks is indicated to restore the normal anatomy?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of shoulder dislocation as seen on the X-ray. Interscalene block provides surgical anaesthesia for procedures of the shoulder and upper arm.

Interscalene nerve block is performed between the anterior and middle scalene muscles in the inter-scalene groove at the level of C6, where the brachial plexus emerges. It provides an adequate block of the superior and middle trunks of the brachial plexus. The ulnar nerve (C8, T1) from the inferior trunk may be missed. Hence, this block is not used for procedures of the forearm and hand.

The most common complication of inter-scalene block seen in 100% of patients is diaphragmatic hemiparesis due to ipsilateral phrenic nerve blockade. This can result in dyspnea, hypoxia, and hypercapnia, especially if the patient has compromised lung function or preexisting contralateral phrenic nerve paralysis.

Other complications of inter-scalene block are:

  • Horners syndrome – ptosis, myosis, anhydrosis. Due to the involvement of the sympathetic nerves in the cervicothoracic ganglion. (loss of ciliospinal reflex)
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
  • Vagus nerve involvement
  • Pneumothorax (stratosphere sign on ultrasound of the chest)
  • Bezold Jarisch reflex (hypotension, bradycardia and coronary vasodilation)
  • Accidental vertebral artery injection (immediate seizure is seen)
  • Accidental spinal or epidural injection

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman presented to the emergency room within two hours of sudden onset of weakness of the right side. On examination, she had global aphasia, right facial droop, and right hemiplegia. CT angiography showed a left middle cerebral artery occlusion. Which of the following is the next best management?

MCA- Middle cerebral artery
questions.solution:
The given features of hemiparesis and facial drooping with aphasia are suggestive of a stroke. CT angiography confirms the diagnosis. The next best step of management is thrombolysis in this case.

Thrombolysis refers to the dissolution of the intravascular clots to prevent ischemic damage and to improve blood flow. Intravenous alteplase has been the mainstay of thrombolysis in acute ischemic stroke. 

Indications for thrombolysis in acute ischemic stroke:

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • The onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <4.5 hours
  • CT scan showing no hemorrhage or edema of >1/3 of MCA territory 
  • Age of the patient >18 years

Contraindications for thrombolysis in acute ischemic stroke:

  • Sustained blood pressure >185/110 mmHg despite treatment 
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in the preceding 14 days
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in the preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

However, mechanical thrombectomy is beneficial as well for acute ischemic stroke due to a proximal large artery occlusion in the anterior circulation or in patients who are ineligible for thrombolysis.

Management of stroke:

Non-contrast CT is the imaging modality of choice in patients with acute stroke. It can identify extra parenchymal hemorrhages, subarachnoid hemorrhages, neoplasms, abscesses, and other conditions that can mimic stroke. However, in the case of ischemic stroke, the CT may appear normal for the first few hours and the infarct may not appear until 24-48 hours. 

Imaging modalities that can be useful in the early identification of stroke are diffusion-weighted imaging, fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR), and MR perfusion studies using gadolinium contrast.

Treatment of acute ischemic stroke:

Initial treatment: Check for the patient's pulse rate, blood pressure, temperature, and glucose levels. Treat hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, or fever if present. Maintain the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation.

Blood pressure should be reduced acutely if :

  • Blood pressure > 220/120 mmHg
  • There is malignant hypertension
  • There is concomitant myocardial ischemia
  • Blood pressure is > 185/110 mmHg and the patient is being planned for intravenous thrombolysis.

Serum glucose should be maintained between 180mg/dL and 60mg/dL.

Ischemia can result in edema which peaks on the second or third day and can lead to a mass effect for around 10 days. Therefore, intravenous mannitol should be started and water restriction should be advised for the patients.

Specific measures:

Intravenous thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA), alteplase should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period (within 4.5 hours of symptom onset).

Endovascular mechanical thrombectomy is done in patients who do not respond to thrombolytic therapy or in whom thrombolysis is contraindicated.

Oral aspirin with an initial dose of 325 mg should be started within 24-48 hours of acute ischemic stroke. It is also continued as an adjunct therapy after intravenous thrombolysis.

Routine use of heparin and other oral anticoagulants is not recommended in patients with ischemic stroke because they can increase the risk of brain and systemic hemorrhage. They can be used if the patient is bedridden, in order to prevent deep vein thrombosis. (Option B)

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: A elderly male patient complains of chest pain at rest. He previously experienced it on exertion. ECG shows ST depression, with no elevation of cardiac biomarkers, what is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is unstable angina based on the clinical features given. Unstable angina is a subtype of acute coronary syndrome (ACS).

ACS includes:

1. Non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary syndrome (NSTE-ACS)

  • Unstable angina
  • Non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI)

2. ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI)

The former, which includes unstable angina arises due to an imbalance in the myocardial oxygen supply-demand ratio. They present with characteristic features such as chest pain at rest, of recent onset, and lasting for more than ten minutes. It usually lasts longer or is more severe than previous episodes. (crescendo pattern). The pain is usually retrosternal and might radiate to the left arm, shoulder, or jaw. 

ECG may show new ST-segment depression in one-third of the patients. It can be transient or may last for several days in NSTEMI. In unstable angina, there is no elevation of cardiac biomarkers, namely cardiac troponin I or cardiac troponin T. In other words, there is no evidence of myocyte necrosis.

Stable angina is marked by ischemic episodes which present as chest pain, precipitated by exertion and relieved with rest. 

Other options:

Option A: Non-ST elevation myocardial infarction, a component of ACS, presents with similar symptoms. In contrast to unstable angina, there are elevated levels of cardiac biomarkers.

Option B: ST-elevation myocardial infarction, occurs due to occlusion of a coronary artery by thrombus. Usually, these vessels are already affected by atherosclerosis. The chest pain may last for more than 30 minutes, associated with marked diaphoresis. The ECG initially shows ST-segment elevation, and usually develops Q waves later on. There is an elevation of cardiac biomarkers. 

Option C: Left heart failure, which arises due to pulmonary edema, presents with shortness of breath. Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) and N-terminal pro-BNP are biomarkers that are usually elevated. There are no specific ECG changes. Any abnormality can rather point to the underlying cardiac condition.

questions.text: During your first day of junior residency, you notice a senior resident performing the following maneuver to remove the placenta from the hard and contracted uterus. This method of placental separation is known as
questions.solution:
The given image shows Brandt Andrew's method of placental separation.

Brandt Andrew's method is a maneuver of expressing the placenta from the uterus in the third stage of labor. 

Here, the palmar surface of the left hand is placed on the mother's abdomen approximately at the junction of the upper and lower uterine segment (above the symphysis pubis) and the umbilical cord is grasped with other hand. While the hand on the abdomen is pressed backward and slightly upward, the other applies gentle traction on the cord in downward and backward direction holding the clamp until the placenta comes outside the introitus.

The procedure is used only when the uterus is hard and contracted.

 

Other mechanisms by which placental separation may occur include

Schultze's method
(image A)		 Mathews- Duncan's method
(image B)
Separation begins from the center of the placenta to the periphery. Separation begins from the periphery to the center.
Blood does not escape externally, as the blood pours into the membrane sac. Blood escapes from the vagina as the blood collects between the membranes and the uterine wall.

 

 

Ritgen’s maneuver is done for assisted delivery of the head by extension, exerting an upward pressure to the chin by right hand placed over the anococcygeal raphe.

questions.text: A 3-year-old baby was examined in a village camp. The child had a poor appetite and visible peripheral edema. The hair was sparse and easily pluckable. The skin showed peeling as depicted below.  What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is kwashiorkor. The above clinical vignette and the image showing flaky paint dermatosis are seen characteristically in kwashiorkor.

Kwashiorkor results due to severe protein and essential amino acid deprivation along with adequate calorie intake. It is particularly seen in children at the time of weaning, to a diet consisting majorly of corn, rice, or beans. 

The clinical features include a classic cutaneous finding of diffuse reddish-brown scaling dermatosis that has been likened to cracked skin, peeling paint, enamel paint, flaky paint, or crazy paving. This is due to the typical scaling and irregular fissuring. Nails are thin and soft. Hairs are thin and sparse and display a flag sign consisting of alternative light and dark bands of hair. The consistent feature is the peripheral edema due to the associated hypoproteinaemia. Edema of the face results in moon facies. Abdominal distention (pot belly) is a feature and is due to hepatomegaly from increased fatty deposition due to a lack of available apolipoproteins.

Other options:

Option A: Marasmus results due to global macro-nutrient deficiency, which leads to growth retardation with <60% of ideal body weight. Loss of subcutaneous tissue, growth stunting, dyspigmentation, and desquamative changes are seen in these patients. Marasmus patients do not demonstrate hypoproteinaemia or edema. There is distension of the abdomen due to hypotonia of the abdominal musculature. These patients typically have wrinkled, loose, and dry skin. The hair and nails often grow slowly and may show brittleness. The hair falls out easily and often shows features of alopecia.

Below is the image of a child with marasmus.

Option B: Pellagra results from a deficiency of niacin (vitamin B3). It is characterized by the classic presentation of dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Casal's necklace is a lesion seen around the neck, which is a characteristic feature seen in pellagra.

Below is the image showing Casal's necklace.

Option C: Vitamin A deficiency can result in phrynoderma that is characterized by keratotic follicular papules along the anterolateral thighs and posterolateral arms. It is seen in the deficiency of vitamin B complex, C, E, and essential fatty acids as well.

Below is the image showing phrynoderma.

questions.text: An 81-year-old lady presented with the following raised lesion which has gotten itchy. It is scaly but does not produce bleeding on itching. A short course of steroids is given but no improvement is seen. Biopsy revealed full-thickness epidermal dysplasia with loss of epithelial polarity. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and biopsy findings suggest a likely diagnosis of Bowen's disease

Bowen’s disease is an intraepidermal squamous cell carcinoma. It is characterized by a persistent, solitary,  non‐elevated, red, scaly, or crusted plaque with a small potential for invasive malignancy.

It usually grows progressively but sometimes undergoes spontaneous partial resolution. It is commonly seen in patients more than 60 years of age and predominantly seen in women. Human Papilloma Virus 16 infection is associated with it.

It can occur anywhere, but it occurs more in the head and neck region.  Histologically, it is characterized by full-thickness epidermal dysplasia with loss of polarity.

Initially, patients present with a small, red, and slightly scaly area, which gradually enlarges in an irregular fashion. The margins of the lesions are slightly raised with the surface is usually flat. Bowen disease on perianal skin carries a higher risk of invasion and recurrence. Management includes cryotherapy, curettage, topical 5% 5-fluorouracil, 5% imiquimod cream. 

Other options:

Option A- Plaque psoriasis is the most common clinical type of psoriasis. Psoriatic plaques are symmetrical, well defined, and erythematous distributed over the elbow, knees, and lower back. On removal of the slivery-white scales, it shows pinpoint bleeding spots called the Auspitz sign. Histology shows parakeratosis, spongiform pustules, microabscesses with the neutrophil collection, and tortuous dilated papillary capillaries.

Option B- Discoid dermatitis has large multiple plaques and mainly presents with pruritus. Histology shows parakeratosis, intracellular edema, eosinophils, and exocytosis of lymphocytes. Most of the cases show improvement with corticosteroids. 

Option D- Malignant melanoma is the malignant transformation of melanocytes that are derived from neural crest cells. it is commonly found in patients younger than 55 years. The characteristics of melanoma are:

  • Asymmetry
  • Border irregularity
  • Color variations, especially red, white, and blue tones in a brown or black lesion
  • Diameter greater than 6 mm
  • Evolution

Histopathology shows individual melanoma cells which are larger than normal melanocytes. They have large nuclei with irregular contours, chromatin is characteristically clumped at the periphery of the nuclear membrane with prominent red eosinophilic nucleoli.

questions.text: A patient was found to have spontaneous and continuous writhing movements at the neck. A lesion in which of the following structure is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
A lesion in the globus pallidus is most likely responsible for the given condition.

Lesions in the globus pallidus frequently lead to spontaneous and often continuous writhing movements of a hand, an arm, the neck, or the face. These movements are called athetosis.

Other options:

Option B: Lesions in the subthalamus often leads to sudden flailing movements of an entire limb, a condition called hemiballismus.

Option C: Lesions in the putamen lead to flicking movements in the hands, face, and other parts of the body, called chorea.

Option D: Lesions of the substantia nigra lead to Parkinson’s disease, characterised by rigidity, akinesia, and tremors.
