questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding primary myelofibrosis.

choices.text: Common in individuals less than 30 years of age
White blood cell count is elevated in the initial phase
Advanced disease is characterised by diffuse fibrosis of bone marrow and splenomegaly
Peripheral smear shows the presence of leukoerythroblastosis and dacryocytes

questions.solution:
The false statement regarding primary myelofibrosis is that it occurs in individuals less than 30 years of age.

Myelofibrosis is characterized by abnormal production of red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets, in association with marrow fibrosis (scarring) and extramedullary hematopoiesis. It can present de novo as primary myelofibrosis (PMF), a chronic progressive myeloproliferative disorder or due to an underlying disorder such as leukemia or hyperparathyroidism, in which case it is called secondary or reactive myelofibrosis.

Primary myelofibrosis occurs in individuals over 60 years of age. JAK2, CALR, and MPL mutations are seen in the majority of the cases. Patients present with vague, constitutional symptoms such as weight loss, night sweats, low-grade fever, cachexia, fatigue, and pruritus. There might be a history of exposure to industrial solvents or radiation. Later in the disease, there may be a sensation of fullness in the upper left quadrant due to splenomegaly. Hyperuricemia and secondary gout may also occur.

Peripheral smear shows the presence of normochromic normocytic anemia and leukoerythroblastosis. There is a release of nucleated erythroid and early granulocyte progenitors from the bone marrow and the presence of dacryocytes, which are tear-drop-shaped red cells. 

Early in the disease, the WBC count is markedly elevated up to 100,000 cells/mm3 but later the count usually returns to normal or is reduced, even.

The chief pathologic feature is the extensive deposition of collagen in the marrow by fibroblasts. The fibrosis of bone marrow is thought to be caused by the inappropriate release of platelet-derived growth factor and TGF-β. Early in the disease, the marrow is hypercellular with an increase in the maturation of cells of all lineages but with disease progression and collagen deposition, the bone marrow becomes hypocellular and diffusely fibrotic. Eventually, the fibrotic marrow space is converted to bone, which is called osteosclerosis.

Due to the obliteration of marrow space by fibrotic changes, there is extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis mainly in the spleen, giving rise to massive splenomegaly. Subcapsular infarcts are common and there may be moderate enlargement of the liver. There is no significant lymphadenopathy, though hematopoiesis may occur even in the lymph nodes.

The complications include recurrent infections, thrombotic episodes, platelet anomalies leading to bleeding diathesis, and sometimes, transformation into acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

Janus kinase inhibitors like ruxolitinib and fedratinib have been approved for management. Hematopoietic stem cell (HSC) transplantation may also be considered depending on factors like the patients' age and fitness for the procedure.

Related Pearl: 2016 Criteria for Primary Myelofibrosis

WHO overt PMF criteria

Major criteria

Presence of megakaryocytic proliferation and atypia, accompanied by either reticulin and/or collagen fibrosis grades 2 or 3

Not meeting WHO criteria for ET, PV, BCR-ABL1+ CML, myelodysplastic syndromes, or other myeloid neoplasms

Presence of JAK2, CALR, or MPL mutation or in the absence of these mutations, presence of another clonal marker,<† or absence of reactive myelofibrosis

Minor criteria

Presence of at least 1 of the following, confirmed in 2 consecutive determinations:

Anemia not attributed to a comorbid condition

Leukocytosis ≥11 × 10 9/L

Palpable splenomegaly

LDH increased to more than the upper normal limit of the institutional reference range

Leukoerythroblastosis

ET: Essential thrombocythemia 

PV: Polycythemia vera

CML: Chronic myeloid leukemia

LDH: Lactate dehydrogenase

questions.text: A pregnant woman diagnosed with Cushing's syndrome does not want surgery and requests medical treatment. Which of the following drugs can be recommended?
questions.solution:
Metyrapone can be recommended as it is approved in the treatment of pregnant women with Cushing's syndrome. It inhibits the synthesis of cortisol by inhibiting steroid 11 β-hydroxylase reversibly. 

Cushing’s syndrome (CS) is a manifestation of symptoms that are precipitated by excessive cortisol production. Transsphenoidal surgery, radiation, and pharmacotherapy constitute the standard treatment for tumor-related causes of CS (e.g. pituitary adenoma).

The three main pharmacological approaches are:

  • Cortisol synthesis inhibitors: Ketoconazole, metyrapone, mitotane, etomidate, aminoglutethimide
  • ACTH secretion inhibitors: Cyproheptadine, pasireotide, octreotide, cabergoline
  • Glucocorticoid receptor antagonist: Mifepristone

Note: Metyrapone is also used to test the hypothalamic-pituitary feedback pathway in the diagnosis of Cushing syndrome.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with benign prostatic hypertrophy underwent TURP.  An hour later, he was found to have an altered sensorium and had several bouts of vomiting. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The most probable cause for the above-mentioned symptoms is water intoxication also known as transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP) syndrome. 

Absorption of water into the circulation at the time of transurethral urethral resection can lead to :

  • Hyponatremia, which may manifest as confusion, nausea, and vomiting
  • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Hemolysis 

It is managed by fluid restriction.

The use of isotonic glycine for irrigation during resection reduces the incidence of water intoxication.

questions.text: You are planning to conduct a randomized control trial to study the effect of an emollient on eczema. You consider two groups, one of which will receive a placebo. You decide to follow a blinding trial to prevent bias. Which among the following is the most frequent blinding method that is used to conduct such trials?
questions.solution:
Double-blinding is the most frequently used blinding method when blinded trials are conducted, even though triple blinding should be ideally used.

Double blinding trials are where neither the group members nor the observers are aware of the group allocation.

Related Pearl: Blinding in Epidemiology

  • Blinding is done in epidemiology to reduce the possibility of bias.
  • Types:
    • In single blind trials, only the participants or group members are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In double blind trials, both the group members and the observers are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In triple blind trials, the group members, the observers and the analyzers are unaware of the group allocation.
  • The most commonly used type of blinding is double blinding.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

Type of Bias Definition Methods to reduce it
Observer bias Differential ability to observe. A subjective bias.  
Interviewer's bias Interviewer asking leading questions to the subjects. Or interviewing cases thoroughly than the controls.  Double blinding
Memory/ Recall bias Differential ability of cases and controls to recall a certain detail. An objective bias. Decrease time from exposure to follow-up
Surveillance bias Active surveillance leads to an increased chance of identifying the event.  
Reporting/ notification bias Diseases associated with stigma are reported less.  
Berkesonian bias Hospital-based case-control studies. Occurs due to differential hospital admission rates.

Randomization or Matching 
Selection bias A sampling bias. Non-random allocation of subjects that do not represent the population Randomization or Matching
Hawthorne bias Change in attitude/ actions of the subjects under observation Use placebo group
Confounding bias Factors related to both exposure and outcome distort the effect of exposure on outcome Matching, cross-over studies, randomization, or stratification
Attrition bias Participants lost to follow-up have a different prognosis than those who complete the study. Randomization
Pygmalion bias Researcher's high expectations in the efficacy of the treatment change the outcome of that treatment. Blinding
Neyman's/ Prevalence-Incidence bias  Occurs due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. Very sick patients are automatically excluded because of their early death.  

Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias example: a case-control study is carried out to study the relationship between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The cases are interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show a lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Ecological fallacy results when characteristics of the group are assigned inappropriately to individuals.

Related Pearl: Randomized Controlled Trials

Randomized controlled trials are a type of experimental studies.

Types

  • Clinical trials
  • Preventive trials
  • Risk factor trials
  • Cessation experiments
  • Trial of etiological agents
  • Evaluation of health services

General Design of an RCT

Steps of an RCT

  • Drawing up a protocol
  • Selecting reference and experimental population
  • Randomization
  • Manipulation or intervention
  • Follow-up
  • Assessment of outcome.

questions.text: The insecticide shown below is used to eliminate the larval form of
questions.solution:
The above image shows Paris green which is a commonly used larvicide against Anopheles larvae. Paris green mainly kills larvae who are surface feeders which include Anopheles larvae.

Paris green (Copper acetoarsenite) is an insecticide, which is a green powder that has 50% arsenious oxide. It is a stomach poison and to be effective, it must be ingested by the larvae. 

Other commonly used larvicides are:

  • Mineral oils - diesel oil, kerosene, fractions of crude oils, mosquito larvicidal oil
  • Synthetic insecticides - Fenthion, Chlorpyrifos, and Abate

Larvicides that are not recommended include organochlorine compounds like DDT and HCH. This is because they have a long residual effect, and contaminate water. Vector mosquitoes may also develop resistance to these compounds.

The larvae of Anopheles lie parallel to the surface of the water. They don't have a siphon tube. In their larval stage, they are surface feeders. In contrast, Culicine larvae like Aedes, Culex, Mansonia have a siphon tube that helps them to suspend in water with their head downwards.

The image below shows Laraval forms of different mosquitoes.

Related Pearl: Mosquito Control Measures

  • Anti-larval measures
    • Environmental control
      • This is done by source reduction by eliminating breeding places through appropriate methods for the different species.
      • Intermittent irrigation is also a method of environmental control
    • Chemical control
      • Mineral oils: Oldest known larvicidal method. Oils that are used are diesel oil, kerosene, crude oil fractions. Disadvantage is that it kills fish.
      • Paris green: Copper acetoarsenite is an emerald green, micro-crystalline powder and is insoluble in water. It is a stomach poison to larvae. It is not harmful to man or animals. Very effective against Anopheles as they are surface feeders.
      • Synthetic insecticides: Organo-phosphorous compounds like fenthion, chlorpyrifos and abate are larvicidal. Abate is least toxic.
    • Biological control
      • The fish species Gambusia affinis and Lebister reticulatus (Barbados millions) feed on mosquito larvae.
      • These are used in conjunction with other methods.
  • Anti-adult measures
    • Residual sprays
      • Adult mosquitoes can be controlled by spraying with residual insecticides like DDT, Malathion, propoxur and gamma-HCH (lindane)
      • Resistance to DDT has been shown by mosquitoes
    • Space sprays
      • Space sprays are those in which insecticides are sprayed into the atmosphere in the form of a mist or fog.
      • Pyrethrum is a contact, nerve poison and is the most common insecticide used as a space spray. Its active principle is pyrethrin.
      • Ultra-low volume space spraying (ULV) is done with Malathion and fenitrothion.
    • Genetic control by sterile male technique, cytoplasmic incompatibility, sex distortion, etc.
  • Protection against bites
    • Usage of mosquito nets, building screens and repellants like diethyltoluamide (deet), indalone, dimethylphthalate, dimethyl carbate, etc.

Related Pearl: Insecticides

Contact poisons

  • Natural: Pyrethrum, rotenone, derris, nicotine, mineral oils
  • Synthetic:
    • Organo-chlorine compounds: DDT, methoxychlor, HCH, lindane, chlordane, heptachlor, dieldrin, aldrin, toxaphene, kepone, mirex.
    • Repellants: Benzyl benzoate, indalone, meta-diethyltoluamide, dimethyl phthalate, ethyl hexanediol.
    • Organo-phosphorus compounds: Chlorthion (aryl), diazinon (aryl), demethoate, malathion (alkyl), fenthion, parathion (aryl), trichlorfon (alkyl), runnel, abale, naled, chlorpyrifos, fenitrothion, dicapthon.
    • Carbamates: Carbaryl, dimetilan, propoxur, pyrolan.
    • Synthetic pyrethroids: Prothrin, resmethrin, bioresmethrin, permethrin, proparthin, tetramethrin
  • Stomach poisons: Paris green, sodium fluoride.
  • Fumigants: Hydrogen cyanide, methyl bromide, sulphur dioxide, carbon disulphide.
Specific Insecticides Comments
DDT (Dichloro-diphenyl-thrichloroethane) Insecticidal properties were discovered by Swiss scientist, Paul Muller. Most widely used insecticide. Attacks nerves of insects but doesn’t cause immediate death. White amorphous powder. Contains 70 – 80% of para-para isomers, which is the most active fraction of DDT. questions.text:
Identify the true statement regarding the regulation of the rate-limiting enzyme in de novo purine synthesis.

ATP - Adenosine triphosphate

GMP - Guanosine monophosphate
questions.solution:
The rate-limiting enzyme in de novo purine synthesis is phosphoribosylpyrophosphate (PRPP) glutamyl amidotransferase; it is inhibited by GMP which is one of the end products of the pathway & activated by the concentration of glutamine.

De novo purine synthesis involves the synthesis of purines from amphibolic intermediates. The first step of this reaction involves the transfer of two phosphoryl groups from ATP to ribose-5-phosphate form 5-phosphoribosyl-1-pyrophosphate (PRPP), catalyzed by the enzyme PRPP synthase. PRPP is then converted to 5-phosphoribosylamine by the enzyme PRPP glutamyl amidotransferase, in the presence of glutamine and H2O; this undergoes a series of changes to form inosine monophosphate (IMP).

The IMP formed can then be used for the synthesis of both AMP and GMP by different pathways. Subsequently, one ATP is used for the conversion of AMP to ADP and GMP to GDP; this is followed by the synthesis of GTP from GDP using another phosphoryl group from ATP, while ADP can be converted to ATP by oxidative phosphorylation.

The rate of the reaction is determined by the intracellular concentration of PRPP, which in turn depends on the rate of PRPP synthesis and utilization. The rate of PRPP synthesis depends on the availability of ribose-5-phosphate and on the activity of PRPP synthase, an enzyme whose activity is feedback inhibited by AMP, ADP, GMP, and GDP. Additionally, the enzyme PRPP glutamyl amidotransferase is inhibited by AMP and GMP, the end products of the pathway.

The other compounds that block purine biosynthesis include azaserine, 6-mercaptopurine, methotrexate and mycophenolic acid.

questions.text: Match the gross structure with its histology.
questions.solution:
The given histological image is of transitional epithelium with a star-shaped appearance, which is a feature of the ureter. In the gross image provided, the structure labelled as 1 is the ureter, specifically the left ureter. 

The other structures marked are:

2: Inferior mesenteric artery

3: Descending colon 

4: Femoral cutaneous nerve 

Histology of ureter:

It has 3 layers- the innermost mucous membrane, the middle smooth muscle layer and the outer connective tissue layer.

The innermost mucous membrane is made of transitional epithelium. It is 4-5 cell layers thick with an underlying lamina propria. The mucosa is thrown into longitudinal folds which gives the lumen a star-shaped appearance. These folds vanish when the ureter is distended. 

The middle smooth muscle layer consists of an upper 2/3rd of inner longitudinal and outer circular fibres and a lower 1/3rd- of extra outer longitudinal muscle layer. The muscle coat has 2 layers in the upper 2/3rd and 3 layers in the lower 1/3rd, which may not be distinctly differentiated from each other. 

The outer connective tissue layer, also called the tunica adventitia contains blood vessels, nerves, lymphatics and fat cells. 

Ureters are narrow muscular tubes that begin from the renal pelvis and extend up to the urinary bladder. They are about 25cm long, and 3mm thick with 5 constrictions along their length. They are constricted at the pelvic-ureteric junction, the brim of the lesser pelvis, the crossing of the ureter by ductus deferens or broad ligament of the uterus, during their oblique passage through the bladder wall and at the opening in the lateral angle of the trigone.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl was brought to the psychiatric emergency department after she slashed her wrist in an attempt to commit suicide. Her father reveals that there were multiple such attempts in the past. She has a history of marked fluctuations of mood and unstable relationships in the past. Which of the following non-pharmacological therapy is advised for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of borderline personality disorder. The psychotherapy advised for this patient is dialectical behavioral therapy.

Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice for borderline personality disorder. Dialectical behavior therapy (DBT), transference-focused psychotherapy (TFP), and mentalization-based therapy (MBT) are the various psychotherapies used in the treatment of this condition. There is no consensus as to which particular therapy (viz. DBT, TFP, or MBT) is superior to the others.

A borderline personality disorder is characterized by extraordinarily unstable affect, mood, behavior, object relations, and self-image. According to DSM-5, a diagnosis of borderline personality disorder can be made if at least 5 out of the following are shown by the patient:

  • Panicky efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment
  • Unstable interpersonal relationships
  • Marked and persistently unstable self-image or sense of self
  • Impulsivity in at least two areas of potentially self-damaging like sex, substance abuse, reckless driving, binge eating, etc.
  • Repeated suicidal behavior, gestures, threats, or self-mutilating behavior
  • Instability in affect due to a marked reactivity of mood
  • Prolonged feeling of emptiness
  • Inappropriate, intense anger or difficulty in controlling anger
  • Transient stress-related paranoid ideation

Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice for borderline personality disorder. 

Antipsychotics help to control anger, hostility, and brief psychotic episodes. Antidepressants are used to improve depressive mood which is common in patients with borderline personality disorder.

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors help in the modulation of impulsive behavior and benzodiazepine-like alprazolam helps in improving anxiety and depression. Anticonvulsants like carbamazepine help in improving the global functioning of patients with borderline personality disorder. 

Other options:

Interpersonal psychotherapy is used in the treatment of depression. It focuses on grief over loss, interpersonal disputes, interpersonal skill deficits, and role transitions.

Exposure and response prevention is used in the treatment of OCD.

questions.text: A severely injured person who is a victim of an assault is brought to the hospital. Which among the following statements is false about recording his dying declaration?

choices.text: The doctors role is to ascertain compos mentis
Dying declaration can be recorded only by the magistrate
Dying declaration has to be recorded in patient's words
Suggestions or leading questions are not allowed

questions.solution:
A dying declaration can be recorded by the doctor himself in the presence of two witnesses if he thinks that the victim will not survive till the arrival of the magistrate.

A dying declaration is a statement, verbal or written made by a victim before his or her death, relating to the circumstances leading to death. A medical officer should inform the magistrate to have a dying declaration recorded as soon as the severely injured person is brought to the hospital.

The doctors can record it themselves in the presence of two witnesses if they think that the person will not survive till the arrival of the magistrate. Treatment should not be delayed while recording a dying declaration.

The doctor has to ascertain that the dying person is of sound mind (compos mentis) before recording the statement.

If the person dies or becomes unconscious while recording the dying declaration, the doctor must record the information obtained up to that point. It should be recorded in the patient's own words. No suggestions or leading questions are allowed, and any outsider is not allowed to be present.

After completing the writing, it has to be read back to the patient who has to approve it with a signature or thumb impression. The signature of two witnesses is mandatory.

questions.text: An army recruit presents to you with complaints of pain and swelling in the right foot. He had joined army training 6 months back. An X-ray of his foot is given. Which of the following is the most sensitive and specific investigation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the most sensitive and specific investigation in this patient.

The given clinical scenario and the X-ray showing a fractured neck of the 2nd metatarsal are suggestive of a March fracture. It is a type of stress fracture.

The image below shows the March fracture:

Stress fractures (or fatigue fractures) occur in a normal bone that is subjected to chronic repetitive stress. This initiates a bone remodeling process. When resorption occurs faster than replacement, the bone becomes liable to fracture. Such fractures are typically seen in athletes, dancers, or military personnel who have a strenuous exercise regimen.

Common sites for stress fractures include:

  • Metatarsals: 2nd metatarsal stress fracture is known as a march fracture
  • Calcaneum
  • Navicular
  • The distal shaft of the fibula is known as runner's fracture
  • Tibial shaft
  • Femoral neck, etc.

MRI has the maximum sensitivity and specificity to diagnose stress fractures. It can visualize lower-grade stress injuries before X-ray changes appear. A bone scan is the best investigation when bilateral, multiple sites have stress fractures. 

Most stress fractures are managed using an elastic bandage and avoidance of painful activity until the lesion heals. Stress fracture of the femoral neck should be managed by internal fixation as a prophylactic measure.

Other options:

Option A- Computed tomography (CT) scan can be used to diagnose stress fractures but it has a lower sensitivity when compared to MRI.

Option C- Bone scan is sensitive for metatarsal stress fractures but it is not specific. It is the best investigation in cases of bilateral, multiple stress fractures.

Option D- Radiograph is the initial investigation done in stress fracture but it is difficult to detect the early fracture line in the radiograph

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman complains of a creepy crawling sensation in her legs associated with an irresistible urge to move the legs. It is more at night and prevents her from sleeping. Which of the following drugs is considered as the drug of choice in treating her condition?
questions.solution:
The history is suggestive of restless leg syndrome and gabapentinoids are now considered as the drug of choice in treating this condition. 

Restless leg syndrome is a typical sensory-motor disorder that generally affects the legs during rest periods, especially during sleep. There is an irresistible urge to shake the legs associated with a burning sensation, itching, and cramps of the legs. In idiopathic cases, dopaminergic hypofunction is postulated.

In patients with restless legs syndrome, iron stores are initially repleted, and the aggravating factors are eliminated. If RLS still persists, initial therapy with a gabapentinoid (pregabalin, gabapentin, gabapentin enacarbil) is preferred, rather than a dopamine agonist (pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine). This is due to the high frequency of intermediate and long-term augmentation with dopamine agonists, as well as their risk of impulse control disorders.

FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of restless leg syndrome: 

  • Gabapentin
  • Ropinirole
  • Pramipexole
  • Rotigotine 

A dopamine agonist is used as an alternative in patients with increased risk for side effects from gabapentinoids, such as those with obesity and its complications, a past or present history of moderate to severe depression, a disorder causing gait instability or respiratory failure, and a history of substance use disorder.

Non-pharmacological treatments that can be used in restless leg syndrome are:

  • Avoiding alcohol at bedtime
  • Massaging affected legs
  • Hot baths
  • Applying hot or cold to the affected area
  • Engaging in moderate exercises

Other options:

Option A- Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor that binds to serotonin transporter and inhibits its transport. They are mainly indicated in depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, panic disorder, social phobia, and posttraumatic stress disorder. 

Option B- Clozapine is a second-generation antipsychotic that is an antagonist to 5HT2A and D2 receptors. They are mainly used in refractory schizophrenia and refractory mania. 

Option D- Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant that inhibits serotonin receptor transporter, norepinephrine transporter. They also block H1 histamine, 5HT2, alpha 1 adrenergic, muscarinic 1 receptors. They are indicated in major depression.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient was diagnosed with metastatic colon cancer. He has been started on a multidrug chemotherapy regimen. This regimen consists of all of the following drugs except:
questions.solution:
The FOLFOX regimen is used as first-line treatment for metastatic colon cancer. This regimen consists of all of the drugs mentioned above except filgrastim.

5-Fluorouracil in combination with Leucovorin and Oxaliplatin is used in the management of metastatic colorectal cancers. It is associated with improved survival rates. This is also called the FOLFOX regimen. The addition of irinotecan gives us an extension to this regimen called FOLFIRINOX which has been used in the treatment of colorectal and pancreatic cancers.

Option A: Filgrastim is a recombinant cytokine identical to human granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF). It binds to and activates G-CSF receptors and controls the production and function of neutrophilic granulocyte progenitors, bringing about immunomodulation. It is effective in the treatment of severe neutropenia after autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation as well as high dose cancer chemotherapy.

questions.text:
A 4-year-old girl presented with a history of easy bruising and frequent nosebleeds. There was no history of fever. The platelet count was low and the peripheral smear showed platelets, as marked by the arrows. Platelet function studies show an absence of aggregation to ristocetin but a normal response to adenosine diphosphate (ADP), epinephrine, and collagen. What is the likely diagnosis?

aPTT: Normal
Bleeding time: prolonged
Serum creatinine and urea within normal limits
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Bernard-Soulier syndrome.

Points that favor the diagnosis:

  • History of easy bruising and frequent nosebleeds
  • Low platelet count and giant platelets
  • Prolonged bleeding time
  • Absent aggregation to ristocetin in platelet function studies 

It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to an inherited deficiency of platelet membrane glycoprotein complex Ib-IX. This glycoprotein is a receptor of the von Willebrand factor, which is needed for normal platelet adhesion to the subendothelial extracellular matrix. 

They mostly present with easy bruising, nose bleeds, mucosal bleeding, menorrhagia, and occasionally gastrointestinal bleeding.

Laboratory features:

  • Low platelet count
  • Large platelets on smear
  • Platelet aggregation will not occur in response to ristocetin but have normal aggregation with  ADP, collagen, or epinephrine
  • Platelet membrane glycoprotein abnormality is seen on flow cytometry.

Supportive treatment is only needed. Antiplatelet medications like aspirin should be avoided. Anti-fibrinolytic can be used in mucosal bleeding.

The below image shows giant platelets in peripheral blood smear in Bernard-Soulier syndrome.

Other options:

Option A- Glanzmann thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive platelet disorder that results from a deficiency of the glycoprotein IIb/IIIa complex.

Patients mainly present with petechiae, ecchymosis, excessive bleeding after dental extraction, menorrhagia, gingival bleeding, and epistaxis. 

Laboratory features:

  • Normal platelet count
  • Bleeding time- prolonged
  • Normal platelet morphology on peripheral smear
  • Platelet aggregation responses to ADP, collagen, or epinephrine are low but have normal aggregation with ristocetin
  • Flow cytometry and monoclonal antibodies confirm the diagnosis

Option B-  Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura is due to the deficiency of ADAMTS13, which is the negative regulator of von Willebrand factor (vWF). They are mostly seen in adults less than 40 years of age.

They are classically manifested by a pentad of:

  • Fever
  • Neurological abnormalities
  • Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Renal failure

Option C- von Willebrand disease is a common inherited disorder caused by deficiency or dysfunction of the vWF. Patients will have thrombocytopenia with mild to moderate mucocutaneous hemorrhage.

Laboratory features:

  • Mild thrombocytopenia
  • Slightly enlarged platelets
  • Decreased levels of von Willebrand factor
  • Low levels of ristocetin cofactor
  • Prolonged activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT)and bleeding time

questions.text: A 24-year-old primiparous woman with grade 2 genuine stress incontinence, who did not respond to conservative management was managed surgically by opposing medial fibers of puborectalis muscle in the midline under the bladder neck region to elevate it via vaginal approach. Which of the following operations is being done on this patient?
questions.solution:
Pacey’s repair done for stress urinary incontinence include opposing medial fibers of puborectalis muscle in the midline under the bladder neck region to elevate it.

Genuine stress incontinence occurs when the bladder pressure exceeds urethral pressure during physical stress in the absence of detrusor contraction

Genuine stress incontinence (GSI) can be graded into three different severities:

  • Grade 1 - Incontinence on severe stress, such as coughing, sneezing or jogging
  • Grade 2 - Incontinence on moderate stress such as walking fast or climbing stairs
  • Grade 3 - Incontinence on mild stress, such as on standing

Surgical Repair of Stress Urinary Incontinence includes,

Vaginal Operations: 

  • Kelly’s repair: Anterior colporrhaphy with plication of the bladder neck.
  • Pacey’s repair: Opposing medial fibers of puborectalis muscles in the midline under the bladder neck region to elevate it.

Abdominal Operations:

  • Marshall–Marchetti–Krantz operation: Here bladder neck and the vaginal vault is sutured to the periosteum of the back of the pubic symphysis. Osteitis may follow this operation.
  • Burch colposuspension: Here vaginal suspension is achieved using the iliopectineal ligaments.

Combined abdominal and vaginal operations: Pereyra operation

Conservative treatment should be the first line of treatment, especially in younger women. It can also be advised for elderly and frail women, who are unfit for surgery, and during the initial 6 months after the delivery. It includes, 

  • Physiotherapy and drugs
  • Intraurethral and vaginal devices 
  • Electric stimulation 
  • Artificial urinary sphincter 
  • Weight loss 
  • Reduce caffeine intake and stop smoking 
  • Bladder training and timed voiding

questions.text: An elderly male patient who was on the central venous line for the last 7 days was given ceftazidime and amikacin. After 7 days of antibiotics, he develops a spike of fever and his blood culture is positive for non-hemolytic gram-positive cocci, which are catalase-negative and can grow in 6.5% NaCl. Tiny magenta pink colonies were seen on MacConkey medium. Following this, vancomycin was started but the culture remained positive for the same organism even after 2 weeks of therapy.  Identify this organism.
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) infection. Catalase-negative and Gram-positive cocci suggest streptococcaceae family. Positive culture after 2 weeks of vancomycin therapy suggests resistance to vancomycin.

Enterococcus species (S.faecalis and other enterococci) show growth in 6.5% NaCl and can cause urinary tract infections, endocarditis, and suppurative infections.

They belong to Lancefield group D and can grow in the presence of 40% bile, 6.5% sodium chloride, at a pH of 9.6, and in 0.1% methylene blue milk.

  • they produce tiny magenta pink colonies on MacConkey medium.
  • They are relatively heat-resistant, surviving at 60°C for 30 minutes
  • They typically appear as pairs of oval cocci
  • They are usually non-hemolytic, though some strains may show alpha or beta hemolysis

The other streptococci are usually beta or alpha-hemolytic, do not grow on MacConkey medium, and do not withstand high temperatures.

Note: Vancomycin is the drug of choice for aminoglycoside resistance. Vancomycin resistance can also occur due to the presence of resistance genes Van A, B, C, D and E.

Other options:

Streptococcus agalactiae and Streptococcus pyogenes show beta-hemolysis on blood agar and they usually do not show any growth on MacConkey medium.

Viridans streptococci are usually mouth commensals and are sensitive to vancomycin. These strains  typically produce alpha-hemolysis on blood agar.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever,  vomiting, and watery diarrhea. He gives a history of having consumed shellfish and raw seafood a day before, at a party. The causative agent showed hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar. Which of the following organisms is responsible for his presenting features?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with culture findings of hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar, is suggestive of infection with Vibrio parahaemolyticus.

V. parahaemolyticus causes food poisoning due to the consumption of contaminated seafood, after an incubation period of 12–24 hours. The common sources of infection are raw seafood like molluscs and crustaceans.

Clinically, patients present with nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, fever, and watery or bloody diarrhea. Fecal leukocytes are often seen in stool samples.

Enteritis subsides spontaneously in 1–3 days with no specific treatment. Adequate hydration and electrolyte balance should be restored.

V. parahaemolyticus is a capsulated bacterium. It shows bipolar staining and has a tendency to pleomorphism. It is characterized by peritrichous flagella on solid media and monotrichous on liquid media and gives a positive string test.

V. parahaemolyticus grows well on blood agar, where it is identified by its oxidase-positive growth. On thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose (TCBS) agar, it produces green colonies, as shown in the image below.

Pathogenic strains of V. parahemolyticus are hemolytic on Wagatsuma agar, while non-pathogenic strains are non-hemolytic. This is called the Kanagawa phenomenon and is due to a heat-stable hemolysin.

questions.text: The government uses the following sign at public places in order to directly or indirectly alter human behavior. This is an example of which of the following approaches towards health education?
questions.solution:
The "No smoking" sign is an example of a regulatory approach.

A regulatory approach with respect to health education is defined as a government intervention, which is designed to alter human behavior either directly or indirectly. Regulations may take many forms, from prohibition to imprisonment.

Examples of this approach include The Child Marriage Restraint Act and the use of compulsory seatbelts. However, there are many failures to this approach, as some of these approaches involve areas related to personal choices as well like diet, exercise, smoking, etc

The four approaches to health education:

  • Regulatory approach
  • Service approach
  • Health education approach
  • Primary health care approach

The service approach (option B) is a government intervention aimed at providing all the health services needed by the people at their doorstep so the people would use them to improve their own health. An example of this approach is the free-of-cost latrines provided by the government. But many people in the rural areas did not make use of this because its need was not felt.

The health education approach (option A) is an intervention to provide necessary behavioral changes in people to make their own choice for a healthy life through health education. Examples of this approach are cessation of smoking, use of safe water supply, fertility control through health education. 

The primary health care approach (option D) is an intervention with active involvement from the people in the planning and delivery of health services based on the principle of primary health care. This actually deals with community involvement and intersectoral coordination.

questions.text: You were posted for screening of deafness in school children under your primary health center. Which type of screening is done in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The type of screening done for deafness in school children is prescriptive screening. 

Prescriptive screening is done for case detection. People are examined primarily for their own benefit. It may lead to the early identification of an unrecognized disease. Hence, appropriate treatment can be initiated immediately to decline the disease progression.

Screening is initiated by medical and public health personnel and is not requested by a patient. Examples of prescriptive screening are:

  • Screening of hemolytic disease in newborns
  • Screening of infants for phenylketonuria
  • Screening of bacteriuria in pregnancy
  • Screening of school children for visual and auditory defects

Other options:

Option A - Prospective screening is done for disease control. People are screened for the benefit of others. It may lead to an early diagnosis and permit more effective treatment. It also reduces the spread of infectious diseases in the community. Hence, reduces mortality associated with the disease. Examples of prospective screening are:

  • Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and syphilis to protect the citizens
  • Screening for streptococcal infection to prevent rheumatic fever
  • Screening of sex workers for HIV to prevent transmission of HIV to others
  • Screening of COVID infection among the international passengers at the airport

Option B - Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination, to a large population at one time. It is not cost-effective and has shown no benefit in reducing the morbidity and mortality of the population.

Option D - Selective screening is done in high-risk groups. It is one of the most effective screening tests. Example: Screening for diabetes in the other members of a family for a detected diabetes case since these diseases get aggregated in families.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.

  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

Related Pearl: Cut-off points in diagnostic tests

  • Highly sensitive test, when negative, rules out a disease. (Screening test)
  • Highly specific test, when positive, rules in a disease. (Confirmatory test)

Sensitivity (True-positive rate): High sensitivity indicates low false-negative rate.

Specificity (True-negative rate): High specificity indicates low false-positive rate.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient was diagnosed to be suffering from systemic mycoses infection. Culture from the lesion at 37°C shows the appearance of the causative organism as given in the below image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the characteristic 'pilot wheel appearance' on culture shown by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. It causes South American blastomycosis/paracoccidioidomycosis.

Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It causes paracoccidioidomycosis, a chronic granulomatous disease affecting the lungs, skin, mucosa, and lymph nodes. 

The spores are inhaled which results in a primary pulmonary infection. This is followed by a hematogenous spread to the mucosa of the nose, mouth, gastrointestinal tract, skin, and lymphatics. This leads to ulcerative granulomas of the buccal and nasal mucosa.

On culture at 37 °C, large oval cells with multiple buds encircling the mother cell are seen This is known as Mariner’s or pilot’s wheel appearance. On culture at 25-30°C, it is found in the mycelial phase.

Other options:

Option A: Darling's disease (Histoplasmosis) is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum. 

Option B: North American blastomycosis (Blastomycosis) is caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis.

Option D: Valley Fever (Coccidioidomycosis) is caused by Coccidioides immitis

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 35 weeks of gestation with Rh-negative pregnancy undergoes the following analysis. The amniotic fluid bilirubin levels plotted fall in zone 3. Which of the following indicates the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Pregnancy can be continued till term

questions.solution:
The graph shown in the above image is Liley's chart. As the amniotic fluid bilirubin levels fall in zone 3, it indicates that the fetus is severely affected and requires immediate delivery.

Liley's chart helps in the estimation of hemolysis severity and indirect assessment of anemia. Amnionic fluid bilirubin is measured by a spectrophotometer and is demonstrable as a change in optical density absorbance at 450 nm—ΔOD450.

The chart is divided into 3 zones: 

Liley’s zone I (low zone): Rh-negative fetus or fetus is unlikely to be affected and the pregnancy can be continued till term.

Liley’s zone II (mid zone): Indicates fetal anemia.

  • Repeat amniocentesis after 2 weeks → value upward→ cordocentesis→ hematocrit <30%→ intrauterine transfusion to raise hematocrit 40–45%.
  • Preterm delivery may be needed after 34 weeks.

Liley’s zone III (high zone): Indicates severely affected fetus and death is imminent.

  • If Pregnancy >34 weeks → delivery.
  • If Pregnancy <34 weeks → cordocentesis → hematocrit < 30% → intrauterine transfusion to raise hematocrit 40–45%.
  • Preterm delivery may be needed after 34 weeks

questions.text: A 22-year-old mother wants to get her 2-day-old newborn to be screened for hypothyroidism as she had read on the internet that it is a common cause of preventable mental retardation. Which of the following strategies is most commonly followed for the screening process?

choices.text: A fresh blood sample and screen first for TSH levels
A fresh blood sample and screen first for T4 levels
A dried blood sample and screen first for TSH levels
A dried blood sample and screen first for T4 levels

questions.solution:
The most commonly followed strategy for newborn screening of congenital hypothyroidism is using a dried blood sample and screening it first for TSH.

Congenital hypothyroidism is the most common preventable cause of mental retardation. Screening of children for congenital hypothyroidism is very important, as early diagnosis and treatment can help in normal intellectual development. Children diagnosed beyond the neonatal period have a poor outcome.

Screening is usually done between day 2 - day 4 postnatally using dried blood samples for this. The most commonly used strategy is screening for TSH first as they have higher sensitivity compared to the T4-based approach. Although the TSH-based approach is better, it doesn't identify central hypothyroidism, which can be identified by the T4-first approach. But, the T4-based approach misses out on the cases of compensated hypothyroidism.

The incidence of congenital hypothyroidism is 4 times higher in India compared to western countries. Thyroid dysgenesis has emerged as the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in India.

Clinical features of hypothyroidism:

Congenital Acquired
Open posterior fontanel Growth retardation
Umbilical hernia Delayed skeletal maturation
Characteristic edematous facies Delayed dental development
Constipation Delayed puberty
Pallor Myopathy and pseudohypertrophy
Hypothermia Enlarged sella
Large tongue Pseudotumor cerebri
Rough dry skin  
Hypotonia  
Large abdomen  

Management is by thyroid replacement soon after the diagnosis. Thyroxine of dose 10-15 μg/kg/day should be started and adjusted to achieve the normal free T4 range. TSH may be elevated up to 2 years of age with a reset of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis.

questions.text: The electrocardiograph (ECG) of a patient with core body temperature of 85 °F is shown below. What is the hallmark of this patient's ECG marked by arrows in the image below?
questions.solution:
The hallmark of this patient's ECG is the Osborn J wave.

Hypothermia is defined as core body temperature is less than 95°F.

In the initial stages of hypothermia, as a reaction to the general stress, there is sinus tachycardia. As the temperature drops below 90°F, there is sinus bradycardia associated with prolongation of the PR interval, QRS complex, and QT interval progressively.

With temperature approaching 86°F, atrial ectopic activity is often noted and can progress to atrial fibrillation. It is at this level of hypothermia that many patients have Osborn waves that consist of an extra deflection at the end of the QRS complex. J waves occur when a heterogeneous distribution of potassium current enhances the activity of a transient outward potassium current in the heart, caused by low temperatures.

Osborn waves, also known as J waves, camel-hump waves, or hypothermic waves, are best seen in the inferior and lateral precordial leads. They become more prominent as the body temperature drops, and they regress gradually with rewarming.

A progressive widening of the QRS complex occurs when the temperature falls below 86°F, which is associated with an increased risk of ventricular fibrillation and asystole occurs when the temperature drops to about 60°F.

Other options:

Option A: Prominent U waves are seen in hypokalemia.

Option B: Tall peaked T waves are the first change in the ECG as the plasma potassium level rises.

Option C: ST segment elevation is seen in myocardial infarction.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes with complaints of fever and increasing fatigue for the past week. On examination, he is febrile, hypotensive and tachycardic. The findings of microscopic examination of his peripheral blood smear is given below. What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Fever, fatigue, hypotension, tachycardia and the blood smear showing multiple ring forms in RBCs are suggestive of malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.

Falciparum malaria, or malignant tertian malaria, is the most serious malaria. Plasmodium falciparum infects both young and mature erythrocytes, resulting in a large population of erythrocytes affected. Affected erythrocytes display cytoadherence, form rosettes and cause capillary plugging in vital organs like the brain, kidney, lungs etc. Diagnosis is by demonstration of P. falciparum in peripheral blood smear. The peripheral smear findings of falciparum malaria include:

  • Multiple ring forms: Multiple delicate rings are visible within the erythrocytes
  • Double chromatin: Binucleate ring forms resembling stereo headphones
  • Accole form or form applique: Ring forms are attached to the margins of red cells
  • Maurer's dots or clefts: Coarse brick red dots within erythrocytes
  • Banana shaped gametocytes within erythrocytes
  • Absent schizont

The below image shows banana shaped gametocyte:

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is diagnosed with an indirect inguinal hernia. The surgeon uses the suture material given in the image below for the hernia repair. It is a polyamide polymer that undergoes degradation and loses tensile strength at the rate of 15-20% every year. Identify the suture material.
questions.solution:
The suture material is nylon.

Nylon is a monofilament or braided multifilament type non absorbable suture material. It is a polyamide polymer with low tissue reaction and is used in skin closure, abdominal wall mass closure, hernia repair, plastic surgery, neurosurgery, microsurgery, ophthalmic surgery, etc. However, it also loses 15-20% of its tensile strength every year and degrades at the rate of 15-20% every year.

Other options:

Option A: Polyester is a monofilament or braided multifilament type non-absorbable suture material made out of polyethylene terephthalate. It has an infinite tensile strength (>1 year) and remains encapsulated in body tissues. Tissue reaction when used is also low and is used in cardiovascular, ophthalmic, plastic, and general surgery.

Option B: Polypropylene is a monofilament, non-absorbable suture material made of a propylene polymer. It has an infinite tensile strength (>1 year). It is used in plastic surgery, cardiovascular surgery, hernia repair, ophthalmic surgery, and general surgical subcuticular skin closure.

Option D: Polyglycaprone (Monocryl) is an absorbable suture material and is used in the subcuticular suturing of the skin. It is a monofilament suture which is a copolymer of glycolite and caprolactone. It is absorbed in 90-120 days and it retains tensile strength in-vivo for a maximum of 21 days.

questions.text: The device shown below is the most widely used instrument for measuring  _______.
questions.solution:
The given image is of a dry and wet bulb hygrometer. It is the most widely used instrument for measuring the humidity of air. 

A dry and wet bulb hygrometer consists of two identical thermometers—a dry bulb thermometer and a wet-bulb thermometer—mounted side by side on a stand. 

After obtaining the readings of both thermometers, the corresponding relative humidity can be found in psychrometric charts and slides. 

Other instruments used to measure humidity:

  • Sling psychrometer
  • Assmann psychrometer

Other options:

Option B - The mean radiant temperature is measured using a globe thermometer.

Option C - The cooling power of air was originally measured using a kata thermometer. Kata thermometer is now largely used for recording low air velocities. 

Option D - The maximum temperature reached in a given time is measured by a maximum thermometer. The thermometer is set each time by swinging briskly.

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

The following image depicts a whirling psychrometer:

The following image depicts an Assmann psychrometer:

The following image depicts a dry and wet hygrometer:

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient came with complaints of pain, photophobia, and watery discharge for a few days. The inspection findings are as shown in the image below. On examination, preauricular lymph nodes are found to be enlarged. No history of pharyngitis or fever was present.  Which of the following can be a causative agent for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of pain, redness, photophobia, lacrimation of both eyes with preauricular lymphadenopathy, and an image showing conjunctival congestion, chemosis, multiple hemorrhages in bulbar conjunctiva along with lid edema are suggestive of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis. It is caused by enterovirus 70.  

Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by picornavirus namely enterovirus 70 and coxsackievirus. It is also known as Apollo conjunctivitis. 

Patients present with pain, watering, mild photophobia, transient blurring of vision, and lid swelling.

On examination conjunctival congestion, chemosis, multiple hemorrhages in bulbar conjunctiva, follicular hyperplasia, lid edema, and preauricular lymphadenopathy.

It has a rapid onset and is usually self-limiting, running a course of 1-2 weeks. Broad-spectrum antibiotic eye drops can be used to prevent secondary bacterial infections. 

Other options:

Option A- Herpes simplex causes herpetic conjunctivitis. It presents as acute unilateral follicular conjunctivitis and is often associated with skin vesicles.

Option B- Adenovirus 3, 4 and 7 causes pharyngoconjunctival fever. It is characterized by acute follicular conjunctivitis in association with pharyngitis, fever, and occasionally preauricular lymphadenopathy. It is commonly seen in children. 

Option D- Molluscum contagiosum is a skin infection caused by a human-specific double-stranded DNA pox virus. The skin lesions shed virus particles and can cause chronic follicular conjunctivitis. It is commonly seen in children between the age of 2-4 years.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of the lesion shown in the image below?

questions.text: Abdominal examination of a 28-year-old primigravida, who is in the second stage of labour, reveals retraction ring between the active upper segment and the distended lower segment. Which would best describe this ring?
questions.solution:
Bandl's ring refers to pathological retraction ring. It is formed in cases of obstructed labour.

The upper segment of the uterus contracts and retracts vigourously in an attempt to overcome the obstruction while the lower segment dilates.

With each contraction there is myometrial shortening so that the actively contracting upper segment becomes progressively thicker and shorter. The passive lower segment is progressively stretched and becomes thinner.

The junction between the two segments stands out prominently as a pathological retraction ring.

Schroeder's constriction ring is formed due to incordinate uterine action when there is localized spastic contraction of a ring of circular muscle fibres of the uterus. It is formed due to injudicious use of oxytocin and premature rupture of membranes (PROM).

questions.text:
A patient diagnosed with hereditary hyperlipoproteinemia is being treated with fenofibrate. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?

LPL - Lipoprotein lipase; PPARα - Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-alpha

choices.text: Bind to PPARα and increase LPL synthesis
Binds bile acids in the intestine

questions.solution:
Fenofibrate increases lipoprotein lipase activity through peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-alpha (PPAR-α); hence, Option A is correct.

Fenofibrate is a fibric acid derivative. Fibrates bind to peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (PPARα) and reduce triglyceride levels by PPARα-mediated stimulation of fatty acid oxidation, increased LPL synthesis, and reduced expression of apo C-III. Fibrates increase the HDL by PPARα-mediated stimulation of apo A-I and apo A-II expression. Fibrates are the drugs of choice for treating type III hyperlipoproteinemia, as well as mild hypertriglyceridemia (triglycerides <400 mg/dL).

Other options:

Option B: Niacin inhibits the lipolysis of triglycerides by hormone-sensitive lipase in adipose tissue. It leads to a reduction of the transport of free fatty acids to the liver, thereby decreasing hepatic triglyceride synthesis.

Option C: Statins cause a reduction of LDL levels by competitively inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase which is the rate-limiting step in cholesterol biosynthesis. Statins affect blood cholesterol levels by inhibiting hepatic cholesterol synthesis, which results in increased expression of the LDL receptor gene.

Option D: The bile acid sequestrants (Cholestyramine, Colestipol, Colesevelam) are highly positively charged and bind to negatively charged bile acids. The resins are not absorbed because of their large size, and the bound bile acids are excreted in the stool. Interruption in the process of reabsorption of bile acid leads to depletion of the pool of bile acids, and hepatic bile acid synthesis increases. As a result, hepatic cholesterol content declines, which stimulates the production of LDL receptors.

4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: A person is brought dead to the casualty and you notice certain eye changes, which are marked in the image below. The person has not been dead for more than 4 hours.  What is the shown postmortem change known as?
questions.solution:
The postmortem change shown in the given image is suggestive of tache noir, a black-colored deposit of cell debris and mucous on the sclera that occurs within 3-4 hours of death.  

Initially, yellow-colored triangles appear on either side of the cornea with the apex pointing towards the canthus. The color then progressively changes to brown and black, followed by wrinkling of the surface.

Other postmortem changes occurring in the eye:

  • Loss of corneal reflex
  • Flaccidity of eyeballs occurs due to a reduction in intraocular pressure (IOP). IOP reaches zero at the end of 2 hours after death.
  • Dilatation of the pupil due to relaxation of muscles of the iris
  • Increased potassium concentration in the vitreous up to 100 hours following death
  • Kevorkian sign (Option A) occurs due to fragmentation of blood column in the retinal vessels, which lasts for about 1 hour. It occurs due to the loss of blood pressure and can be seen only through an ophthalmoscope as shown below:

Other options

Option C- During the distribution of postmortem hypostasis, the pressure by collar bands, waistbands, belts, wrinkles in the clothes prevents the capillaries from filling due to gravity. Such areas remain free from stain and are seen as strips or bands called vibices. 

Option D- Tardieu spots are round, dark, and well-defined pinpoint petechial hemorrhages. They are seen in asphyxial deaths. This occurs due to the increased intravenous pressure, leading to the rupture of thin-walled capillaries and venules.

questions.text: A wet mount examination of the stool sample of a patient with abdominal pain and diarrhea is given below.  Which of the following parasites is he likely infected with?
questions.solution:
The given image showing an operculated egg (egg having a lid-like structure on its end) in the stool sample is suggestive of Fasciola hepatica infection.

The eggs of Fasciola hepatica are large, ovoid, operculated, and bile stained. They contain an immature larva (miracidium) and do not float in the saturated salt solution.

The following are the parasites with operculated eggs:

  • Fasciola hepatica
  • Fasciolopsis buski
  • Fasciola gigantica
  • Paragonimus westermani
  • Opisthorchis felineus
  • Clonorchis sinensis
  • Gastrodiscoides hominis
  • Diphyllobothrium latum

Eggs of Schistosoma japonicum, Enterobius vermicularis, and Ancylostoma duodenale are non-operculated. 

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for an accessory spleen?
questions.solution:
The most common site for accessory spleen or splenunculi is the splenic hilum. 

An accessory spleen, a supernumerary spleen, a splenule, or a splenunculus refers to splenic tissue found outside the normal spleen. Around 10% to 30% of the population have accessory spleens; with an individual having one to six accessory splenic buds. Furthermore, the size of an accessory spleen can also vary. Most accessory spleens are approximately 1 centimeter but spleens larger than a few centimeters have also been observed.

Accessory spleens are formed due to incomplete fusion of mesenchymal buds during development. 

Most of the accessory spleens are observed in the splenic hilum, the site at which blood vessels enter the spleen; this is followed by the tail of the pancreas, with about 20% of all accessory splenic tissue appearing here. The rest can be found in areas such as the gastrosplenic ligaments, the lienorenal ligaments, the wall of the stomach, the wall of the intestines, the greater omentum, the mesentery, or even the pelvis or scrotum.

Accessory spleens are of importance during procedures like splenectomies and imaging studies.

In a therapeutic splenectomy, it is necessary to remove all accessory splenic tissue for resolution of symptoms failing which symptoms will continue because an accessory spleen is a functional splenic tissue. Conditions that tend to necessitate this sort of management are hemolytic anemia and chronic idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura.

Accessory spleens are also relevant when evaluating the results of imaging studies; for example, when a patient undergoes a CT scan, accessory spleens can appear similar to lymph nodes or even a neoplastic growth.

questions.text: A wildlife photographer presents with complaints of fever and a skin lesion as shown below. He also gives the history of insect bite at the site of skin lesion. A blood test reveals a positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins.  Which of the following is the most likely etiological agent causing this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing eschar at the bite site along with a positive Weil-Felix reaction with OX K agglutinins is suggestive of scrub typhus. It is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi.

Scrub typhus is also known as chigger-borne typhus which is caused by O. tsutsugamushi. The vector is trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. 

The incubation period is 1–3 weeks. The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash.

Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains—Proteus vulgaris - OX 19 and OX 2 and Proteus mirabilis OX K. The basis of the test is sharing an alkali-stable carbohydrate antigen by some Rickettsiae and by some strains of Proteus.

OX K is agglutinated only in scrub typhus.

questions.text: A statistician is working on a study about the hemoglobin status of children in an area. He plotted the frequency distribution as shown below.  Which of the following is most likely to be the mean, median, and mode, respectively of the same?
questions.solution:
The image given shows a positively/ right-skewed distribution where mean> median> mode. Hence, the mean, median, and mode must be 11, 9, and 7 respectively. None of the other options have such a sequence.

The observed value that occurs with the greatest frequency is known as the mode. If there are two values that occur with the same greatest frequency, the distribution is bimodal. If there are more than two such values, the distribution becomes multimodal. 

When all the values are listed in order, the value that divides the distribution in half is known as the median. When there are an even number of values, the median is obtained by calculating the mean of the two middle scores.

The mean (average) is obtained by summing up all the values and dividing the obtained sum by the total number of values in the distribution.

Skewed distributions are the ones that have asymmetric frequency distributions. They can be identified as positive (right) or negative (left) according to the location of the tail of the curve.

In the image, the tail is located on the positive side of the graph (right side) and so it is a positively or right-skewed distribution. A positively skewed data set contains a large number of low scores but a small number of very high scores. It is vice versa in negatively skewed distributions.

The mean in a positively skewed distribution is pulled up because of the relatively small number of very high scores. The mode is the most frequent and the highest point on the curve, while the median lies between the mean and mode. 

Other options:

Option A: Mean= median= mode is seen in a normal (unimodal) distribution.

Option C: Mean< median< mode is seen in a negatively skewed distribution.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

questions.text: In an experiment, a researcher is using gene knockout technology and inducing cell death. The following pattern is visualized in an agarose gel by ethidium bromide staining of DNA fragments released from these cells. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this mechanism of cell death?

choices.text: BCL2, BCL-XL, MCL-1 promote cell death
Karyorrhexis and karyolysis are essential steps in the process
Annexin V is a marker for this process
Caspase-8 plays an important role in the intrinsic pathway

questions.solution:
Annexin V is a marker for this process.
 

The given image shows the characteristic DNA ladder pattern visualized in the agarose gel electrophoresis with an ethidium bromide stain which is indicative of apoptosis.

Apoptosis is defined as the programmed cell death characterized by activation of intrinsic enzymes that degrade the cells' genomic DNA, nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins.

Genes involved in the regulation of apoptosis:
  • BCL2, BCL-XL, MCL-1 are anti-apoptotic genes that keep the outer mitochondrial membrane-impermeable to death-inducing proteins. Thereby they prevent the leakage of cytochrome c and other death-inducing proteins into the cytosol.
  • BAX and BAK are pro-apoptotic factors that insert into the mitochondrial membrane and create channels that allow proteins from the inner mitochondrial membrane to leak out into the cytoplasm.
  • Initiators of apoptosis include BAD, BIM, BID, Puma, and Noxa. Their activity is upregulated and activated by sensors of cellular stress and damage.

Apoptosis has two pathways:

Mitochondrial or intrinsic pathway:

Cell injury results in the release of cytochrome c and other pro-apoptotic proteins from mitochondria. Cytochrome c binds to a protein called APAF-1 (apoptosis-activating factor-1), forming apoptosome. These then activate caspase 9 which cause nuclear fragmentation and the formation of apoptotic bodies

Death receptor or extrinsic pathway:

In this pathway, activation of death receptors causes apoptosis by activating caspase-8. Prototypic death receptors are the type I TNF receptor and Fas (CD95). Fas ligand (FasL) binds to Fas and forms a binding site to the FADD (Fas-associated death domain). This activates caspase 8 and initiates apoptosis.

Other Options:

Option A- BCL2, BCL-XL, MCL-1 are anti-apoptotic molecules.

Option B- Karyorrhexis and karyolysis are essential steps in necrosis.

Option D- Caspase-8 plays an important role in the extrinsic pathway.
