questions.text: Which of the following drugs has recently been approved for the treatment of non-small-cell lung carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The drug recently approved for the treatment of non-small-cell lung carcinoma is dacomitinib.

Dacomitinib is an irreversible inhibitor of the activity of the human epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), which plays a role in tumour growth, metastasis, and treatment resistance. It is administered orally and 98% of the drug binds to plasma proteins. It is metabolised in the liver and has a very long half-life of 45 hours. The adverse effects include stomatitis, rash, palmar-plantar erythrodysesthesia syndrome, dehydration, paronychia, and diarrhoea. It can also lead to an increase in serum aminotransferase levels without any incidence of acute liver failure.

Gefitinib, erlotinib and afatinib are protein kinase antagonists which presently constitute the first line treatment of non-small cell lung carcinoma with ATP site mutation of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR).

Other options:

Option B: Lenvatinib inhibits the protein kinase activities of VEGFR and approved for the treatment of patients with recurrent or metastatic differentiated thyroid cancer and in combination with everolimus for patients with advanced renal cell cancer. Lenvatinib is orally bioavailable, metabolized by CYP3A with a t1/2of 28 h. Major adverse effects include hypertension, thrombotic and hemorrhagic events, hepatotoxicity, GI perforation, and QT prolongation. 

Option C: Bosutinib is a second-generation BCR-ABL kinase inhibitor that can be administered orally and has been approved by the FDA for the treatment of patients with chronic, accelerated, or blast-phase CML with resistance or intolerance to prior therapy. The most common adverse reactions are diarrhoea, nausea, thrombocytopenia, vomiting, abdominal pain, rash, anaemia, pyrexia, and fatigue.

Option D: Ruxolitinib is a Janus-associated protein kinase (JAK) inhibitor which is an analogue of ATP, indicated for the treatment of patients with polycythemia vera unresponsive to hydroxyurea and for the treatment of myelofibrosis. It has good oral bioavailability, is metabolised in the liver and largely excreted in urine, thereby necessitating a dose adjustment in patients with hepatic or renal impairment. Its most common adverse effects include thrombocytopenia and anemia. In rare cases, basal cell carcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma of skin may occur; therefore, periodic skin examinations should be done during treatment.

questions.text: A patient with low hemoglobin levels is diagnosed with pernicious anemia. Deficiency of a glycoprotein causes this condition. Identify the cell that secretes this glycoprotein among the gastric gland cells marked in the image below.
questions.solution:
The cells marked as 2 are parietal cells and they are responsible for the secretion of a glycoprotein called intrinsic factor. Deficiency of intrinsic factor results in pernicious anaemia.

Parietal cells, also called oxyntic cells are more numerous in the upper half of the gastric glands. They are characterized by the presence of canaliculi. These cells have numerous mitochondria and are actively involved in the secretion of hydrochloric acid and intrinsic factor - a glycoprotein that must be present for adequate absorption of vitamin B12 from the ileum. 

Intrinsic factor combines with vitamin B12 in the stomach and protects it from being digested and destroyed as it passes into the small intestine. Then, when the intrinsic factor–vitamin B12 complex reaches the terminal ileum, the intrinsic factor binds with receptors on the ileal epithelial surface, which makes it possible for vitamin B12 to be absorbed.

In the absence of intrinsic factor, only a small amount of vitamin B12 is absorbed. In addition, without intrinsic factor, an adequate amount of vitamin B12 is not made available from the foods to cause young, newly forming red blood cells to mature in the bone marrow. This gives rise to pernicious anemia.

Other options:

The cells marked as 1 are mucous neck cells, which are located near the upper end or "neck" of the gastric glands and secrete mucous.

The cells marked as 3  are the enterochromaffin-like cell (ECL) which are present near the basal part of gastric glands and lie between the chief cells and the basement membrane. The function of this cell is to release histamine which in turn stimulates the parietal cells to secrete HCL. The ECL is stimulated by gastrin secreted by G cells from the pylorus and acetylcholine secreted by the vagus.

The cells marked as 4 are chief cells which are numerous in the basal part of the main gastric glands. Their cells are cuboidal or low columnar, which secrete pepsinogen and gastric lipase.

questions.text: An AIDS patient presented with skin lesions as shown in the image below. Skin biopsy revealed proliferating spindle cells in the dermis with slit-like spaces containing the red cells. Identify the causative agent and its subfamily among the herpesviridae.
questions.solution:
The above image shows red-purple macules and plaques together with the clinical features, and the biopsy finding is suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma, which is caused by Human herpesvirus 8. It belongs to the gamma viruses subfamily of the herpesviridae family.

Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular tumor caused by human herpesvirus 8, also called Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV). It is the most common HIV-related malignancy and is an AIDS-defining illness. The lesions appear as red-purple macules or raised plaques over the skin, and the biopsy shows spindle cells in the dermis.

The Herpesviridae family is divided into 3 subfamilies:

  • Beta herpes viruses

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient with a demyelinating disease presents with a  cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) report showing the presence of oligoclonal bands. His MRI brain is given below. His laboratory investigations showed positivity for the John Cunningham (JC) virus antibody. Which of the following drugs is not recommended for this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a demyelinating disease with oligoclonal bands in CSF and the image showing periventricular and callosal lesions called Dawson's finger sign is suggestive of multiple sclerosis. Natalizumab is not recommended for this patient.

Natalizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the α4 subunit of α4β1 integrin. It is highly effective and reduces the attack rate thus improving the severity of the disease (both clinical and MRI). Natalizumab is given as an injectable preparation. 

The major concern associated with natalizumab is the risk of the development of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), which is also a life-threatening condition developed from the JC virus infection. The risk of developing PML is higher in patients taking natalizumab associated with JC antibody positive. Therefore, natalizumab is recommended only for JC antibody-negative patients.

Other options:

Option A- Fingolimod is a sphingosine-1-phosphate inhibitor. It reduces the attack rate and improves the disease severity in multiple sclerosis. It is given as oral preparation. The patients on fingolimod are at risk of developing macular edema and disseminated varicella-zoster infection.

Option B- Teriflunomide inhibits the mitochondrial enzyme, dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase present in de novo pyrimidine synthesis. It is given as oral preparation. The adverse effect includes Stevens-Johnson syndrome. It has teratogenicity and is considered a category X drug. 

Option C- Ocrelizumab is a humanized monoclonal antibody against the CD20 molecule located on the surface of mature B cells. It is given as an intravenous preparation. It is associated with an increased risk of malignancies like breast cancers and infusion reactions.

questions.text: A senior resident who is in charge of the labor ward asks you to perform cardiotocography (CTG) in a G2P1 patient. The tracing that you obtain is as shown in the image below. This finding is associated with which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
The given CTG shows early decelerations. It is seen in fetal head compression.

In early decelerations, the onset, nadir, and recovery of deceleration coincide with the beginning, peak, and ending of uterine contraction respectively.

This finding in CTG is suggestive of fetal head compression causing vagal nerve activation.

 

The CTG given below shows late decelerations, Here the fetal heart rate begins to drop after the end of uterine contraction. It is mostly associated with uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia.

Other causes of late decelerations include:

  • Placental pathologies like- postmaturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption
  • Excessive uterine contractions
  • Excessive use of oxytocin
  • Epidural anesthesia

 

The CTG given below shows variable decelerations as seen in umbilical cord compression.

 

The CTG given below shows a sinusoidal pattern. It resembles a sine wave. It is often associated with fetal anemia, fetomaternal hemorrhage, and fetal acidosis.

Related Pearl: Deceleration patterns on cardiotocography (CTG)

Early deceleration: seen in head compression

 

Late deceleration: Seen in uteroplacental insufficiency, foetal hypoxia

 

Variable deceleration: Seen in umbilical cord compression

questions.text: Visual field testing of a  48-year-old male patient in the neurology ward revealed the following type of visual defect. Where is the likely site of lesion in the optic pathway?
questions.solution:
The image shows inferior homonymous quadrantanopia (pie on the floor). The likely site of the lesion is the parietal lobe.

In inferior homonymous quadrantanopia, the superior fibers of the optic radiations in the parietal lobe which subserve the inferior visual field are affected.

Some of the associated features of dominant parietal lobe disease are acalculia, agraphia, left-right disorientation, and finger agnosia while non-dominant lobe lesions may cause dressing, constitutional apraxia, and spatial neglect.

Other options:

Option A- In temporal lobe lesion, the inferior fibers of optic radiations which subserve the upper visual fields get involved and result in superior homonymous quadrantanopia (pie in the sky). 

Option C- In occipital lobe lesions:

  • Congruous homonymous hemianopia sparing macula occurs in occlusion of the posterior cerebral artery supplying the anterior part of the visual cortex
  • Congruous homonymous macular defects occur in the lesions of the tip of the occipital cortex
  • Bilateral homonymous hemianopia with macula sparing occurs in bilateral occipital lobe lesions
  • Bilateral homonymous macula defects occur in the bilateral occipital cortex lesions

Option D- In optic chiasma lesion, decussating fibers on the body of chiasma get involved and produces bitemporal hemianopia. 

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic male patient presented with arthralgia and skin pigmentation. On examination, he was found to have hepatomegaly, arthropathy involving small joints, excessive skin pigmentation with characteristic slate-grey hue, and hypogonadism. What will be the best treatment for this disease?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to hemochromatosis, and the best treatment for this iron-overload state is phlebotomy. One 500-mL unit of blood contains 200–250 mg of iron. Iron removal can be accomplished by weekly or twice-weekly phlebotomy of 500 mL.

With repeated phlebotomy, the following changes occur:

  • Liver decreases in size
  • Liver function improves
  • Hepatic fibrosis may decrease, but established cirrhosis is irreversible
  • Pigmentation of skin decreases
  • Cardiac failure may be reversed
  • Diabetes also improves in about 40% of patients
  • There is little or no effect of arthropathy and hypogonadism. In some cases, arthropathy may even progress, despite therapy.

The goal is to reduce the serum ferritin levels to 50–100 ng/mL. Once the goal is reached, the phlebotomies may be done at appropriate intervals (usually, 3-4 times a year), required to maintain the serum ferritin levels at that level. 

Hemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disease caused due to mutation in the HFE gene on chromosome 6. It is tightly linked to the HLA-A locus on chromosome 6p.

Clinical manifestations are initially non-specific like lethargy, arthralgia, skin pigmentation, and features of diabetes mellitus. The liver is the first organ to be affected, resulting in hepatomegaly, ascites, and spider angiomas. Other systems are also affected, leading to cardiac arrhythmias, congestive cardiac failure, and testicular atrophy. 

Pathogenesis:

The mutated HFE gene on chromosome 6p causes abnormally low levels of hepcidin, which is a principal iron regulatory hormone. This, in turn, leads to increased iron absorption from the duodenum. The excessively absorbed iron is primarily deposited in the parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas; heart; joints; and endocrine organs.

Other features:

  • Hemochromatosis can also be acquired from iron overload due to hemolytic anemia and transfusions.
  • It is associated with an increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is the most common manifestation of hemochromatosis. Hemochromatosis can also produce restrictive cardiomyopathy but it is less common as compared to DCM.

Diagnosis: Clinical features, family history, and laboratory investigations directed at diagnosing an increase in total body iron stores using serum iron, transferrin saturation, and serum ferritin levels. Liver biopsy with measurement of the iron concentration and calculation of the hepatic iron index. MRI of the liver is also indicated.

Other options:

Option B- Deferoxamine is a chelating agent, which removes 10–20 mg of iron per day when given parenterally. It is used in cases of severe iron load or when phlebotomy is not well-tolerated.

Options A and D- Trientine and D-penicillamine are chelating agents that bind to copper and are used in the treatment of Wilson's disease.

questions.text: During your internship, you notice the following cylinder attached to an anesthetic machine present in the operation theater.  In which of the following scenario the inhalational agent from this can be used?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a blue color cylinder that is used to store nitrous oxide (N2O). It is commonly used for analgesia and sedation in dental procedures.

Nitrous oxide is 35 times more soluble than nitrogen in the blood. It tends to diffuse into air-containing cavities more rapidly than nitrogen is absorbed by the bloodstream. Due to this reason nitrous oxide is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Pneumothorax
  • Acute intestinal obstruction with bowel distention
  • Intracranial air (pneumocephalus following dural closure or pneumoencephalography)
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting

Side effects of nitrous oxide are:

  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Bone marrow depression
  • Teratogenicity
  • Peripheral neuropathy

Related Pearl: Unique features of Nitrous oxide

Concentration-effect

  • The blood gas partition coefficient of N2O is 35 times higher than O2 and N2, hence its rapid uptake diminishes its volume and concentrates the remaining anesthetics in the alveolus.

Second-gas effect

  • Concentration-effect of one gas over another is known as the second gas effect
  • Increase in the partial pressure of the 2nd gas (Oxygen and volatile agents) due to the rapid uptake of N2O during induction.

Diffusion hypoxia (Finks effect)

  • Rapid elimination of N2O during recovery causes a reduction in the partial pressure of oxygen leading to hypoxia
  • Avoided by using 100% oxygen for 10 minutes during recovery from anesthesia.

Nitrous oxide in gas-filled spaces

  • It diffuses into air-containing cavities more rapidly than air (principally nitrogen) can be absorbed by the bloodstream
  • If the walls surrounding the cavity are rigid, pressure rises instead of volume.

Hence N2O is contraindicated in:

  • Venous or arterial air embolism
  • Acute intestinal obstruction
  • Pneumocephalus, pneumothorax
  • Pulmonary air cysts
  • Intraocular air bubbles
  • Tympanic membrane grafting.

questions.text: A neonatology study was conducted between 2 groups of newborns by measuring their weights. Assigning the neonates to 2 groups was based on whether their mothers did or did not receive food supplements during the antenatal period. Which of the following statistical tests can be used to correlate the means obtained?
questions.solution:
The above study tests the difference between the sample means of 2 independent groups (weights of newborns of mothers who did or did not receive food supplements in the antenatal period). Student’s t-test (unpaired t-test) can be used to compare the means of 2 groups that are independent of each other.

Means can only be calculated for quantitative variables; hence, we use the parametric tests here. The type of parametric test to be used depends on the number of groups being tested.

Other options:

Option A- Paired t-test is used for a single sample to test the difference between two paired results. 

Option C- ANOVA method is used to assess the relative size of variance among the group means compared to the average variance within the groups. ANOVA is used to compare means among three or more groups.

Option D- Chi-square test is a non-parametric test used to analyze the differences when two dependable variables are measured at a nominal level.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text:
A patient presented from the dermatology out-patient with a biopsy-proven melanoma on her right arm with a Breslow depth of 2.1 mm. Nodes were clinically negative. What is the surgical management for this patient?

SLNB: Sentinal lymph node biopsy
questions.solution:
Wide local excision with a resection margin of 2 cm along with sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) will be recommended for melanomas invading to a depth > 2mm.

Recommended margins of wide local excision:

Depth Margin
In situ 0.5 cm
<1 mm 1 cm
1-2 mm 1-2 cm
>2-4 mm 2 cm
>4 mm 2 cm

Wide local excision with SLNB is preferred for early-stage tumours. SLNB should be performed for lesions >1mm in depth. If SLNB is positive or if nodes are clinically positive, lymph node dissection should be performed.

SLN biopsy is more challenging in the head and neck than in other regions because of the rich lymphatic drainage network, and the false-negative rate for SLN biopsy is generally higher for melanomas in these locations. Cross-sectional imaging, such as with a single-photon emission CT, helps to identify the exact anatomic location of the SLNs more accurately.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male patient is admitted for acute pancreatitis. He complains of breathlessness and cough 3 days later. He is diagnosed to be in acute respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is not included in the diagnostic criteria for acute respiratory distress syndrome?

PaO2- Partial pressure of oxygen

FiO2- Fraction of inspired oxygen
questions.solution:
Unilateral interstitial infiltrates are not included in the diagnostic criteria for acute respiratory distress syndrome.

The diagnostic criteria as per Berlin's definition of ARDS is:

  • It develops within 1 week of clinical insult or onset of respiratory symptoms.
  • Chest radiograph shows bilateral opacities consistent with pulmonary edema. These opacities are not fully explained by effusions, lobar or lung collapse, or nodules.
  • The pulmonary edema is not due to cardiac failure, or fluid overload.
  • There is impaired oxygenation. The ratio of arterial oxygen partial pressure to the fraction of inspired oxygen (PaO2/FiO2) is ≤ 300 mmHg as assessed on 5 cm H2O of positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) or continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). 

Depending on the value of PaO2/FiO2 (with PEEP or CPAP ≥5 cm H2O) it can be

  • Mild: PaO2/FiO2 is between 300mmHg to 200 mmHg
  • Moderate: PaO2/FiO2 is between 200mmHg to 100 mmHg
  • Severe: PaO2/FiO2 is ≤ 100mmHg

Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is the most severe type of acute lung injury characterized by poor oxygenation, pulmonary infiltrates, and acuity of onset. It is associated with capillary endothelial injury and diffuse alveolar damage. Conditions associated with direct lung injury like pneumonia, aspiration of gastric contents, pulmonary contusion, near-drowning, and toxic inhalational injury are associated with ARDS. Systemic conditions causing indirect lung injury and ARDS include sepsis, severe trauma (head injury, burns, multiple bone fractures), multiple blood transfusions, and pancreatitis.

ARDS is characterized by the development of dyspnea, tachypnea, and increased work of breathing. The chest radiograph shows opacities involving most of the bilateral lung fields as shown below.

 

The main treatment strategy which has been shown to reduce mortality in patients is low tidal volume ventilation (6 mL/kg of predicted body weight). Conventional tidal volume ventilation leads to overdistension injury because the lung in ARDS is already consolidated and any attempt to push more air through it will lead to barotrauma. Apart from this, high PEEP, prone position, early neuromuscular blockade, and use of extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) may also be useful.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency room of a hospital after he consumed 12-14 tablets of acetaminophen 650 mg . He complains of nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain. The false statement regarding this condition is:

choices.text: Plasma transaminases are elevated within 6 hours after ingestion
Centrilobular necrosis can be seen in this condition
N-acetyl cysteine helps replenish glutathione stores

questions.solution:
The given scenario indicates acetaminophen poisoning. Plasma transaminases become elevated about 12–36 hours after ingestion, not within 6 hours.

Acetaminophen is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID), which appears to inhibit cyclooxygenase (COX) in the brain selectively and has both analgesic and antipyretic effects. Even though acetaminophen has a good safety profile at therapeutic levels, it can cause severe liver toxicity if taken in large amounts.

Acetaminophen poisoning can cause necrosis in the Centrilobular zone of the portal triad. Hepatic injury with acetaminophen involves its conversion to the toxic metabolite N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI). Generally, it is eliminated rapidly by conjugation with glutathione and then metabolized to a mercapturic acid before being excreted into the urine. 

However, in an acetaminophen overdose, hepatocellular levels of glutathione become depleted as a result of which the NAPQI metabolite binds covalently to cell macromolecules, leading to cellular dysfunction. Furthermore, depletion of intracellular glutathione renders the hepatocytes highly susceptible to oxidative stress and apoptosis. Renal tubular necrosis and hypoglycemic coma also may occur.

N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI) is a toxic metabolite of acetaminophen which causes hepatotoxicity. In adults, hepatotoxicity may occur after ingestion of a single dose of 10–15 g (150–250 mg/kg) of acetaminophen; doses of 20–25 g or more are potentially fatal.

Plasma transaminases become elevated, beginning about 12–36 hours after ingestion. Symptoms that occur during the first 2 days include nausea, abdominal pain, anorexia ; indications of hepatic damage manifest within 2–4 days of ingestion and present as right subcostal pain, tender hepatomegaly, jaundice, and coagulopathy. Renal impairment or frank renal failure may occur. Liver enzyme abnormalities typically peak 72–96 h after ingestion. Biopsy of the liver would show centrilobular necrosis with periportal sparing.

Activated charcoal, if given within 4 h of ingestion, decreases acetaminophen absorption considerably and should be administered if the ingested dose is suspected to exceed 7.5 g. N-acetyl cysteine is indicated for those at risk of hepatic injury and functions by detoxifying NAPQI and replenishing glutathione stores. 

Hypoglycemia may result from liver failure, therefore plasma glucose should be monitored closely. Fulminant hepatic failure is an indication for liver transplantation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient presented with painless, foul-smelling ear discharge from the right ear. The angle of the mouth has deviated to the left side. On otoscopic examination, multiple perforations were seen in the pars tensa of the tympanic membrane. Identify the causative organism for this condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of the diagnosis as tubercular otitis media and Mycobacterium tuberculosis is the causative agent.

The above clinical scenario of painless, foul-smelling discharge, facial palsy with multiple perforations in the pars tensa of the tympanic membrane are suggestive of tubercular otitis media.

Tubercular otitis media is usually secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis where the infection spreads to the middle ear through the eustachian tube or is blood-borne from the tubercular focus. It is more commonly seen in children and young adults.

It presents as a painless condition, with foul-smelling discharge from the ear. Multiple perforations in pars tensa of the tympanic membrane and pale granulations in the middle ear cleft are seen. Severe hearing loss, mostly conductive type is seen in tubercular otitis media. If the labyrinth is involved then, sensorineural hearing loss can occur. Facial palsy is a common complication in the tubercular otitis media.

Diagnosis is based on the culture of the ear discharge for tubercle bacilli, histopathological examinations of granulations, and chest radiograph.

Treatment includes systemic antitubercular therapy, local treatment with an aural toilet, and mastoid surgery in cases of complications.

Other options:

Options B, C, and D- Streptococcus pneumonia, Hemophilus influenzae, and Moraxella catarrhalis are the most common causative organisms for acute suppurative otitis media(ASOM). Acute suppurative otitis media is an acute inflammation of the middle ear caused by pyogenic organisms. It is differentiated into 4 stages:

  • Stage of tubal occlusion- The symptoms are deafness and earache. Otoscopic signs include retracted tympanic membrane with a horizontal position of the handle of malleus, prominent lateral process of malleus, loss of light reflex.
  • Stage of presuppuration- The symptoms are marked earache, deafness, tinnitus, and a high grade of fever. Otoscopic signs include congested pars tensa of the tympanic membrane and cart-wheel appearance (leash of blood vessels appear along with the handle of malleus and at the periphery of the tympanic membrane). 
  • Stage of suppuration- The symptoms are excruciating earache, deafness, and fever. Otoscopic signs include red and bulging tympanic membrane with loss of the landmarks 
  • Stage of resolution- Earache is relieved with the evacuation of the pus. A small perforation is seen on the anteroinferior quadrant of pars tensa. Hyperemia of tympanic membrane subsides.

Below is an image showing the cart-wheel appearance of the tympanic membrane.

ASOM by antibiotics, decongestant nasal drops, analgesics, aural toilet, and myringotomy to relieve pus.

questions.text: You are providing cardiopulmonary resuscitation to an unconscious adult patient. Which of the following statements correctly describes effective chest compressions?

choices.text: Full chest recoil is avoided between 2 compressions
The chest is pressed to a depth of 4 inches
Given at lower half of the sternum

questions.solution:
Effective chest compressions in BLS are given on the lower half of the patient's sternum at a rate of 100-120 compressions per minute (30 compressions for every 15-18 sec).

Adequate chest compressions create blood flow by increasing the intrathoracic pressure and directly compressing the heart.

2015 AHA guidelines for cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) recommend a chest compression of 100-120/min, a depth for adults of at least 2 inches. 

Components of high-quality CPR include compressing the chest at an adequate rate and depth. Allowing complete chest recoil after each compression. Minimizing interruptions in compressions and should avoid excessive ventilation.

Effective chest compression in adults:

  • Provide 15 chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute.
  • Place your arms, one over the other in the midline, on the lower half of the patient's sternum, and lock your arms.
  • Use both arms to press the chest to a depth of 5- 6cm
  • Allow for full chest recoil after every compression.

Related Pearl: High quality CPR for adults

  • Push hard: 5-6cm depth
  • Push fast: 100-120/min frequency
  • Allow for complete chest recoil
  • Minimize interruptions in compressions <10 seconds
  • Avoid excessive ventilation
  • Rotate compressor every 2 min or earlier if fatigued
  • If no advanced airway, 30:2 compression-ventilation ratio

Attempt to improve CPR quality if :

  • Quantitative waveform capnography - PETCO2 <10mmHg, 
  • Intra-arterial pressure - If relaxation phase (diastolic) pressure <20mmHg

questions.text: Autopsy findings in a young woman who died of cardiac failure reveal small, warty vegetations on mitral valve leaflets, an enlarged left atrium, and mitral leaflet calcification with orifice narrowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above autopsy findings of small, warty vegetations along the lines of closure of the valve leaflets, enlargement of the left atrium and mitral leaflet calcification with mitral orifice narrowing (fish-mouth appearance) are suggestive of rheumatic heart disease.

Rheumatic heart disease (RHD) is a long-term sequel of acute rheumatic fever characterised by deforming fibrotic valvular disease. The mitral valve is most commonly affected. It results due to the antibody cross-reaction between streptococcal M proteins and cardiac self-antigens. 

Histopathology of RHD: 

Aschoff bodies are the lesions found in the heart during acute rheumatic fever. They are composed of foci of T lymphocytes, a few plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages called Anitschkow cells. Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and central round-to-ovoid nuclei with slender, wavy, ribbon-like chromatin. Hence they are also called caterpillar cells.

The image below image shows Aschoff's body.


The image below shows Anitschkow cells:


Fibrinoid necrosis occurs due to inflammation of the endocardium and the left-sided valves. Over these areas of necrosis, small vegetations can be seen along the lines of closure, called verrucae. MacCallum plaques are irregular thickenings in the subendocardium. These are caused due to regurgitant jets.

In chronic RHD, the mitral valve shows leaflet thickening, commissural fusion and shortening, and thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords. Calcification and fibrous bridging of the valve can lead to narrowing the mitral orifice and giving it a fish-mouth appearance.


Other options:

Option B: Infective endocarditis is a microbial infection of the heart or mural endocardium. The aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly involved. The vegetations present on the valves are large, friable, bulky, destructive lesions that contain fibrin, inflammatory cells, and bacteria or other organisms.

Option C: Marantic endocarditis/Non-bacterial thrombotic endocarditis is characterised by small, sterile thrombi on the leaflets of the cardiac valves. It is seen in patients with cancer or sepsis. 

Option D: Libman-Sacks endocarditis is seen in people with systemic lupus erythematosus. They have medium to small-sized vegetation appearing on both sides of the leaflets. They may occur on any site like the surface of the valve, chordae, or even on the atrial or ventricular endocardium.

questions.text: A young woman, who was diagnosed with threatened abortion was referred to you from the peripheral hospital for an ultrasonography. Examination of this patient would reveal:

choices.text: Closed cervical os with absent fetal cardiac activity on USG
Closed cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG
Dilated cervical os with absent fetal cardiac activity on USG
Dilated cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG

questions.solution:
Examination of a patient diagnosed with threatened abortion would reveal closed cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG.

In threatened miscarriage, the process of miscarriage has started but has not progressed to a state from which recovery is impossible. 

Features:

  • Bleeding which is usually slight and may be brownish or bright red in color
  • Usually painless but pain appears following hemorrhage
  • Closed external os
  • Uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhea
  • Uterus and cervix feel soft
  • Transvaginal Ultrasonography shows well-formed gestation ring indicating healthy fetus with fetal cardiac activity.

Abortion is the expulsion or extraction from the mother of an embryo or fetus weighing 500 g or less when it is not capable of independent survival.

Classification of abortion:

Other options:

Option A: In missed abortion, the fetus is dead and is retained inside the uterus for a variable period. Here closed cervical os with absent fetal cardiac activity on USG can be seen.

Option C: In incomplete abortion, entire products of conception are not expelled, instead, a part of it is left inside the uterine cavity. Here dilated cervical os with absent fetal cardiac activity on USG can be seen.

Option D: In inevitable abortion, the changes have progressed to a state from where continuation of pregnancy is impossible. Here dilated cervical os with fetal cardiac activity on USG can be seen.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presented with complaints of rectal bleeding, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. On examination, an ulcer as shown in the image is noted. Barium enema revealed a hose pipe appearance in the descending and transverse colon. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with barium enema showing a hose pipe appearance (lead pipe appearance) in the descending and transverse colon, and the image showing pyoderma gangrenosum are suggestive of ulcerative colitis.

Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease resulting in superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends proximally in a continuous manner.

Clinically, patients present with abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea with mucus, and tenesmus. Other symptoms like anorexia, nausea, vomiting, fever, and weight loss are also present.

Extraintestinal manifestations associated with IBD include ocular features (episcleritis, and uveitis), dermatological manifestations (erythema nodosum, pyoderma gangrenosum), rheumatological (arthropathies, sacroiliitis, ankylosing spondylitis) and primary sclerosing cholangitis.

The diagnosis of ulcerative colitis is made by colonoscopy which pseudopolyps, granularity, friability, and ulceration involving the distal rectum, extending proximally in symmetric, continuous, and circumferential patterns called backwash ileitis.

Barium contrast enema shows a hose pipe appearance characterized by a smooth-walled and cylindrical colon with complete loss of haustrations. Fecal calprotectin and fecal lactoferrin levels will be elevated.

Severe attacks of ulcerative colitis may result in toxic megacolon, colonic perforation, and colon cancer.

Other options:

Option A: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that shows string sign of Kantor on barium enema as shown below:

 

Option C: Colon carcinoma typically arises in patients above the age group of 50 years. change in bowel habits or rectal bleeding in cases of left-sided colon tumors, and iron deficiency anemia or a mass in proximal lesions of the colon. Double-contrast barium enema shows Apple-core sign is typically seen in carcinoma colon as seen in the image below. It appears as short irregular stenosis with sharp shoulders at either end (yellow arrows):

 

Option D: Diverticulosis is seen in the age group of more than 50 years. The majority of the patients with diverticulosis are usually asymptomatic. However, some patients may present with abdominal cramps, altered bowel habits, and painless rectal bleeding.

Colonic diverticulosis gives a saw-tooth appearance on the barium enema as shown below:

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with backache. Urine examination revealed nephrotic-range proteinuria with Bence-Jones proteins. Laboratory reports showed hypercalcemia. The image below shows the appearance of a renal biopsy specimen stained with Congo red and visualized under polarized light. Accumulation of which fibril protein will majorly be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient has multiple myeloma. The major fibril protein accumulated in this patient is amyloid light chain (AL).

The above clinical scenario of backache, proteinuria with Bence-Jones protein, hypercalcemia are suggestive of multiple myeloma. The image showing a Congo red–stained biopsy specimen with apple-green birefringence under polarized microscopy is indicative of amyloid accumulation in the organ. In multiple myeloma, the amyloid is made from the light chain of immunoglobulins (chiefly λ type). 

Amyloidosis refers to extracellular deposits of fibrillar proteins. The abnormal fibrils are obtained by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits bind to proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, including heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate, and plasma proteins, notably serum amyloid P component (SAP). Amyloid is an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, extracellular substance.

Microscopy:

All types of amyloid deposits are made up of continuous, nonbranching fibrils and are demonstrated on electron microscopy. A characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation is visualized on x-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy. The stain used for amyloid deposits is Congo red staining. It imparts pink to red color to the amyloid under ordinary light. Under polarized microscopy, Congo red-stained amyloid shows apple-green birefringence.

Other options:

Option A -  The fibrillar protein amyloid β2 microglobulin (Aβ2M) is accumulated in hemodialysis-associated amyloidosis in chronic renal failure.

Option B -The fibrillar protein amyloid-associated (AA) is accumulated in secondary systemic amyloidosis and familial Mediterranean fever.

Option D - The fibrillar protein amyloid transthyretin (ATTR) is accumulated in the mutated form in familial amyloidotic polyneuropathies and in an unmutated form in systemic senile amyloidosis.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with the complaints of mass per vagina, as shown in the below image was posted for operative repair. During a pre-anesthetic check-up, she was found to be unfit for major surgery. Which of the following procedures is recommended in her?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the image is suggestive of severe uterine prolapse in elderly women. Le Fort’s repair is recommended in this case.

This repair is done in patients who satisfy the following criteria:

  • Very elderly menopausal patient with an advanced prolapse
  • Do not wish to retain sexual function
  • Medically unfit for major surgeries

This procedure can be performed under sedation and local anesthesia, or epidural anesthesia. The vaginal flaps from the anterior and posterior vaginal walls are excised, the raw areas are apposed in the midline with catgut sutures. This prevents the uterus from prolapsing.

This operation limits marital functions; hence, it should not be advised in women who wish to retain sexual function.

Other options

Abdominal sling operations are designed for women with type II or III degree prolapse and who are desirous of retaining childbearing function and menstrual function.

Sling operations are best suited to nulliparous prolapse. It includes,

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy (Option A) 
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation (Option B) 
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation (Option D)

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought with a high fever and noisy breathing. The child had a cough and cold for the past few days. A lateral x-ray of the neck showed a soft tissue swelling and widening of the prevertebral shadow. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the widening of prevertebral shadow on a lateral x-ray of the neck in a 2-year-old child suggests a diagnosis of retropharyngeal abscess. 

An acute retropharyngeal abscess commonly occurs in children below 3 years of age due to infections of adenoids or tonsils, causing suppuration in the retropharyngeal lymph nodes, which leads to abscess formation. Since the retropharyngeal lymph nodes disappear after this age, an adult retropharyngeal abscess is uncommon and usually occurs secondary to trauma.

The clinical features of a retropharyngeal abscess include dysphagia, dyspnea, stridor, croupy cough, torticollis (extended stiff neck), and unilateral swelling on the midline of the posterior pharyngeal wall. The lateral view of the radiograph shows soft tissue swelling and the widening of the prevertebral shadow. The extent of the abscess can be visualised on a contrast-enhanced CT scan.

Treatment is usually done by incision and drainage of the abscess and antibiotics. Tracheostomy is required in cases of a large abscess causing obstruction to the airway or leading to laryngeal oedema. 

The image below shows a retropharyngeal abscess seen on a lateral x-ray of the neck:

Other options:

Option A - Parapharyngeal abscess can occur from acute and chronic infections of the tonsils like dental infections, Bezold abscess, petrositis, trauma to the neck, and infections of the parotid, retropharyngeal and submaxillary spaces. Patients with anterior compartment involvement present with prolapse of the tonsil and tonsillar pillar, trismus, and swelling of the parotid region. Patients with posterior compartment involvement present with bulges of the pharynx behind the posterior pillar; paralysis of cranial nerves IX, X, XI, and XII and sympathetic chain; and swelling of the parotid region. Symptoms common to both compartments are fever, odynophagia, sore throat, torticollis, and signs of toxaemia. The extent of a lesion can be revealed by a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the neck. 

The image below shows an enhanced CT scan revealing a large mass involving the left parapharyngeal and retropharyngeal spaces, causing significant airway narrowing.

Option C- Peritonsillar abscess/quinsy is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx. It presents with severe pain in the throat, fever, chills and rigours, and a hot potato voice. There is congestion and swelling of the tonsil, pillars, and soft palate on the involved side. On examination, a bulging of the soft palate and anterior pillar above the tonsil can be seen. Uvula may be pushed to the opposite side. The presence and the extent of the abscess can be identified on a contrast-enhanced CT scan or MRI. 

The image below shows a peritonsillar abscess.

Option D- Acute epiglottitis is an acute inflammatory condition involving the epiglottis, aryepiglottic folds, and arytenoids (supraglottic structures). It is usually caused by Haemophilus influenzae and group A beta-hemolytic streptococci. The symptoms have an acute onset with a rapid progression. These include fever, sore throat, dysphagia, dyspnea, and stridor. Indirect laryngoscopy shows oedema and congestion of the supraglottic structure. A lateral x-ray of the neck shows swollen epiglottis (thumb sign).

Below is an image showing the thumb sign on a radiograph:

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has moderate hypertension for the past few years. The given image shows a section of a small blood vessel of this patient. What is the finding seen in this image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows hyaline arteriolosclerosis. Homogenous pink thickening of the vessel wall with narrowing of the lumen is seen in the above slide.

Hypertension leads to a variety of vascular pathologies. In small blood vessels, hypertension may lead to arteriosclerosis, which is the thickening of the vessel wall with loss of its elasticity. It has two variants:

  • Hyaline arteriolosclerosis - This is seen in chronic hypertension. Chronic changes in blood pressure damage the vessel wall leading to the deposition of plasma proteins and matrix. On microscopy, it appears as a homogenous pink thickening of the vessel wall with the narrowing of the lumen. It is also seen in elderly patients (normotensive or hypertensive) and diabetes mellitus.
  • Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis - This is seen in severe hypertension. Microscopy shows a characteristic concentric, laminated (onion peel appearance) thickening of the vessel wall with luminal narrowing. It is the characteristic vascular lesion of severe hypertension.

In medium and large vessels it can lead to degenerative changes and can cause aortic dissection and cerebrovascular hemorrhage.

The image below shows hyperplastic arteriosclerosis.

Monckeberg medial sclerosis is characterized by the calcification of the walls of muscular arteries, typically involving the internal elastic lamina. It occurs in people aged 50 years and above as a part of senile degeneration. It is usually an incidental finding. 

The following image shows Monckeberg medial sclerosis of an artery.

Atherosclerotic plaque is yellow-tan that is raised above the vessel wall. It occurs due to intimal thickening and lipid accumulation. The lumen appears irregular. The given image shows atherosclerosis:

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis of the computed tomography (CT) image provided below?
questions.solution:
The given image is a CT pulmonary angiography showing a pulmonary (saddle) embolism.

CT pulmonary angiography using multi-detector CT is the best investigation for pulmonary embolism. 

An embolus in the bifurcation of the main pulmonary artery is referred to as a saddle embolus. Pulmonary emboli (PE) originate from deep venous thromboses. Fragmented thrombi from DVTs are carried through progressively larger veins and the right side of the heart, before slamming into the pulmonary arterial vasculature.

Depending on the size of the embolus, it can occlude the main pulmonary artery; straddle the pulmonary artery bifurcation (saddle embolus); or pass out into the smaller, branching arteries.

The below image shows a CT thorax of saddle embolism.

Other options

Option A- Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is defined as an increase in vascular resistance of the pulmonary circulation involving a combination of vasoconstriction and remodeling of small vessels. Hemodynamically, it is defined as a systolic pulmonary artery pressure of more than 35 mmHg or a mean pulmonary artery pressure (mPAP) >20 mmHg

A diameter of the main pulmonary artery at the level of its bifurcation of more than 29 mm helps in the diagnosis of PH.

Option B- Thoracic aortic aneurysm occurs due to the intrinsic weakness of the aortic wall and they rarely manifest with symptoms. A CECT scan is the most widely used for diagnosis and it assesses the size, extent, and location of the aneurysm.

The below image shows a CT scan of a ruptured thoracic aortic aneurysm. The black arrow is the aorta and the white arrow is blood in the thorax.

Option D- The mural thrombus of the aorta is the thrombus attached to the wall of an aorta. They occur in the normal or minimally atherosclerotic vessel. The modality for diagnosis of mural thrombi is CT or MRI angiography.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant female patient presents with features of bilateral conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. She gives a similar history of hearing loss to her mother.  The otoscopic findings of her tympanic membranes are given below. The pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curves bilaterally. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is active otosclerosis.

The above clinical scenario of bilateral conductive deafness, tinnitus in a pregnant female, family history of similar deafness, pure tone audiometry showing a dip at 2000 Hz in bone conduction curves, and the otoscopic picture showing a reddish hue on the promontory through the tympanic membrane are suggestive of active otosclerosis.

The reddish hue seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane is called the Schwartze sign. This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. 

Otosclerosis is the primary disease of the bony labyrinth characterized by abnormal bone remodeling in which a normal dense endochondral layer of the bony otic capsule is replaced by one or more foci of irregularly laid spongy bone. It has a positive family history with an autosomal dominant trait. It is more commonly seen in females and the hearing loss is aggravated during pregnancy. It may be associated with osteogenesis imperfecta and a viral infection like measles. 

The types of otosclerosis include stapedial otosclerosis, cochlear otosclerosis, and histologic otosclerosis.

Patients present with a bilateral conductive type of hearing loss, tinnitus (commonly in cochlear type and active stage), paracusis Willisii (better hearing in a noisy surrounding than in a quiet place), vertigo, and a monotonous, well-modulated soft speech.

The tympanic membrane is quite normal and mobile. Eustachian tube function is also normal. Pure tone audiometry shows a dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curve known as the Carhart's notch. Tympanometry shows an As type of tympanogram in which there is reduced compliance at or near the ambient air pressure.

Treatment includes medical, surgical management, and hearing aids. Medical management with sodium fluoride is used in the active stage to hasten the maturity of the active focus and halt further cochlear loss. The treatment of choice is the surgical management that includes stapedotomy/stapedectomy with the placement of a prosthesis. Hearing aids are used in patients who are refuse or are unfit for the surgery.

Audiogram given below shows Cahart's notch seen in otosclerosis.

Other options:

Option A: Repeated exposure to loud sounds above 85 dB or single exposure to loud sounds above 120-155 dB such as explosions, gun-shots etc, can lead to noise-induced hearing loss. It results in bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and is caused by irreversible damage to the stereocilia of hair cells in the Organ of Corti. 

The patient presents with tinnitus and difficulty in hearing in a noisy environment. This condition is irreversible and is managed with hearing aids. The Rinne test is positive bilaterally.

Audiometry shows a typical notch at 4000 Hz. As the duration of noise exposure increases, the notch becomes deeper and wider involving lower and higher frequencies.

Option C: Glomus tumor is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear that arises from the glomus bodies. When the tumor is intratympanic, the hearing loss is a conductive type and a swishing, pulsatile tinnitus that is synchronous with the carotid pulse is heard. On otoscopic examination, a red reflex through the tympanic membrane is seen. This is known as the 'rising sun' appearance which occurs when the tumor arises from the floor of the middle ear. Brown's sign/Pulsation sign is also positive in which the tumor pulsates and then blanches on increasing the ear canal pressure using a Siegel's speculum.

Option D: Meniere's disease (endolymphatic hydrops) is an inner ear disorder where the endolymph distends the endolymphatic system. The disease is usually unilateral. It is characterized by episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sense of ear fullness. No abnormality is seen on otoscopic examination. Pure tone audiometry reveals a sensorineural type of hearing loss with lower frequencies affected first. It shows a rising type of curve.

questions.text: A known hypertensive presented with intermittent loin pain. His brother passed away two years ago due to a ruptured berry aneurysm. CT abdomen done is shown below. Which of the following is false regarding his condition?

choices.text: Caused by mutations in chromosomes 16 and 4
Can progress to end-stage renal disease

questions.solution:
The given scenario with CT showing multiple cysts in the kidneys and liver points to a diagnosis of adult polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). The predominant feature in patients with ADPKD is hypertension, not hypotension.

ADPKD is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait with mutations in the PKD1 (chromosome 16) and PKD2 genes (chromosome 4) (option B). The patients present with hypertension and flank pain. The cause of the pain is the infection of the renal cysts, hemorrhage or concomitant stone formation. Gross hematuria can also occur when the cyst ruptures. The most important causes of mortality in patients with ADPKD are cardiovascular complications due to hypertension, and infections of the cyst. The patients progress to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) by late middle age (option D). 

Manifestations of ADPKD in other organs include:

  • Cysts in liver, pancreas, spleen, and lungs
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms resulting in subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • Mitral valve prolapse (option C)
  • Colonic diverticulae 
  • Abdominal wall hernias

The diagnosis is made using typical clinical features, family history consistent with autosomal dominant inheritance, and the presence of multiple, bilateral cysts on imaging. Ultrasound is often used as the first-line investigation. CT and T2 weighted MRI are more sensitive than ultrasound in detecting smaller-sized cysts.

Treatment includes strict control of BP using blockers of RAAS, such as ACE inhibitors and angiotensin-receptor blockers. Tolvaptan (vasopressin antagonist), sirolimus, and everolimus (mTOR pathway inhibitors) have been shown to delay the progression of renal disease. More than half of the patients with ADPKD eventually require renal replacement therapy in the form of hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis, or renal transplant.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman presents with a triad of postprandial pain, weight loss and an abdominal bruit. A CT abdomen revealed that the median arcuate ligament is thickened and is lower than normal. A compression of which of the following vessels is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Compression of the celiac artery is responsible for this condition.

The clinical scenario describes median arcuate ligament syndrome (MALS) which is caused by the compression of the celiac artery.

It occurs as a result of abnormal anatomy due to which the median arcuate ligament lies significantly inferiorly, positioning itself anterior to the celiac artery. This causes compression and is characterized clinically by postprandial abdominal pain, vomiting, weight loss, and sometimes an abdominal bruit. A definitive diagnosis requires advanced vascular imaging.

Other options:

Option B: Inferior vena cava - compression of this vessel leads to venous hypertension or extensive lower extremity deep vein thrombosis. 

Option C: Superior mesenteric artery - Superior mesenteric artery syndrome is characterized by compression of the third portion of the duodenum due to narrowing of the space between the superior mesenteric artery and aorta and is primarily attributed to loss of the intervening mesenteric fat pad.

Option D: Left renal vein - compression of this vessel leads to nutcracker syndrome. The left renal vein is compressed between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric artery as if a nutcracker is crushing a nut (left renal vein). It leads to hematuria, left flank pain, and varicocele.

questions.text: A young man is arrested for rubbing his genitals against a female passenger to obtain sexual satisfaction in public transport. He is punishable under which section of the IPC/BNS?
questions.solution:
Obtaining sexual satisfaction by rubbing private parts against another person is known as frotteurism. This sexual offence is liable to punishment under Sec. 290 IPC (Sec 292 BNS) with a fine of up to 1000 rupees. 

They obtain sexual satisfaction through the action. It is generally done by rubbing against a female's breasts, buttocks, thighs, or genital areas in crowds. They feel that the touching behaviour will not offend and that the victims find it pleasurable. 

Other options:

Option A - Sec. 354-C IPC (Sec 77 BNS) deals with voyeurism. It is a sexual offence wherein the alleged offender (voyeur or peeping Tom) experiences sexual gratification by observing an unsuspecting person who is undressed and in the process of disrobing or engaging in sexual activity.

Option C - Sec. 294 IPC (Sec 296 BNS) deals with obscene acts like exhibitionism where they obtain sexual gratification with intentional exposure of one's genitals to an unsuspecting stranger. It is punishable by imprisonment up to three months or a fine. 

Option D - Sec. 297 IPC (Sec 301 BNS) deals with offences related to trespassing of burial places. Necrophilia and necrophagia are punishable under this IPC. Necrophilia is defined as the desire for sexual intercourse with a corpse and in necrophagia, the person drinks the blood and eats the flesh of the victim to derive sexual pleasure.  It is punished with imprisonment up to one year and or fine.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the emergency for the alleged consumption of an organophosphate compound. He is being treated with atropine and develops palpitations, blurring of vision, dryness of mouth, difficulty in speaking and swallowing, and difficulty in micturition. All of the following antihistamines can safely administered in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of a patient being treated with atropine developing palpitations, blurring or vision and dryness of mouth,  difficulty in speaking and swallowing, and difficulty in micturition are indicative of atropine toxicity. Promethazine should be avoided in this case.

Promethazine is a first-generation antihistamine that has the strongest antimuscarinic activity amongst all antihistamines and therefore can potentiate atropine toxicity. Therefore, it has to be avoided in this patient.

A few important symptoms of atropine toxicity are shown in the diagram below.

The predominant initial signs are of muscarinic excess which includes: (DUMBBELSS)

  • Diarrhea
  • Urination
  • Miosis
  • Bronchospasm
  • Bradycardia
  • Emesis
  • Lacrimation
  • Salivation
  • Sweating

Nicotinic manifestations include twitching of eyelids, tongue, and facial muscles which then leads to paralysis. CNS stimulation results in headaches, tremors, ataxia, coma, and death. 

Other options:

Options A, B, and D: Fexofenadine, loratadine, and levocetrizine are second-generation antihistamines with no anticholinergic activity and therefore can safely be used in this patient.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida who is a known diabetic, had a spontaneous miscarriage. The baby had the deformity as shown in the image below. Which of the following defects during embryonal development is likely to cause the given condition?

choices.text: Persistence of pluripotent cells in primitive streak
Defect in the development of notochord
Loss of cells in the anterior midline of the germ disc

questions.solution:
The condition shown in the above image is sirenomelia. It is caused due to insufficient formation of mesoderm in the caudal most region of the embryo.

The mesoderm in the caudal region is involved in the formation of lower limbs, urogenital system, and lumbosacral vertebrae. Therefore, the defects seen in this condition include hypoplasia and fusion of the lower limbs, vertebral abnormalities, renal agenesis, imperforate anus, and anomalies of the genital organs. 

During the third week of development, a process called gastrulation occurs which leads to the formation of all three germ layers. The process begins with the formation of the primitive streak, which develops into the primitive node and primitive pit. The primitive pit further invaginates and organizes itself into cells arranged in three layers, which eventually develop into ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm.

Gastrulation related abnormalities:

Sacrococcygeal teratomas occur due to remnants of pluripotent cells from the primitive streak. They are the most common tumor in newborns, occurring at a frequency of 1 in 37,000 births. Sacrococcygeal teratomas contain tissues derived from all three germ layers. When pluripotent cells from the primitive streak remain in the sacrococcygeal region, they proliferate to form sacrococcygeal teratomas.

Holoprosencephaly is a deficiency in the midline craniofacial structures. It occurs due to teratogenic exposure (such as high alcohol dose) during gastrulation which kills the cells in the anterior midline of the embryonic disc. In holoprosencephaly, the forebrain is small, the two lateral ventricles are often merged into a single ventricle, and the eyes are close together (hypotelorism).

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient has been diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma of the left kidney. A CECT abdomen and pelvis showed the presence of a tumor that is 10 cm in its largest dimension. It is limited to the kidney with intact Gerota's fascia. No regional lymph nodes, veins, or adrenal gland are involved. The findings are indicative of the tumor being:
questions.solution:
The findings are characteristic of a stage II tumour.

The staging of renal cell carcinoma is based on size, position and lymph node involvement. The stages and the features of each stage are given below.

Stage of RCC Features 
Stage I Tumour <7 cm in the largest dimension, limited to the kidney
Stage II Tumour >7 cm in the largest dimension, limited to the kidney
Stage III Tumour in the major veins, or adrenal gland with intact Gerota’s fascia, or regional lymph nodes involved
Stage IV Tumour beyond Gerota's fascia

 

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) arises from the epithelium of the proximal convoluted tubule and is frequently detected coincidentally. It has a male preponderance.

There are six major subtypes which are clear-cell, papillary, chromophobe, MiT family translocation, collecting duct, and medullary type.

The classic triad of loin pain, loin mass, and haematuria is seen in <10% of patients with renal tumors. Rather, the majority of diagnoses result from incidental findings during procedures like CT imaging, performed for other reasons.

Major risk factors for RCC include age, sex, obesity, hypertension, and cigarette smoking. Other medical conditions associated with RCC include chronic kidney disease, hemodialysis, kidney transplantation, and acquired cystic disease of the kidney (ACDK).

Genetic factors also contribute to an increased risk of RCC, evidenced by individuals with a family history of renal cancer having an approximately twofold increased risk. The most common symptoms associated with paraneoplastic syndromes are hypercalcemia, fever, and erythrocytosis.

Surgeries done for RCC include:

  • Partial nephrectomy, the goal of which is to completely remove the primary tumor while preserving the largest possible amount of healthy renal parenchyma. It is used for renal tumors <7cm in size.
  • Classic radical nephrectomy involves removal of the kidney, perirenal fat, adrenal gland, and regional lymph nodes.

There also exist targeted therapies for RCC which include tyrosine kinase inhibitors like sorafenib, sunitinib, and lenvatinib, anti-VEGF monoclonal antibodies like bevacizumab, and mTOR inhibitors like everolimus and temsirolimus. The average duration of disease control with these agents is 8–9 months.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presented with abdominal distention and increased irritability for 10 days. Physical examination showed jaundice, hepatomegaly, and a boiled cabbage odor. Investigations were notable for elevated transaminases and succinylacetone. What is the likely enzyme deficiency in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of type 1 tyrosinemia (tyrosinosis). It is caused by a deficiency of fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase enzyme.

Type 1 tyrosinemia usually present between 2-6 months of age with acute liver failure. They may also present with peripheral neuropathy resembling acute porphyria. Renal involvement is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia, hypophosphatemia, and vitamin D-resistant rickets.

An odor resembling boiled cabbage resulting from increased methionine metabolites can be noted. Elevated levels of succinylacetone in blood or urine are diagnostic of type 1 tyrosinemia.

It is treated by a combination of nitisinone and dietary restriction of phenylalanine and tyrosine.

There are three types of tyrosinemias:

  • Type 1 (Hepatorenal tyrosinemia): Fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase deficiency
  • Type 2 (Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia/ Richner-Hanhart syndrome): Tyrosine transaminase deficiency
  • Type 3 (Neonatal tyrosinemia)

Other options:

Option A: Deficiency of ornithine transcarbamoylase causes hyperammonemia type 2.

Option B: Deficiency of tyrosine transaminase (also known as tyrosine aminotransferase) causes type 2 tyrosinemia.

Option C: Deficiency of carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I (CPS1) causes hyperammonemia type 1. 

Note: A boiled cabbage odor can also occur in hypermethioninemia.

questions.text: The maximum amount of air that can be expelled from the lungs after first filling the lungs to their maximum extent and then expiring to the maximum extent is equal to ____.
questions.solution:
The maximum amount of air that can be expelled from the lungs after first filling the lungs to their maximum extent and then expiring to the maximum extent is equal to the vital capacity of the lungs.

The vital capacity is the sum of inspiratory reserve volume, tidal volume, and expiratory reserve volume. It is around 4600 mL.

Option A: Functional residual capacity is the sum of expiratory reserve volume and residual volume, and it is the total amount of air remaining in the lungs after normal expiration. It is about 2300 mL.

Option B: The total lung capacity is the maximum volume to which lungs can be expanded with the greatest effort. It is the sum of vital capacity and the residual volume and is about 5800 mL.

Option D: The inspiratory capacity is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level and is about 3500 mL.

questions.text: A child with a grazed knee comes to your clinic for first aid. He has a history of nephrotic syndrome and is on oral prednisolone therapy. Which stage of wound healing would be most affected by his medication?
questions.solution:
While all of the given options are inhibited by steroids, the major effect of steroids is to inhibit the initial inflammatory phase of wound healing (angiogenesis, neutrophil and macrophage migration, and fibroblast proliferation) and the release of lysosomal enzymes.

The stronger the anti-inflammatory effect of the steroid compound used, the greater the inhibitory effect on wound healing. Steroids used after the first 3 to 4 days post-injury do not affect wound healing as severely as when they are used in the immediate postoperative period. 

In addition to inhibiting collagen synthesis, steroids also inhibit epithelialization and contraction and contribute to increased rates of wound infection, regardless of the time of administration.

Steroid delayed healing of cutaneous wounds can be stimulated to epithelialize by topical application of vitamin A.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man from West Bengal presents with recurrent fever with chills for the past 3 months with progressive weakness and abdominal discomfort. On examination, he has hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow aspiration finding is shown in the image below. Which of the following skin tests can be used to know the prior exposure to this parasite?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 20-year-old man presenting with fever with chills, progressive weakness, and abdominal discomfort for the past 3 months and the bone marrow aspirate showing Leishman-Donovan bodies are suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis. A positive Montenegro skin test indicates prior exposure to the leishmanial parasite.

Leishmaniasis is a slowly progressing indigenous disease caused by a protozoan parasite of the genus Leishmania. It is transmitted by the bite of an infected female Phlebotomus sandfly, which inoculates the flagellated promastigotes into the skin of the host in developing countries. In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh.

Causative organisms include:

  • Old world leishmaniasis: Leishmania donovani, Leishmania major, and Leishmania tropica
  • New world leishmaniasis: Leishmania mexicana complex and Leishmania braziliensis complex

The image given below shows a phlebotomus sandfly.

The image below shows Lutzomyia sandfly responsible for the New World cutaneous leishmanisis.

In human beings, the disease presents in four different forms with a broad range of clinical manifestations:

  • Visceral leishmaniasis/ kala-azar
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis
  • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis
  • Diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis

The life cycle of Leishmania involves two forms:

  • The promastigote develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector and
  • The amastigote multiplies intracellularly in the reticuloendothelial cells of the host.  

When the infected sandfly bites a person, infectious promastigotes are released into the host dermis along with the sandfly's saliva, which potentiates parasite infectivity. Amastigote form (as shown in the image below) is also known as the Leishman-Donovan (LD) body. It is an intracellular form found inside macrophages, monocytes, and reticuloendothelial cells. It contains a kinetoplast, which consists of a parabasal body and a blepharoplast. Flagellum is absent.

Promastigote form (as shown in the below image) is present in the midgut of the female sandfly. The kinetoplast lies transversely near the anterior end. A single flagellum is seen. It is the infective form of L. donovani for humans.

Given below is the lifecycle of L. donovanii.

This condition causes fever with rigor and chills associated with splenomegaly and hepatomegaly. It lowers immunity and causes persistent fever, anaemia, leucopenia, and thrombocytopenia, if left untreated, death may occur due to opportunistic infection.

Diagnosis of kala-azar is mainly by demonstration of amastigotes within macrophages in tissue aspirates such as blood smears, bone marrow, splenic, or lymph node aspirate. It is the gold standard for diagnosis.

The image below shows amastigotes located intracellularly within macrophages.

Tests to detect leishmaniasis include:

  • Rapid diagnostic test: rK39 Rapid diagnostic test and Kala-azar dipstick test strip. This is recommended by the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP) in India.
  • Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of LD bodies in buffy coat smear - confirmatory.
  • Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.
  • Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELISA, indirect fluorescent antibody test
  • Leishmanin (Montenegro) test: A skin test, 0.1 ml of killed promastigote suspension is injected intradermally on the dorsoventral aspect of foremarmInduration of 5mm or more is considered positive and indicates prior exposure to the leishmanial parasite. In active kala azar, this test is negative and becomes positive after 6-8 weeks (delayed hypersensitivity) after a cure from the disease or if the patient developed protective immunity.

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are

  • Sodium stibogluconate - Drug of choice in countries where strains are sensitive to antimony compounds.
  • Miltefosine - Alternative to sodium stibogluconate and only oral drug used in Kala-azar.
  • Amphotericin B - Drug of choice in India, as 40-60% of strains are resistant to antimony compounds. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10 mg/kg IV is the first line of treatment in India, 

Other options:  

Option A: Frenkel's test is done in toxoplasmosis.

Option C: Fairley's test is done in schistosomiasis.

Option D: Bachman intradermal test done in trichinellosis.

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.
