questions.text:
A diabetic woman who is on metformin presented with abdominal pain and diarrhea. On evaluation, her blood sugar levels are within normal limits. Her arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis report is given below. What is the most likely cause for her ABG findings?
  • pH - 7.24
  • HCO3 - 16 mEq/L
  • PaCO2- 35 mmHg
  • Sodium levels - 130 mEq/L
  • Chloride levels - 94 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The most likely cause for the above ABG findings is lactic acidosis.

This patient has high anion gap metabolic acidosis. This is most probably due to lactic acidosis due to the history of metformin treatment.

Inference from the given question stem:

Step 1: pH in this patient is 7.24, which indicates acidosis. (normal range: 7.35-7.45)

Step 2: Bicarbonate level in this patient is 16 mEq/L, which is decreased. This signifies the deficiency of the base. Hence, this is metabolic acidosis. (normal range: 22-26 mmHg)

Step 3: PaCO2 level in this patient is 35 mmHg, which is normal. (normal range 35-45 mmHg)

Step 4: Anion gap calculation:

Anion gap = Na+ - (Cl-+HCO3-)

=130 - (94+16)

=20, which is a high anion gap

Other causes of high anion gap metabolic acidosis:

  • Lactic acidosis
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Ethanol poisoning
  • Salicylate poisoning
  • Methanol poisoning 
  • Renal failure
  • Propylene glycol poisoning

Other options:

Option A- Diabetic ketoacidosis results in high anion gap metabolic acidosis associated with elevated levels of ketone bodies and hyperglycemia (serum glucose level >17 mmol/L or 300 mg/dL). This cannot be the cause in this patient as the serum glucose levels are within normal limits.

Options C and D- Diarrhea and renal tubular acidosis type 1 results in normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A full-term primigravida has asked for epidural labor analgesia at the first stage of labor. Which of the following local anesthetic is commonly used to provide sensory blockade along with fentanyl?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used local anesthetic to provide sensory blockade along with fentanyl is bupivacaine. In concentrations of 0.0625% - 0.125%, bupivacaine is used in epidural labor analgesia to provide maximum sensory blockade with a minimum motor blockade.

Lumbar epidural analgesia is the mainstay of pain relief during the early stages of labor. Epidural analgesia is usually performed between L2-L3 and L4-L5 since the spinal cord typically terminates at the L1 level. An appropriate labor analgesic should provide a sensory blockade without motor blockade or other maternal or fetal effects.

The doses of local anesthetics can be reduced by combining them with opioids like fentanyl or sufentanil. The lesser concentration of local anesthetic used leads to greater preservation of motor function and makes ambulation of the patient possible (walking or mobile epidural). Moreover, by reducing the concentration of the drugs, adverse effects like hypotension and drug toxicity are minimized.

Concentrations used for epidural:

The dose of opioid used:

  • Fentanyl : 2–3 mcg/mL 
  • Sufentanil: 0.3–0.5 mcg/mL

Ropivacaine (0.0625% - 0.2%) is the other commonly used local anesthetic for epidural analgesia and is the preferred one due to reduced cardiotoxicity as with bupivacaine.

Procaine, tetracaine, and mepivacaine are not commonly used for epidural labor analgesia.

Other options:

Option A: Chloroprocaine is a chlorinated derivative of procaine, used in spinal anesthesia for ambulatory surgeries.

Option C: Tetracaine is used in topical anesthetic preparations. It is also used in spinal anesthesia when a longer duration of action is needed

 Option D: Mepivacaine has a longer duration of action when compared with lidocaine. It leads to transient neurological symptoms, hence the use of the drug is reduced.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male patient with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension comes for a routine examination. He is on ramipril for hypertension and metformin for diabetes. On evaluation, he is found to have hyperkalemia and acidemia. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

RTA- Renal tubular acidosis
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is RTA type IV.

The above clinical features of diabetes, angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ramipril), hyperkalemia, and acidemia are suggestive of type IV renal tubular acidosis. 

Type IV renal tubular acidosis (hyporeninemic hypoaldosteronism) occurs in type 1 or 2 diabetes mellitus. It is more commonly seen in diabetic nephropathy-induced destruction of juxtaglomerular apparatus, drugs like ACEI/ARBs, potassium-sparing diuretics, calcineurin inhibitors, NSAIDs, and heparin.

The clinical features seen in Type IV RTA are as follows:

  • Hyperkalemia: Hypoaldosteronism results in an increase in potassium concentration. 
  • Metabolic acidosis: The important buffers in urine are ammonia and phosphate. Hyperkalemia impairs ammonia production in the proximal tubule, which reduces the buffering of hydrogen ions. This results in decreased hydrogen ion excretion. 
  • Urinary pH<5.5: Due to the decreased production of ammonia in the proximal tubule, excess protons are excreted in the renal tubules, thus decreasing the urinary pH.

Other options:

Option A- RTA type I (distal RTA) is seen in autoimmune diseases like Sjogren's syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, medullary sponge kidney disease, cirrhosis, drugs like amphotericin B, lithium, etc. The patients develop hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis with alkaline urine (urinary pH >5.5). 

Option B- RTA type II (proximal RTA) is seen in Fanconi syndrome, Wilson's disease, heavy metals ingestion, etc., The patients develop hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis with acidic urine (urinary pH <5.5). There is also the excretion of glucose, urate, and amino acids.

Option C- RTA type III (mixed RTA) is seen in inherited mutations of carbonic anhydrase II. A combined pathology of type I and type II RTA is seen in this type. It results in hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A young man presented with severe muscle weakness and drooping of eyelids. The symptoms worsen with repetitive movements but resolve after rest. Chest X-ray revealed an anterior mediastinal mass. Biopsy of this mass would most likely reveal which of the following pathologic changes?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of myasthenia gravis. It is associated with thymic hyperplasia.

Myasthenia gravis is an acquired autoimmune disease characterized by abnormal muscular fatigability that typically worsens with exertion and towards the end of the day. It most commonly involves the extraocular muscles causing diplopia and ptosis.

It is caused due to circulating autoantibodies against the acetylcholine receptor at the myoneural junction. In about 30% of the patients, thymic hyperplasia is closely associated with myasthenia gravis, and about 10% have thymoma. 

The thymus normally contains small numbers of myoid cells, stromal cells that express skeletal muscle antigens. In both thymoma and thymic hyperplasia, the normal thymic function is disrupted leading to autoimmunity against ACh receptors expressed on thymic myoid cells. 

Thymectomy is often an effective treatment for these patients.

Related Pearl: Auto antibodies in a few disorders

Auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis:

i) Anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies

ii) Anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies

iii) Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4) antibodies

Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). 

Anti-Smith antibodies (Anti-Sm) are associated with SLE.

Anti-lysosome associated membrane protein-2 (LAMP-2) antibodies are associated with certain types of vasculitis.

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida visits your clinic for a regular antenatal check-up at 37 weeks of gestation. You perform the following grip by standing near the head end of the mother while facing her feet. What is this grip known as?
questions.solution:
The obstetric grip shown in the picture is the Fourth Leopold maneuver (also known as pelvic grip).

Pelvic grip (fourth Leopold) assesses the engagement, and attitude of the fetal head and determines the degree of descent. The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part. They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet. It is the only grip performed facing the feet.

The fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of fetal head are assessed by Leopold's maneuvers:

First Leopold (Fundal grip ):

  • Performed by facing the patient’s face
  • Assesses the uterine fundus.
  • Helps in identification of fetal lie and determination of fetal pole at the fundus.
  • The breech gives the sensation of a large, irregular mass. 
  • The head feels hard and round and is more mobile.

Second Leopold (Lateral grip): 

  • Performed by facing the patient’s face
  • Assesses fetal orientation.
  • The palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is exerted.
  • The back is felt on one side as a hard, resistant structure.
  • The fetal extremities are felt on the other side as numerous small, irregular, mobile parts are felt.
  • Fetal orientation can be determined by noting whether the back is directed anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly.
  • The position of the anterior shoulder is mainly assessed by this grip.

Pawlik's grip (third Leopold):

  • Performed by facing the patient’s face.
  • Assesses the presenting part with respect to the true pelvis.
  • The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis.
  • If the presenting part is not engaged it can be grasped distinctly.

questions.text: The method of asphyxia shown in the given image is ______
questions.solution:
The given image is characteristic of mugging where strangulation is caused by holding the neck of the victim in the bend of the elbow.

In this case, the pressure is put upon the neck by the arm held around the throat. The attack is usually made from behind, with the neck being trapped in the crook of the elbow and pressure exerted when the front and sides of the larynx. 

A diffuse abrasion is seen along the margin of the jaw due to the friction of the forearm. Death can occur due to asphyxia or reflex cardiac arrest

Other options:

Option A: Garrotting involves attacking the victim from behind using a ligature. The ligature is thrown around the unaware victim’s neck and then tightened with the help of two sticks tied at the free ends of the string. Earlier in Spain, garroting was also an official method of execution of criminals.

An image of the execution of a prisoner by garroting is shown below

Option B: Throttling or manual strangulation is defined as compression and strangulation with bare hands. 

Effects of pressure on the neck due to manual strangulation are:

  • Carotid artery blockage resulting in loss of consciousness
  • Carotid sinus pressure causing vagus nerve stimulation and cardiac arrest
  • Airway blockages causing hypoxemia 

The given autopsy images showing carotid intimal tear and muscle hematoma with nail marks on the neck and absence of ligature mark point towards a diagnosis of throttling.

Option D: Smothering is defined as a form of asphyxia where the external respiratory orifices are closed either by the hand or by other means or blocking up the cavities of the nose and mouth by the introduction of a foreign substance.

The image shows smothering, which involves the blockage of the external air passages, usually by a hand or soft fabric/pillow.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man diagnosed with type-2 diabetes mellitus is being treated with metformin for the last 5 years. The deficiency of which of the following vitamins would be most likely in this patient?
questions.solution:
A vitamin B12 deficiency is most likely in this patient.

Metformin interferes with the calcium-dependent absorption of vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex in the terminal ileum. In addition, it is also proposed to cause alterations in small bowel motility which stimulates bacterial overgrowth and consequential vitamin B12 deficiency, competitive inhibition or inactivation of vitamin B12 absorption, alterations in intrinsic factor (IF) levels and interaction with the cubulin endocytic receptor. As a result, vitamin B12 deficiency can occur.

Decrease in vitamin B12 absorption and levels following metformin use generally begins around the 4th month but clinically observable features of vitamin B12 deficiency manifest by 5–10 years owing to the large body stores in the liver mainly that are not quickly depleted. Additionally, the risk of developing metformin associated vitamin B12 deficiency is greatly influenced by increasing age, metformin dose and duration of use.

Therefore, periodic screening for vitamin B12 deficiency should be considered, especially in patients with peripheral neuropathy or macrocytic anemia. Also, this effect can be reversed with calcium supplementation.

questions.text: What is the name of the procedure depicted below?
questions.solution:
The Kasai procedure, or Roux-en-Y hepato-portoenterostomy, is shown in the above image.

It is done for all types of extrahepatic biliary atresia. It involves the excision of all extrahepatic bile duct remnants up to the liver capsule and the gallbladder. Following this, a Roux-en-Y loop of jejunum is mobilized and anastomosed to the exposed area of the liver capsule above the bifurcation of the portal vein creating a portoenterostomy.

Extrahepatic biliary atresia is a rare disease of neonates characterized by the inflammation and obliteration of extrahepatic bile ducts. The incidence is estimated to be 1 in 5000 to 12,000 infants and the disease is progressive. It may be associated with other congenital malformations, such as splenic abnormalities like asplenia, absence of the inferior vena cava, and intestinal malformation.

Histopathology shows significant extrahepatic biliary obstruction with portal tract fibrosis, inflammatory cell infiltration, bile duct proliferation, and cholestasis with bile plugging.

The disease is classified according to the level of the most proximal biliary obstruction:

  • Type 1 biliary atresia has patency to the level of the common bile duct (CBD)
  • Type 2 biliary atresia has patency to the level of the common hepatic duct
  • Type 3, which accounts for a majority of the cases, occurs when the left and right hepatic ducts, at the level of the porta hepatis, are involved. 

Infants have symptoms of jaundice, pale stools, and dark urine right after birth. In advanced disease, infants present with failure to thrive, hepatomegaly, and ascites due to liver cirrhosis. If jaundice persists after 14 days of life in a term infant, the liver function needs to be assessed by determining direct or conjugated bilirubin levels, which will be elevated to more than 2.0 mg/dL in those with liver involvement. Other investigations to be done include serology for toxoplasmosis, rubella, cytomegalovirus, and herpes (TORCH) and hepatitis B and C infections, α1-antitrypsin levels, and cystic fibrosis. Metabolic disorders, such as galactosemia and tyrosinemia, and endocrine abnormalities must also be ruled out.

Liver biopsy is the gold standard for the diagnosis of biliary atresia.

Other options:

Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is used as bariatric surgery where a small proximal gastric pouch is created at the lesser curvature of the stomach and a roux limb of 75–150 cm (jejunum) is created by anastomosing the proximal jejunum to the gastric pouch and, a shorter biliary/biliopancreatic limb of 30–50 cm (consisting duodenum and proximal jejunum) is anastomosed to the roux limb via side to side jejunojejunostomy.

Option C: Billroth II loop gastrojejunostomy Here, two-thirds of the stomach is removed, the duodenal stump is closed and the stomach is anastomosed to the jejunum. It helps to re-establish gastrointestinal continuity following antrectomy for complicated peptic ulcer disease.

Option D: Whipple procedure, also known as pancreaticoduodenectomy, can be performed either with the standard technique, which includes distal gastrectomy or with the preservation of pylorus. It is performed in familial adenomatous polyposis, carcinoma head of pancreas, etc.

questions.text: A 27-year-old pregnant woman presents with a five-day history of fever, malaise, and symptoms of urinary frequency, urgency, and dysuria. She also reports pain in the costovertebral angle but has no history of similar episodes. Urinalysis reveals the presence of pus casts. All of the following statements about her condition are true except:
questions.solution:
The clinical stem suggests acute pyelonephritis. Thyroidization of tubules is a feature of chronic pyelonephritis not acute.

Points that favor the diagnosis of acute pyelonephritis are:

  • systemic symptoms like fever and malaise for the past 5 days
  • increased urinary frequency, urgency, and dysuria
  • pain in the costovertebral angle
  • urine routine showing pus casts 

Suppurative inflammation of the kidney caused by a bacterial and viral infection, which can reach the kidney by hematogenous spread or, more commonly, through the ureters in association with vesicoureteral reflux is known as acute pyelonephritis.

Acute pyelonephritis is associated with urinary tract obstruction (congenital or acquired), instrumentation of the urinary tract (catheterization), vesicoureteral reflux, pregnancy, diabetes, preexisting renal lesions, and immunosuppression. Infections are much more frequent in females. However, with increasing age, the incidence in males rises as a result of prostatic hypertrophy.

Histopathological features of acute pyelonephritis are patchy interstitial suppurative inflammation, intratubular aggregates of neutrophils, neutrophilic tubulitis, and tubular injury.

Complications of acute pyelonephritis:

  • Papillary necrosis- is mainly seen in diabetics, sickle cell disease, and urinary tract obstruction. It is usually bilateral. Areas of grey-white to yellow necrosis are seen at the tips or distal two-thirds of the pyramids. The necrotic tissue shows characteristic ischemic coagulative necrosis, with preservation of outlines of tubules
  • Pyonephrosis occurs when the suppurative exudate is unable to drain and fills the renal pelvis, calyces, and ureter with pus. This is seen when there is total or almost complete obstruction of the renal pelvis. 
  • Perinephric abscess is an extension of suppurative inflammation into the perinephric tissue.

Treatment: Uncomplicated acute pyelonephritis is mild, and symptoms disappear within a few days after appropriate antibiotic therapy is initiated.

Chronic pyelonephritis is a disorder in which there is chronic tubulointerstitial inflammation and scarring of the calyces and pelvis. Patients have a silent onset or present with manifestations of acute recurrent pyelonephritis, such as back pain, fever, pyuria, and bacteriuria. The hallmarks features include coarse, discrete, corticomedullary scars overlying dilated, blunted, or deformed calyces, and flattening of the papillae.

The microscopic changes involve predominantly tubules and interstitium. The tubules show atrophy and hypertrophy or dilation. Dilated tubules with flattened epithelium may be filled with casts resembling thyroid colloid (thyroidization).

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida came for her first ultrasound in the late first trimester period.  Two images of her ultrasound scan are given below and laboratory examination shows raised alfa fetoprotein (AFP). What can be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a primigravida with elevated AFP and a late first-trimester scan showing shower cap sign and open calvarium is suggestive of anencephaly. 

Anencephaly is characterized by the absence of cranium and telencephalic structures above the skull base and orbits with normal facial portions. Its incidence is 1 in 1000. Anencephaly and spina bifida are common in the first birth while the incidence of other malformations is high with increasing parity. 

The below image shows the shower cap sign and open calvarium in anencephaly. 

Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". Anencephaly is a severe defect and is not compatible with survival. The images are given below show open calvaria on antenatal ultrasound and frog-eye sign.

Option B- Intrauterine death is defined as the antepartum death occurring beyond the period of viability. Due to the liquefaction of brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, irregular overlapping of cranial bone termed spalding sign occurs. It appears 7 days after death. 

The image below shows the spalding sign.

Option C- Spina bifida is a congenital anomaly occurring due to incomplete development of the neural tube. It is divided into two:

  • spina bifida occulta
  • spina bifida aperta

The most commonly cited signs present in spina bifida are the banana sign and lemon sign.

The banana sign is the curved cerebellum due to its downward displacement that leads to Arnold-Chiari II malformation as shown below.

The lemon sign occurs due to the overlapping of the frontal bones due to the posterior shift of intracranial contents as shown below.

Option D- Omphalocele is a congenital midline anterior abdominal wall defect through which the solid abdominal viscera or bowel herniate. The herniated abdominal contents are covered by a membranous sac as shown below.

 The image below shows an ultrasound image of the fetus suggestive of an omphalocele (asterix).

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text:
A middle-aged man presented with hemoptysis and reduced urine output. There is no history of asthma or upper airway disease. On evaluation, he is found to be positive for p-ANCA. Renal biopsy showed non-granulomatous inflammation, with segmental fibrinoid necrosis. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

p-ANCA - perinuclear antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is microscopic polyangiitis.

The above clinical scenario of hemoptysis, reduced urine output, positive p-ANCA antibody, and biopsy showing non-granulomatous inflammation with segmental fibrinoid necrosis is suggestive of microscopic polyangiitis.

Microscopic polyangiitis is characterized by necrotizing vasculitis with few or no immune complexes affecting the small vessels (capillaries, venules, and arterioles). It may have a gradual or acute onset associated with fever, weight loss, and musculoskeletal pain. Renal involvement results in glomerulonephritis which results in renal failure. Hemoptysis occurs due to alveolar hemorrhage.

Laboratory investigations show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, anemia, leukocytosis, and thrombocytopenia. Most cases are associated with positive p-ANCA antibodies. Tissue biopsy would reveal non-granulomatous inflammation with segmental fibrinoid necrosis. 

Other options:

Option A: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is necrotizing arteritis of the medium and small-sized blood vessels. It can affect the skin, peripheral nerves, renal vessels, mesenteric vessels, heart, and brain. Lungs are usually spared in PAN. The disease initially starts with non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, arthralgia, and myalgia. Later, depending on the artery involved, patients may develop the following symptoms:

  • Skin findings - ulcers, digital gangrene, subcutaneous nodules, and livedo reticularis
  • Renal arteries - hypertension and renal failure
  • Mesenteric arteries - abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bleeding, and a bowel perforation

Patients with PAN do not show p-ANCA and c-ANCA positivity. Tissue biopsy reveals segmental transmural necrotizing inflammation associated with luminal thrombosis.

Options B: Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by asthma, peripheral and tissue eosinophilia, extravascular granuloma formation, and vasculitis of multiple organs. The clinical features include non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss. The pulmonary findings are characterized by severe asthmatic attacks and pulmonary infiltrates. Renal disease is less common in these patients. These patients show p-ANCA positivity.

Option D: Wegener's granulomatosis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by granulomatous vasculitis of the upper and lower respiratory tract with glomerulonephritis. The clinical features include bloody nasal discharge, nasal septal perforation, serous otitis media, hemoptysis, dyspnea, and glomerulonephritis which may lead to rapidly progressive renal failure. These patients show c-ANCA positivity. Tissue biopsy reveals granulomas with geographic patterns of central necrosis and accompanying vasculitis.

questions.text:
Match the tumour markers with their respective tumour types.
Section A Section B
1. Calcitonin A. Prostate cancer
2. Prostate-specific antigen               B. Choriocarcinoma
3. Beta-hCG C. Medullary carcinoma of Thyroid
4. CA-125 D. Epithelial ovarian cancer

CA - Cancer antigen 

hCG - Human chorionic gonadotropin
questions.solution:
Option B represents the correct answer.

In the given question, tumour markers given in section A need to be matched with their respective tumours in section B

Tumour marker Tumour types
1. Calcitonin C. Medullary carcinoma of Thyroid
2. Prostate-specific antigen  A. Prostate cancer
3. Beta-hCG B. Choriocarcinoma
4. CA-125 D. Epithelial ovarian cancer

Medullary carcinomas of the thyroid are neuroendocrine tumors arising from the parafollicular cells (C cells). Like normal C cells, these neoplasms secrete calcitonin. Measurement of this marker plays an important role in the diagnosis and follow-up of patients.

Prostate cancer is associated with elevated levels of prostate-specific antigen. Its levels can be used, after treatment, to monitor the recurrence and disease progression.

Choriocarcinoma is the neoplasm of trophoblastic cells. It secretes large quantities of hCG hormone, which is used as a tumor marker in the diagnosis and management of the tumor. 

CA-125 is used to monitor disease progression and recurrence of epithelial ovarian cancers.

questions.text: You were posted for an autopsy of a 32-year-old man who was murdered by a serial killer. On examination, a fracture caused by a blow with a hammer was found in the skull as shown below. What is the type of fracture called?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image given above are suggestive of a depressed fracture.

A depressed fracture is caused by blows from a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. It is also called a signature fracture as the pattern of fracture resembles the weapon or object used. 

Closer examination of the injury will reveal that the outer table is driven into the diploe, and the inner table has irregular fractures or may be comminuted. 

The depth of the fracture varies according to the velocity with which the impact is delivered. When a hammer is used, the fracture is circular or in the shape of an arc of a circle. The diameter of the fracture is the same as the striking surface. There are generally no radiating linear fractures. 

Other options:

Option A - Comminuted fractures are caused by a greater intensity force striking over a broad area such as crushing head injuries, repeated blows by weapons with a large striking area, or falling from height. In a comminuted fracture, there will be two or more intersecting lines of fracture which divide the bone into three or more fragments. 

Option B - Pond fracture is also known as an indented fracture. This is a dent in the skull. They are caused by an obstetric forceps blade, a blow from a blunt object, etc. They occur only in the infant skulls.

Option C - Gutter fractures occur mainly in oblique bullet wounds as it removes a part of the thickness of the bone.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child presents with a history of morning headaches, vomiting, and lethargy for the past 6 months.  MRI scan showed a contrast-enhancing nodule in the cerebellum. Biopsy findings of the tumor are shown in the image. The tumors were positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A clinical scenario of a child presenting with symptoms of increased intra- cranial tension with an image that shows Rosenthal fibers is suggestive of pilocytic astrocytoma.

Pilocytic astrocytoma is a brain tumor that occurs more often in children and young adults. These tumors are usually slow-growing and benign. The majority of neoplasms are located in the cerebellum. However, they can also appear around the third ventricle, optic nerves, spinal cord, and occasionally in the cerebral hemispheres.

On brain MRI, it can be identified as a contrast-enhancing nodule. On microscopy, it has very limited brain invasion compared to infiltrative astrocytomas. The tumor is made up of bipolar cells with hair-like projections forming a dense fibrillary meshwork. These cells are positive for glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP). The characteristic features of this tumor are the presence of Rosenthal fibers and eosinophilic granular bodies. A Rosenthal fiber is a corkscrew-shaped eosinophilic inclusion while eosinophilic granular bodies are mulberry-shaped inclusions.

In low-grade astrocytoma, surgical resection is the primary treatment modality, and in the high-grade lesions, after surgical correction, local irradiation is also done.

The below image shows pilocytic astrocytoma with Rosenthal fibers (arrows) and dense fibrillary meshwork.

Other options:

Option A- Ependymomas are the tumors that arise from the ependyma-lined ventricular system. The tumor cells have fibrillary processes and form gland-like round or elongated structures (rosettes and canals) that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal.

Option C- Medulloblastoma is a WHO grade IV aggressive tumor arising from the cerebellum. The tumor cells form Homer Wright rosettes.

Option D- Oligodendroglioma is composed of tumor cells that resemble oligodendrocytes. The tumor contains sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin, surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. This gives them fried egg appearance. They contain a network of anastomosing capillaries, resembling chicken wire and also have calcifications.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presented to the casualty holding his right limb close to his chest. He gives a history of falling on his hand from the bike. His vitals are stable. On examination, the arm is abducted, externally rotated and the lateral outline of the shoulder is flattened. X-ray of his shoulder is as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is an anterior shoulder dislocation.

The above clinical features of fall on the hands, the attitude of the arm, flattened lateral outline of the shoulder, and the radiograph showing the humeral head lying below and medial to the glenoid socket is suggestive of anterior shoulder dislocation.

The most common joint to dislocate is the shoulder joint. This is due to the shallowness of the glenoid socket, increased range of motion, underlying conditions like ligamentous laxity or glenoidal dysplasia, and vulnerability of the joint under stressful activities.

Anterior dislocation is the most common among shoulder dislocations. It occurs due to a fall on the hands. The head of the humerus is driven forwards and tears the capsule resulting in an avulsion in the glenoid labrum (Bankart lesion). Sometimes, the posterolateral part of the head of the humerus is crushed resulting in the Hill-Sachs lesion.

The clinical features include severe pain and the patient usually supports his dislocated arm with the opposite arm. On examination, the arm is usually abducted, externally rotated and the lateral outline of the shoulder may be straightened and sometimes a prominent acromion process or a bulge below the clavicle may be appreciated.

The anteroposterior radiograph shows the humeral head lying below and medial to the glenoid socket. It may also show the Bankart lesion and the Hill-Sachs lesion.

Below is the image of a radiograph showing Bankart lesion and Hill-Sachs lesion.

Other options:

Option A- Posterior shoulder dislocation is rare accounting for 2-4% of shoulder dislocations. It occurs due to axial loading on the adducted, internally rotated arm. It can also occur as a result of violent muscle contraction due to seizures or electrocution. The arm is adducted and internally rotated. An anteroposterior view radiograph of the shoulder shows an electric light bulb sign (abnormal shape of the humeral head) and an empty glenoid sign (humeral head is away from the glenoid fossa).

Below is the image showing the electric light bulb sign of posterior shoulder dislocation.

Options B and C: Inferior shoulder dislocation is also known as luxatio erecta. It occurs in less than 1% of cases. It is usually caused during severe hyperabduction of the arm or by axial loading on an abducted arm. On examination, the arm is held above the patient's head without being able to adduct the arm. The humeral head is felt below or in the axilla. The radiograph would reveal the humeral shaft in an abducted position with the humeral head below the glenoid fossa. 

Below is the image showing inferior shoulder dislocation.

Related Pearl: Tests for anterior shoulder dislocation

Bryant’s test: Anterior axillary fold is at a lower level on the dislocated side.

 

Dugas test: The patient is made to place the hand on the opposite shoulder. The examiner then applies gentle pressure on the flexed elbow to make it touch the chest. In shoulder dislocation, the elbow cannot be made to touch the chest. 

 

Hamilton ruler test: In a normal shoulder, a ruler (scale) placed on the lateral side of the arm will not touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion at the same time.

In anterior shoulder dislocation, the ruler will simultaneously touch the lateral condyle of the humerus and the acromion. 

 

 

Callway Test: The vertical circumference of the axilla is increased on the dislocated side as compared to the normal side. 

Related Pearl: Methods of reduction of shoulder dislocation

Kocher's technique - TEAM (Traction → External Rotation → Adduction → Medial Rotation) 

Hippocratic method - The doctor applies a firm and steady pull on the semi-abducted arm of the patient by keeping his foot on the axilla against the chest wall. The foot is used as the fulcrum.

Stimson's gravity technique: Patient is left prone and weight is attached to the elbow or wrist on the affected side. Gravity stretches the muscle and reduction occurs in 15-20 minutes.

questions.text: A 42-year-old working woman was diagnosed with glaucoma and was started on a drug that is delivered by a mechanism as shown in the image.  Identify the drug.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Ocusert / Ocular insert type of the latest drug delivery systems. These are available for the treatment of glaucoma and the only drug available in this formulation is pilocarpine.

Pilocarpine is a directly acting cholinomimetic that lowers intraocular pressure by increasing the trabecular flow.

Ocuserts are made with biological membranes with the drug reservoir in between them, which results in a slow and steady release of the drug into the system. The device is marketed in two sizes, Ocusert Pilo-20 and Ocusert Pilo-40, representing two different in vitro release rates, 20 and 40 mg/h, respectively. It is usually placed in lower-cul-de-sac.

The drug follows zero-order kinetic delivery. Pilocarpine is delivered at a slow constant rate, thus reducing ocular and systemic toxicity. The image below shows the cross-section of Ocusert.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man was posted for open inguinal hernia repair. He is a known hypertensive for the past 6 years and is poorly controlled on medications. Which of the following muscle relaxant can exacerbate hypertension in this patient?
questions.solution:
Pancuronium can exacerbate hypertension in poorly controlled patients by inducing vagal blockade and neural release of catecholamine leading to sympathetic stimulation.

For the same reason, large bolus doses of pancuronium are to be cautiously used in patients with coronary artery disease, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and aortic stenosis.

Pancuronium is a steroidal non-depolarizing muscle relaxant. It is metabolized in the liver and primarily excreted through the kidney.

In predisposed individuals, it causes increased atrioventricular conduction and catecholamines release resulting in ventricular arrhythmia. Individuals who are hypersensitive to bromide can exhibit allergic reactions to pancuronium. 

Other options:

Option B- Atracuronium causes hypotension due to a drop in systemic vascular resistance.

Option C- Vecuronium is devoid of significant cardiovascular effects.

Option D- Rocuronium is cardio stable and shows no changes in heart rate and blood pressure.

  • Muscle relaxant acting directly on muscle: Dantrolene

questions.text: The pattern shown in the image below is caused by:
questions.solution:
The image shows an arborescent burn/ filigree burn/Lichtenberg’s flower caused by lightning stroke.

It usually occurs over the shoulder or the flanks within an hour of the injury and disappears in a day or two. The mechanism by which this pattern is formed is not yet clearly known.

Other options - 

Option B- A scald injury occurs as a result of the application of liquid above 60°C or from steam. The injury does not extend as deep as in burns. At the area of contacts, redness appears at once and blistering will appear within a few minutes.

The below image shows an image of a scald injury.

Option C- Joule burn is specific and diagnostic of contact with electricity. It is found at the point of the entry of the current. It occurs due to the heat generated in the body from the electricity. They are round or oval shallow craters, one to three centimeters in diameter.

Option D- Spark burns or flash burns are electrical injuries that occur due to intense heat that may result from flash-over-producing burns that resemble thermal burns.

There is an air gap between metal and skin in spark burns. It has central brown or yellow nodule surrounded by an area of pale skin. These lesions are small as pinpoints or deeply seated and contracted if the voltage is high or the contact is prolonged.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with weakness and muscle cramps involving both legs. He also reported difficulty in swallowing food. On examination, he is found to be alert and oriented. Both lower limbs exhibit fasciculations with significant atrophy and extensor plantar reflex. The reflexes in both upper and lower limbs are exaggerated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a type of progressive motor neuron disease. The pathological hallmark is the destruction and death of both upper (UMN) and lower motor neurons (LMN). Irrespective of what is involved first, eventually ALS will involve both UMN and LMN. The motor neuron disease involving selectively the upper motor neurons is called primary lateral sclerosis, while the one involving selectively the lower motor neurons is called spinomuscular atrophy.

Patients present with insidious onset asymmetric bilateral weakness of the distal part of the lower limbs. There may be a history of cramping, particularly early in the morning. Lower motor neuron death causes muscle atrophy and fasciculations. Upper motor neuron involvement presents as exaggerated tendon reflexes and spasticity. Some of the patients also tend to develop frontotemporal dementia. However, the sensory, bowel and bladder functions and cognition is preserved even in the late stages of the disease.

Other options:

Option A: Guillain-Barre syndrome is an acute inflammatory demyelinating peripheral neuropathy that occurs 1-3 weeks following an acute infectious process. It results in LMN type of palsy with the absence of deep tendon reflexes. It is also associated with sensory findings like loss of proprioception and autonomic features such as lability of blood pressure. These findings are absent in ALS because only the motor neurons are involved.

Option B: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to abnormalities in the posterior and lateral column function that results in loss of vibration and position sense, progressive spastic weakness, and sensory ataxia. Loss of deep tendon reflexes due to associated peripheral neuropathy can also be seen. However, there is an extensor plantar response due to the involvement of the corticospinal tracts.

Option C: Lambert-Eaton syndrome is a paraneoplastic neuromuscular disorder that presents with proximal muscle weakness, arreflexia, and autonomic dysfunction. In 60% of patients, there may be associated cancer, usually small cell lung cancer.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with pelvic inflammatory disease was brought to you for further management. Hysterosalpingography done in this patient showed the following finding. What is the stage of pelvic inflammatory disease seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The hysterosalpingography image shows the tobacco pouch appearance of the fallopian tube, seen in tubercular salpingitis, which belongs to stage 5 of pelvic inflammatory diseases.

Pelvic inflammatory disease is the inflammation of the upper genital tract including the fallopian tubes as well as the ovaries. The spectrum ranges from mild to moderate to severe.

Clinical features include lower abdominal pain, abnormal bleeding, fever, mucopurulent discharge, cervical motion tenderness, etc.

Depending upon the severity of tubal damage, five stages of PID have been described,

Stages of PID:

Stage

Condition

Stage I 

Acute salpingitis without peritonitis—no adhesions

Stage II 

Acute salpingitis with peritonitis—purulent discharge

Stage III 

Acute salpingitis with superimposed tubal occlusion or tubo-ovarian complex 

Stage IV 

Ruptured tubo-ovarian abscess

Stage V  

Tubercular salpingitis

Tubercular salpingitis: 

Genital tuberculosis is almost always secondary to the primary focus. The fallopian tubes are the first to be involved and are bilaterally affected.

It is secondary to hematogenous spread from a primary focus. The ampullary part of the tube appears dilated with the fimbrial end open and pouting. This gives the characteristic tobacco-pouch appearance as seen in the image below.

The external surface of the tubes are enlarged, roughened, and may show the presence of greyish tubercles. The cut section shows yellowish-grey caseous matter in the lumen. Sometimes, serosanguinous fluid can also be seen in the lumen of the fallopian tube. This is called tuberculous hematosalpinx.

HSG findings in tubercular salpingitis are:

  • A rigid non-peristaltic pipe-like tube (lead pipe appearance)
  • Beading and variation in the filling defect
  • Calcification of the tube, coiling of the tubes
  • Cornual block
  • A jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline
  • Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx

Note : HSG should not be performed in a suspected case of genital tuberculosis as it causes dissemination of the infection. This further increases the damage to the fallopian tubes.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with lesions on her face as shown in the image. Similar lesions were absent in the chest and back. What management plan is suitable for her?
questions.solution:
The image shows typical erythematous papules and small nodules along with a few whiteheads are suggestive of moderate acne vulgaris. It should be treated with oral antibiotics and topical retinoids.

The severity of acne can be classified as:

Mild Open and closed comedones with few inflammatory papules and pustules
Moderate Papules and pustules mainly on the face, occasional inflamed nodules on the chest and back also
Severe Many large, painful nodules and pustules

The clinical severity and approach to treatment are decided based on the type of lesion and based on extensiveness.

Only comedonal types can be treated with topical retinoids.

Papulopustular type can be treated with topical retinoid combined with an antibiotic (topical or oral) based on severity. More oily skin and the occurrence of nodules should prompt oral antibiotics.

Nodular or conglobate type can be treated with oral isotretinoin.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient with a history of maniac disorder with psychotic symptoms was brought to the outpatient department with a history of delusions and hallucinations for the last 3 weeks. His mood has been normal for the same duration. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The concurrent presence of psychotic symptoms together with mania in the past and a three-week episode of psychotic symptoms in the absence of mania is suggestive of schizoaffective disorder.

DSM-5 criteria:

  • An uninterrupted period of illness where there is a major mood episode (depression or mania) concurrent with psychosis that meet the criteria for schizophrenia (delusions, hallucinations, disorganized speech, etc.)
  • Delusions or hallucinations (psychotic symptoms) for at least two weeks in the absence of a major depressive or manic episode during the lifetime course of the illness.
  • Major mood episode is present for the majority of total illness.
  • Not due to intake of substances or another medical condition.

Note: According to DSM-5 guidelines, for a definitive diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder, there have to be two psychotic episodes. One of the psychotic episodes has to be concurrent with a major mood episode (depression or manic).

The other psychotic episode should be for two or more weeks in the absence of a major mood episode. And the major mood episode should dominate the major part of the lifetime course of the illness.

Differential Diagnoses include:

  • Substance-induced disorder
  • Preexisting medical condition-induced disorder
  • Seizure disorder 

Family therapy, cognitive rehabilitation, and social skills training are beneficial. Mood stabilizers like lithium and antidepressants like SSRI - fluoxetine, and sertraline- are used for the management of schizoaffective disorder. Mood stabilizers can be used to manage episodes of mania. ECT can be given in case of intractable mania. Antipsychotics are helpful to manage psychotic symptoms.

Other options:

Option A- Schizophrenia is defined by a group of characterized symptoms like delusions, hallucinations, negative symptoms, determination of social, occupational, and interpersonal functioning, and continuous signs of the disturbances for at least 6 months. 

Option B- Schizophreniform disorder is described as acute psychiatric symptoms as in schizophrenia that were reactive and occurred in persons with relatively normal personalities that last at least 1 month but less than 6 months. 

Option D- Brief psychotic disorder is the sudden onset of psychotic behavior as in schizophrenia lasting for at least 1 day but less than 1 month.

questions.text: A patient who has been on theophylline for several weeks has complaints of gastric discomfort and increased urinary frequency.  He has recently been prescribed a drug for the management of chronic gout. The symptoms were attributed to theophylline toxicity caused by an interaction with the newly prescribed drug. Identify the prescribed drug.
questions.solution:
The drug that was prescribed for gout in this case is most likely to be allopurinol. 

Allopurinol decreases the clearance of theophylline. It inhibits CYP1A2 in the liver, and theophylline is mainly metabolized by CYP1A2 in the liver. This leads to plasma concentration–dependent side effects of theophylline. 

The toxicity and side effects of theophylline are mostly dose-related and generally tend to occur at plasma concentrations greater than 15 mg/L. The adverse effects and their mechanism are summarized below:

       Side effect         Mechanism
Nausea, vomiting, gastric discomfort    PDE4 inhibition
Headaches    PDE4 inhibition
Diuresis / increased urinary frequency     A1 receptor antagonism
Cardiac arrhythmias     PDE3 and A1 receptor antagonism
Epileptic seizures     A1 receptor antagonism

Theophylline belongs to a class of drugs called methylxanthines. It can be given intravenously or orally as tablets or elixirs. Its therapeutic range is 5–15 mg/L and has antiasthma effects (besides bronchodilatation) below 10 mg/L.

Once administered, it is rapidly and completely absorbed, but there are large interindividual variations in clearance due to differences in hepatic metabolism. Theophylline is metabolized in the liver, mainly by CYP1A2 and many factors influence hepatic metabolism and clearance of theophylline.

Factors that decrease the clearance of theophylline:

  • Drugs that cause CYP inhibition - erythromycin, cimetidine, ciprofloxacin, allopurinol, fluvoxamine, zileuton, zafirlukast
  • Congestive heart failure, liver disease, pneumonia
  • Viral infection and vaccination
  • High-carbohydrate diet
  • Old age

Factors increasing its clearance:

  • Drugs like rifampin and ethanol, which are inducers of enzymes such as CYP1A2
  • Tobacco and marijuana smoking, by CYP1A2 induction
  • High-protein, low-carbohydrate diet
  • Barbequed meat

It has been used as a controller in the management of mild persistent asthma and is also used as a bronchodilator in COPD.

questions.text: A patient presents with an inability to close the left eye, purse the lips, raise the eyebrows, or whistle following cranial surgery. There is a loss of taste sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. The Schirmer test is normal, and the stapedial reflex is present. What is the most likely site of nerve injury?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has paralysis of the facial muscles, loss of taste sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue with normal Schirmer test, and stapedial reflex. Therefore, the most likely site of facial nerve injury is above the stylomastoid foramen.

The course of the facial nerve is divided into intracranial (cisternal), intratemporal and extratemporal portions.

Intracranial portion- The facial nerve nucleus lies in the caudal pontine reticular formation near the trapezoid nucleus and nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. Fibres from this nucleus curve around the abducens nucleus and emerge at the cerebellopontine angle.

The intratemporal portion is from the internal acoustic meatus to the stylomastoid foramen. This is further divided into meatal, labyrinthine, tympanic (horizontal), and mastoid (vertical) segments.

  • Meatal- The facial nerve passes through the internal acoustic meatus along with the nervus intermedius, cochlear nerve, and superior and inferior vestibular nerves. It passes above the transverse crest. It is separated from the superior vestibular nerve by Bill's bar.
  • Labyrinthine segment is from the internal acoustic meatus to the first genu near the geniculate ganglion. It is the shortest and narrowest part of the facial nerve and is susceptible to vascular compression.
  • Tympanic part- is the horizontal part of the facial nerve. It curves around the oval window niche then lies just anterior and inferior to the lateral semicircular canal. After this, the nerve makes a second bend (genu) to continue as a vertical part.
  • Mastoid part- is the longest part and runs up to the stylomastoid foramen.

Branches from the intratemporal facial nerve:

  • Greater superficial petrosal nerve- It arises from the geniculate ganglion. It contains parasympathetic fibres for the lacrimal gland and palate.
  • Nerve to stapedius- It arises from the facial nerve in the posterior wall of the tympanic cavity. It supplies stapedius muscle
  • Chorda tympani leaves the facial nerve around 6mm above the stylomastoid foramen. It contains parasympathetic fibres that supply the submandibular and sublingual salivary glands via the submandibular ganglion and taste fibres from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

Extratemporal portion - The facial nerve emerges from the base of the skull at the stylomastoid foramen and supplies the posterior belly of the digastric, stylohyoid, occipitofrontalis, and other facial muscles.

Option A- Injury proximal to the geniculate ganglion will damage the greater superficial petrosal nerve, nerve to stapedius, chorda tympani, and muscular branches. There is loss of lacrimal secretions, loss of stapedial reflex, loss of taste in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue, and facial paralysis.

Option B- Injury above the stapedius will lead to damage of nerve to the stapedius, chorda tympani, and muscular branches. There is loss of stapedial reflex, loss of taste in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue, and facial paralysis.

Option D- Injury at or below the stylomastoid foramen will lead to paralysis of facial muscles, but the taste sensation, stapedial reflex, and secretions of the eye are normal.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant was brought to the hospital with poor head control,  hypotonia of the upper limbs, and delayed motor milestones. The mother gives a history of kernicterus in the baby during the early neonatal period. MRI scan of the brain revealed atrophy of the globus pallidus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a child along with MRI finding of atrophy of globus pallidus (in basal ganglia), most likely points to diagnosis of dyskinetic cerebral palsy. 

Cerebral palsy (CP) is a static encephalopathy affecting movement and posture due to non-progressive disturbances occurring in the developing fetal brain. The subtypes of cerebral palsy include:

  • Spastic diplegia
  • Spastic quadriplegia
  • Spastic hemiplegia
  • Dyskinetic cerebral palsy

Dyskinetic/Athetoid/Choreoathetoid/Extrapyramidal CP is more commonly seen in term infants. It is likely to be associated with birth asphyxia and kernicterus in the early neonatal period. Clinical features include hypotonia with poor head control. Hypertonia with rigidity and dystonia, involuntary movements can develop in the later years. The upper limb is affected more than the lower limb. MRI scan of the brain reveals lesions in the basal ganglia and thalamus.

Other options:

Option B- Spastic diplegia is more commonly seen in premature infants due to damage to immature white matter. Periventricular leukomalacia is the most common neuropathologic finding in spastic diplegic patients. Below is the MRI image showing periventricular leukomalacia.

Option C- Spastic quadriplegia is associated with ischemia of the brain and infections. MRI would reveal severe periventricular leukomalacia and multicystic cortical encephalomalacia.

Option D- Spastic hemiplegia is associated with thrombophilic disorders and infections. MRI is more sensitive than CT scan for the diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient presents with the complaints of a painless ulcer on his penis. The complement fixation test is found to be positive. All of the following immunoglobulins are involved in this reaction, except:
questions.solution:
All the given immunoglobulins are involved in complement fixation except IgG4.

A painless ulcer over the penis with a positive complement fixation test is suggestive of the diagnosis of syphilis.

Complement cannot bind to the free antigen or antibodies directly. It can bind to those antibodies that have combined with their antigen. The ability of these antigen-antibody complexes to bind or fix complement is utilized in the complement fixation test. The test is performed in two steps and involves five reagents: antigen, antibody, complement, sheep erythrocytes, and an amboceptor (rabbit antibody to sheep RBCs). 

Compliment fixation involves the immunoglobulins IgM, IgG3, IgG1, and IgG2 (in this order).

questions.text: A 3-day old neonate of a diabetic mother presents with progressively deepening cyanosis and tachypnea since birth. The chest X-ray of the neonate is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A clinical scenario of an infant born to a diabetic mother, presenting with progressive cyanosis and tachypnea with an X-ray showing the egg-on-side appearance is suggestive of transposition of great arteries. 

TGA is the most specific heart disease in infants of diabetic mothers and is more common in males. The deoxygenated blood returning from the body goes inappropriately out the aorta and back to the body again, while oxygenated pulmonary venous blood is returned directly to the lungs. Survival in the immediate neonatal period is due to the mixture of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood provided by the foramen ovale and the ductus arteriosus. 50% of patients also have a ventricular septal defect (VSD).

Chest X-rays show mild cardiomegaly, a narrow mediastinum (the classic egg-shaped heart or egg-on-string appearance) shown in the image below with normal to increased pulmonary blood flow. Egg-on-string or globular-shaped heart is due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement, and therefore appears like an egg.

An ECHO confirms the transposed ventricular-arterial connection and is diagnostic. A color doppler examination is used to visualize the size of the interatrial communication and the ductus arteriosus. It also assesses the degree of mixing, and presence of any associated ventricular outflow tract obstruction, or a septal defect. 

Other options:

Option A: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC) occurs due to the anomalous connection of pulmonary veins instead of joining to the left atrium resulting in pulmonary venous blood reaching the right atrium. 

In supracardiac (TAPVC)  the configuration of the heart and the superior mediastinal borders resemble a snowman. It is also referred to as the figure of 8 sign as shown below.

Option B: Ebstein anomaly is a rare cyanotic congenital heart disease with diminished pulmonary blood flow due to abnormality of the tricuspid valve. 

In the Ebstein anomaly, there is severe right-sided cardiomegaly due to an elongated and enlarged right atrium which leads to an elevated apex giving a box-shaped heart as shown below.

Option C: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)  is the most common cyanotic heart disease encountered beyond the age of 1 year. It is characterized by tetrad of:

  • Severe right ventricle outflow obstruction
  • Large ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Aorta overriding VSD
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy

In the TOF, the hypertrophied right ventricle causes the rounded apical shadow to be uptilted so that it is situated higher above the diaphragm than normal. This on X-rays appears as a boot-shaped heart or Coeur en sabot as shown below.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient who has worked in the gunpowder and explosive manufacturing industry for more than 20 years presents with swelling in the lower jaw. On further examination, multiple discharging sinuses with foul-smelling pus were noted. Which of the following chemicals is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a male patient working in the gunpowder and explosive manufacturing industry for more than 20 years, presenting with swelling in the lower jaw and multiple discharging sinuses with foul-smelling pus is suggestive of a phossy jaw, seen in chronic phosphorus poisoning.

Phosphorus is a non-metallic, inorganic irritant poison that affects cellular oxidation. It exists in two forms, white phosphorus, a highly toxic form, and red phosphorus, the non-toxic form. 

Chronic phosphorus poisoning is common among the workers of phosphorus industries, who have had chronic exposure to phosphorus fumes over a period of years. It causes necrosis of the lower jaw in the region of a decayed tooth.

Patients initially present with toothache, followed by swelling of the jaw, loosening of the teeth, necrosis of gums, and sequestration of the bone in the mandible producing considerable facial disfigurement. Phossy jaw is the osteomyelitis and necrosis of the jaw, with foul-smelling pus discharging multiple sinuses. It is managed surgically and by prevention of further absorption of the poison. 

Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate oxidizes phosphorus into phosphoric acid and phosphates. Activated charcoal can be used to adsorb the poison. 

Other options:

Option A - Acute arsenic poisoning resembles bacterial food poisoning. Initially, they have dark-coloured, foul-smelling bloody stools, which later become colourless, odourless, and watery, resembling watery stools of cholera. 

Chronic arsenic poisoning occurs due to accidental ingestion of multiple small doses in food or drinks. In chronic poisoning, finely mottled, raindrop pigmentation appears on the skin of flexures, temples, eyelids, and neck. The rashes resemble fading measles rash. In prolonged poisoning, a transverse white line, called the Aldrich-Mees line, appears in fingernails. 


Option B: Prolonged ingestion of fluorides results in the mottling of teeth, an increase in the density of bones, lipping of bony margins of vertebrae, which sometimes produce pressure on the spinal cord leading to paraplegia.

Option C: Acute mercury poisoning occurs when elemental mercury vapors produce corrosive bronchitis with fever, chills, and dyspnea. In children, manifestations similar to Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome) can be seen. Severe infection can cause loosening of teeth and necrosis of the jaw.

Chronic elemental mercury exposure yields a classic triad of gingivitis, tremors, and neuropsychiatric changes.
