questions.text: The 8-year-old child with delayed development was referred for evaluation of recurrent infections. History is notable for the presence of congenital heart defects. Further examination reveals the presence of a cleft palate and workup reveals the presence of hypocalcemia.  Which component of the immune system is likely to be affected in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a child with developmental delay, recurrent infections with a history of congenital heart disease and examination revealing cleft palate and hypocalcemia point towards the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome. Cell-mediated immunity is affected.

DiGeorge syndrome is a complex embryopathy with an autosomal dominant inheritance that is caused by microdeletions in the long arm of chromosome 22, leading to multiple developmental defects.

Children with DiGeorge syndrome have thymic hypoplasia resulting in T-cell immunodeficiency. The disease may range from mildly increased susceptibility to infections to a severe disease requiring a thymic or hematopoietic stem cell transplant. Patients are generally able to cope with extracellular bacterial infections because their innate and T cell-independent antibody responses are intact, but they cannot effectively eliminate intracellular pathogens such as viruses, intracellular bacteria, and fungi.

The clinical features of this syndrome include:

  • Congenital heart disease- aortic arch anomalies
  • Abnormalities of the palate like cleft palate.
  • Facial dysmorphisms such as hypertelorism, antimongoloid slant, low set ears, micrognathia, short philtrum, and bifid uvula.
  • Thymic hypoplasia with impaired T cell immunity. 
  • Parathyroid hypoplasia resulting in hypocalcemia (tetany).

Interestingly individuals with DiGeorge syndrome are at high risk for psychotic illnesses such as schizophrenia and bipolar disorders.

Diagnosis is established only by the detection of deletion in long-arm chromosome 22 by fluorescent in-situ hybridisation(FISH).

 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

The image below shows the abnormal facies in DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: A patient underwent emergency surgery for a femoral shaft fracture. On the 2nd post-operative day, he developed fever, breathlessness, and was disoriented. On examination, he had axillary and subconjunctival petechiae. CT pulmonary angiogram showed diffuse patchy ground-glass shadowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The development of fever, breathlessness, disorientation, and subconjunctival and axillary petechiae within 72 hours of a traumatic skeletal (femur) fracture and CT angiogram showing pulmonary infarction points towards the diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome. 

Fat embolism syndrome is the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after the fracture of a long bone or other major trauma. Its pathogenesis can be related to 2 factors:

  • The release of free fatty acids by the action of lipases on the neutral fats that causes toxic vasculitis.
  • Actual obstruction of small pulmonary vessels by fat globules.

The early signs of fat embolism syndrome that occur within 72 hours of injury are fever and tachycardia. The presenting features can be classified into 2 types:

  • Cerebral type: drowsiness, restlessness, disorientation, and coma
  • Pulmonary type: tachypnoea, tachycardia

Pathognomic signs include a petechial rash in front of neck/ anterior axillary fold/ chest/ conjunctiva.

Management of fat embolism is mainly supportive. This consists of respiratory support with high inspired oxygen concentration, heparinization, intravenous low molecular weight dextran, and corticosteroids to reduce the inflammation in the lungs. Prompt stabilization of long-bone fractures reduces the incidence of fat embolism syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Hemorrhagic shock is the most common cause of shock in surgical or trauma patients. Here the patient presents with agitation, cold clammy extremities, hypotension, tachycardia, and weak peripheral pulses. Acidosis and elevated lactate levels may be seen due to hypoperfusion of tissues.

Option B: Acute compartment syndrome refers to an elevation of the intra-compartmental pressure (ICP) which increases the risk for tissue ischemia and necrosis. It can occur following fractures (commonly) or soft tissue injuries and is a localized condition involving the affected limb. The clinical features include pain, paresthesia, pallor, paralysis, and pulselessness. The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring the intra-compartmental pressures. Fasciotomy is done in confirmed cases.

Option D: Crush syndrome can result when a limb is compressed for a prolonged period (e.g. getting crushed or entrapped in a vehicle or machinery). This results in hypoperfusion and myonecrosis in the crushed limb. When the limb is released from the compression, toxic metabolites get released to cause reperfusion injury. Free myoglobin can lead to acute tubular necrosis and renal failure. Myonecrosis can lead to metabolic acidosis with hyperkalemia and hypocalcemia. The procoagulants that escaped into the systemic circulation can produce systemic coagulopathy. 

Related Pearl: Gurd's criteria for diagnosing fat embolism syndrome

Major criteria
  • Petechial rash
  • Respiratory symptoms with radiographic changes
  • CNS depression.

Minor criteria

  • Tachycardia
  • Pyrexia
  • Retinal changes (fat or petechiae)
  • Renal abnormalities (oliguria, anuria, or lipiduria)
  • Acute thrombocytopenia
  • Acute decrease in hemoglobin
  • Fat globules in sputum
  • Increased ESR

2 major criteria OR one major criteria + four minor criteria suggest a diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome.

questions.text: A 31-year-old male patient with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease presented with a sudden onset of severe headache and vomiting. On examination, marked neck rigidity was noted. Cerebrospinal fluid tap reveals findings as shown in the image. Which among the following drugs is ideal for preventing delayed cerebral ischemia?
questions.solution:
Nimodipine is ideal to prevent delayed cerebral ischaemia in this patient.

The clinical vignette describing a patient with sudden onset headache with meningeal signs of neck rigidity and CSF fluid showing xanthochromia is suggestive of subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH). Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) is commonly associated with intracranial aneurysms.

Nimodipine, which belongs to the dihydropyridine group of drugs, is an L-type calcium channel blocker recommended for all patients with aneurysmal SAH to prevent cerebral vasospasm and delayed cerebral ischemia.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage: 

Etiology - Traumatic or rupture of aneurysms

Clinical features - Thunderclap headache, photophobia, loss of consciousness, vomiting, neck pain, or stiffness

Diagnosis - Non-contrast CT head, lumbar puncture shows xanthochromia

Treatment - Blood pressure must be controlled and maintained at systolic blood pressure (SBP) <160 mmHg or mean arterial pressure (MAP) <110 mmHg.  Nimodipine 60 mg every four hours is administered to all patients with aneurysmal SAH starting within 48 hours of symptom onset. Nimodipine prevents cerebral vasospasm. Management of the aneurysm is done with surgical clipping or endovascular coiling.

Other options:

Option A: Tranexamic acid is an inhibitor of fibrinolysis used in the management of intraoperative bleeding, major head injury and trauma resuscitation.

Option B: Phenytoin is a sodium channel modulator used in the management of focal seizures and generalised tonic-clonic seizures.

Option C: Nifedipine also belongs to the dihydropyridine group of drugs which are calcium channel blockers and is used for management of vasospastic angina, preventing exertional angina, management of hypertension etc.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man complains of persistently aching legs. He also complained of hearing loss. However, his blood tests reveal an elevated serum alkaline phosphatase. An X-ray of the skull is given below. Which of the following malignancies is a complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
Osteosarcoma is a malignant complication of this condition.

The given clinical scenario with a radiograph showing cotton-wool skull is suggestive of Paget's disease of bone.

Paget's disease is characterized by focal areas of increased bone remodelling, resulting in the overgrowth of poorly organized bone. This unbalanced process leads to osseous deformities, nerve compressions, and pathological fractures.

Paget's disease is usually seen at age >50 years. They are mostly asymptomatic but can present with a dull ache. Deformities are usually seen in the lower limbs such as bowing of the tibia or femur. They may have deformities such as bowing of bones—for instance, the tibia bends anteriorly and the femur bends anterolateral. If the skull is affected, enlargement of the skull is seen. Disorganized and increased bone deposition may lead to stenosis of various canals and foramina resulting in compression of cranial nerves, spinal cord, and nerve roots (due to spinal stenosis). Hearing loss is a fairly common feature, due to compression of the cranial nerve and otosclerosis resulting in mixed sensorineural and conductive hearing loss. Pathological fractures of the long bones may be seen. 

Investigations

Serum calcium and phosphate are usually normal. Serum alkaline phosphatase is elevated.

The x-ray findings are characteristic and appear in stages.

  • Osteolytic phase - It involves prominent bone resorption and marked hypervascularization. Radiographically, this manifests as an advancing lytic wedge on the shaft of the bone, or blade of grass, or flame-shaped lesion.
  • Sclerotic phase - Bone resorption declines progressively and leads to a thick, less vascular pagetic or mosaic bone (coarse trabeculations)

Some of the radiographical signs include:

  • Flame-shaped lesions- Seen in long bones due to localized osteolysis/osteopenia. 
  • Picture-frame appearance manifests with cortical thickening and sclerosis encasing the vertebral margins.
  • Ivory vertebra sign may be seen due to diffuse and homogeneous increase in opacity of a vertebral body.
  • Osteogenesis circumscripta describes circumscribed patches of radiolucency due to osteoporosis in the skull.

The arrow mark in the following image indicates a "blade of grass/flame-shaped lesion" appearance.

The image given below depicts the Ivory vertebra sign.

Below is an image depicting the picture-frame appearance seen in vertebral bodies.

Treatment:

Medical management includes bisphosphonates, IV Zolendronate is preferred. Surgical correction is done in cases of deformities and pathological fractures.

Complications:

  • Risk of fractures due to decreased strength of bone
  • Osteoarthritis
  • Bony overgrowth leads to spinal stenosis and nerve compression
  • High output cardiac failure due to the increased blood flow to skeletal bones
  • Hypercalcemia may be seen in prolonged immobilization
  • Cranial nerve-2nd, 5th, 7th, 8th palsy is seen
  • Deafness due to nerve compression or otosclerosis
  • Malignant transformation to osteosarcoma

questions.text: An elder sibling is playing with his 3-year-old sister and he pulls up the child by holding hands. The child starts crying, does not use her arm, and does not let anybody touch it. She presents to the orthopaedics unit with the limb in the position as shown in the image. No swelling or focal point tenderness is elicited but she cries when supination is attempted. What is the possible cause?
questions.solution:
The history of lifting the child by the forearm and later the child refusing to let anyone touch her hand is pointing towards the diagnosis of the pulled elbow/ nursemaid's elbow. The subluxation of the radial head is the possible cause in this case.

Pulled elbow/ nursemaid's elbow is the radial head subluxation from the annular ligament seen more commonly in children less than 6 years of age. 

The underlying mechanism in this deformity is the subluxation of the radial head under the annular ligament and not the olecranon process (option B). This is due to the longitudinal traction applied on an extended and supinated forearm. The clinical features include severe pain and the inability to use the affected arm. Characteristically the child holds the elbow in extension or slight flexion with the forearm pronated as shown in the image above.

Given below is a diagrammatic representation of the mechanism of development of a pulled elbow:

 

The diagnosis is usually clinical but a radiograph is obtained to exclude a fracture.

It can be treated by the closed reduction technique of forearm flexion with supination. Immobilization using a sling can be used for symptomatic relief.

Other options:

Option B: Subluxation of the olecranon process is seen in posterior dislocation of the elbow. It often occurs when a person falls on an outstretched hand. Examination of the elbow joint may show swelling, deformity, or bruising. Posterior elbow dislocations often present with an upper extremity that is flexed and appears shortened. Initial workup involves X-ray in anteroposterior and lateral view. CT scan is considered when the injury is complex. Simple cases are usually treated with closed reductions.

Option C- Supracondylar humerus fracture is the most common fracture in children. It results from a fall on an outstretched hand. The fracture lies just above the condyles of the humerus with angulation or displacement of the distal fragment. The clinical features include pain and a swollen elbow. An X-ray of the supracondylar fracture of the humerus is given below.

 

Option D- Avulsion of the olecranon process results from the eccentric contraction of the triceps tendon.

Below is the radiograph showing olecranon process avulsion.

questions.text: Which of the following proteins connects the lines marked as A and B (indicated by red arrows) in the following image?
questions.solution:
The above image is the electron microscope view of the muscle. Line A corresponds to the M line, and Line B corresponds to the Z line. The protein that connects the M line with the Z line is titin. 

Here is an image highlighting the various zones of a sarcomere.

The area between two Z-lines is called a sarcomere. 

Apart from proteins like actin, myosin, troponin, and tropomyosin, there are some additional structural proteins that are important for the function of the skeletal muscle:

  • Actinin - It binds actin to the Z lines.
  • Titin - It is the largest protein and connects the Z lines to the M lines.
  • Desmin - It connects Z lines to the plasma membrane.

Dystrophin connects actin filaments to the transmembrane protein β-dystroglycan in the sarcolemma by the smaller proteins syntrophins in the cytoplasm.

The troponin molecules are attached intermittently along the sides of the tropomyosin molecules. They have three loosely bound protein subunits:

  • Troponin I - It inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
  • Troponin T - It binds troponin components to tropomyosin.
  • Troponin C - It binds the calcium ions and initiates contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

Related Pearl: Sarcomere

questions.text: A young woman complains of excessive thirst, polyuria, and nocturia following a head injury. There is no glucosuria. Her urine osmolarity is found to be 290 mOsm/L, and her 24-hour urine output is 2.75 L. The patient was asked not to consume any fluids. After 4 hours, the urine osmolality was measured to be 600 mOsm/L. MRI showed a bright spot in the posterior pituitary.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is primary polydipsia.

In the given clinical scenario, the patient has polyuria, nocturia, and polydipsia without glucosuria. Her urine osmolality is initially low (<300 mosm/L) but increases after the fluid restriction (400–800 mosmol/L). The MRI showed a bright spot in the posterior pituitary. These findings favor the diagnosis.

Primary polydipsia means excessive intake of fluids. It can occur as a result of

  • inappropriate thirst mechanism - dipsogenic diabetes insipidus
  • as a part of psychosis - psychogenic polydipsia
  • due to increased water intake owing to its health benefits - iatrogenic polydipsia

Excessive water intake results in decreased plasma osmolality and sodium levels, decreasing the antidiuretic hormone (ADH) secretion. There is a compensatory increase in urine volume and a decrease in urine osmolality.

In patients with primary polydipsia, fluid restriction increases and brings back the plasma osmolality and sodium to normal. This increases the levels of ADH, which results in increased urinary osmolality.

In most healthy adults, the posterior pituitary emits a hyperintense signal visible in the MRI as a bright spot. This is visualized in patients with primary polydipsia and is abnormal or absent in patients with central diabetes insipidus.

Other options:

Option A: Central diabetes insipidus (DI) is caused due to deficiency of ADH secretion. In this condition, the levels of ADH do not increase even after fluid restriction and therefore the urine osmolality will not increase. 

Option B: Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus occurs due to decreased action of ADH. Mutations occur in the V2 receptor or the aquaporin channels and ADH cannot act on them. Therefore, in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, even if the ADH levels are normal, it cannot act on the receptors, and the urine osmolality does not increase after fluid restriction. A simpler way to differentiate between central DI and nephrogenic DI is to measure basal ADH levels and urine osmolality under unrestricted fluid intake conditions. A low urine osmolality with a concurrent elevated ADH level (>1 ng/mL) indicates nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. A low ADH level is suggestive of central DI or primary polydipsia, which can be differentiated on MRI brain.

Option C: Syndrome of inappropriate ADH secretion results in increased secretions of ADH. Therefore, the patients will have decreased urine output and increased urine concentration. If the water intake is not restricted, patients also develop hyponatremia.

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with yellowish discoloration of the eyes and abdominal pain. On examination, there is tender hepatomegaly. Histopathological examination of the liver revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion bodies in hepatocytes composed of intermediate filaments. Identify the inclusion bodies.
questions.solution:
Mallory hyaline bodies are the inclusion bodies in hepatocytes present in this patient.

The clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic presenting with jaundice, abdominal pain, and tender hepatomegaly is suggestive of alcoholic hepatitis. In this condition, there are intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions called Mallory Denk bodies and they contain intermediate filaments. 

The liver undergoes inflammation and fibrosis in alcoholic hepatitis. This leads to injured and swollen hepatocytes with cleared-out cytoplasm and cytoskeletal damage. These hepatocytes are called ballooned hepatocytes. When the cytoskeletal damage is extensive, there is the formation of Mallory Denk/ Mallory hyaline bodies. These are remnants of partially degraded intermediate filaments and are composed of keratin 8 and keratin 18.

Mallory hyaline bodies are seen in:

  • Alcoholic steatohepatitis
  • Wilson disease
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis(NASH)
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma

The given image shows intracytoplasmic eosinophilic Mallory bodies. 

Other options:

Option B- Hepatocyte rosettes are seen in autoimmune hepatitis where the regenerated hepatocytes are arranged in the circular fashion in the form of rosettes around the dilated canaliculus. 

Option C- Councilman bodies are seen in yellow fever. They are apoptotic hepatocytes that are deeply eosinophilic stained. In other conditions like acute and chronic hepatitis, these are called acidophil bodies.

The given image shows the Councilman bodies in hepatocytes.

Option D- Ground glass hepatocytes are seen in chronic hepatitis B due to swelling of the endoplasmic reticulum of the swollen hepatocytes and filling with HbsAg.

The given image shows the ground glass hepatocytes.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient came for a routine check-up. An electrocardiogram was done, which is given below. What is the most probable finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
First-degree heart block is the most probable finding in the given electrocardiogram (ECG).

The ECG image shows a prolongation of the PR interval by >0.20 seconds, which is indicative of first-degree heart block.

First-degree heart block is the abnormal slowing of the conduction through the atrioventricular node. It is characterized by a prolonged PR interval >0.20 seconds without disrupting the atrial and ventricular conduction. The normal PR interval is from 0.12 seconds to 0.20 seconds. 

Some of the common causes of first-degree heart blocks are coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, infections, electrolyte abnormalities, drugs, and collagen vascular diseases. Most of the patients are usually asymptomatic and are diagnosed incidentally. In high-grade first-degree heart block (PR interval >0.30 seconds), patients develop symptoms like dyspnea, chest pain, or syncope.

For the majority of patients with first-degree AV block, there is no need for treatment. In patients with a PR interval greater than 0.30 seconds, who are experiencing symptoms believed to be due to the AV block, pacemaker placement may be required. In patients with AV block related to myocardial infarction (MI), pacemaker placement may be indicated.

Other options:

Option B- Type I Mobitz (Wenckebach) block is a subtype of second-degree heart block. It is characterized by progressive prolongation of the PR interval, shortening of the RR interval, and a pause (dropped beat) that is less than 2 times the immediately preceding RR interval. The shortest PR interval occurs after the pause and the longest PR interval occurs before the pause.

The below image shows the type I Mobitz heart block.

Option C- Type II Mobitz block is also a subtype of second-degree heart block. It is characterized by an intermittent failure of P wave conduction without any change in the preceding impulses. There is no progressive prolongation of PR interval like in type I Mobitz block. 

The below image shows the type II Mobitz block.

Option D- Complete heart block/third-degree heart block is the complete failure of conduction from the atrium to the ventricles. It is characterized by no relationship between the P wave and QRS complex, P waves more than QRS complexes, and equal RR and PR intervals. A junctional or ventricular escape rhythm maintains the ventricular conduction.

The below image shows the complete heart block.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with features of angular stomatitis and a magenta tongue. Deficiency of which of the following vitamin will result in the above features?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario presence of angular stomatitis and magenta tongue is suggestive of vitamin B2 / riboflavin deficiency.

Riboflavin (vitamin B2)

The active form of riboflavin is Flavin mononucleotide(FMN) and Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide (FAD). FMN is present in Complex I of ETC and FAD is present in Complex II in ETC.

FAD-dependent enzymes include succinate dehydrogenase, pyruvate dehydrogenase, alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, xanthine oxidase, and acyl CoA dehydrogenase

Riboflavin is synthesized in the body by intestinal flora. Dietary sources rich in riboflavin are liver, dried yeast, egg, and whole milk. Fish, whole cereals, legumes, and green leafy vegetables are also good sources of riboflavin. Riboflavin is light-sensitive. Hence riboflavin supplementation may be required during phototherapy for hyperbilirubinemia 

Clinical features of riboflavin deficiency include the proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries(the earliest sign of riboflavin deficiency) angular stomatitis, circumcorneal vascularization, cheilosis, magenta-colored tongue, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis. Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

Other options

Option B: Vitamin B3/ niacin deficiency leads to pellagra, which is characterized by a pigmented rash in sun-exposed areas, bright red tongue, diarrhea, apathy, memory loss, and disorientation.

Option C: Vitamin B6/ pyridoxine deficiency leads to symptoms such as seborrhea, glossitis, convulsions, neuropathy, depression, confusion and microcytic anemia.

Option D: Vitamin E is a fat-soluble vitamin and is not soluble in water. Its deficiency leads to peripheral neuropathy, spinocerebellar ataxia, skeletal muscle atrophy, and retinopathy.

questions.text: A newborn assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to have a  heart rate of 90 beats/min and irregular respiration. The baby coughed on inserting a nasal catheter and was moving all his limbs actively. The body was pink with blue extremities. What is the Apgar score in this newborn?
questions.solution:
The parameters in the given clinical scenario indicate that the Apgar score in this newborn is 7:

  • Appearance: Body is pink with blue extremities = 1
  • Pulse: 90 beats/min = 1
  • Grimace: Coughs on nasal catheter insertion = 2
  • Active motion: Moves all the limbs actively = 2
  • Respiratory effort - Irregular respiration = 1

The Apgar score is a systematic way of assessing the infant after birth at 1 and 5 minutes of life. It gives a maximum score of 10 which indicates the newborn is in the best possible condition.

Scores between 0-3 require immediate resuscitation. Changes in the Apgar scores denote the response of the infant to resuscitation. If the score at 5 minutes remains less than 7, the infant should be assessed again every 5 minutes for the next 20 minutes.

Causes for low Apgar score are:

  • Fetal distress
  • Prematurity
  • Drugs like analgesics, narcotics, sedatives, magnesium sulfate
  • Acute cerebral trauma
  • Precipitous delivery
  • Airway obstruction (choanal atresia)  
  • Congenital pneumonia or sepsis
  • Hemorrhage- hypovolemia

False-negative Apgar score is seen in maternal acidosis and high fetal catecholamine levels.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: A father reports to a pediatrician that his daughter has episodes of lethargy, irritability, and vomiting right after she drinks any fruit juice. Urinalysis after such an episode was positive for Benedict's test. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies is likely in this girl?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with symptoms occurring after ingesting fruit juices (containing fructose) points to the diagnosis of hereditary fructose intolerance, and aldolase B enzyme deficiency seen here.

Fructose-1,6- bisphosphate aldolase/ aldolase B is present in the liver, kidney, and intestine. It catalyzes the hydrolysis of fructose-1,6-bisphosphate into triose phosphate and glyceraldehyde phosphate. It also hydrolyzes fructose-1-phosphate.
 
Hereditary fructose intolerance is an autosomal recessive condition, caused by pathogenic variations in the ALDOB gene which causes aldolase deficiency.
 
Patients are asymptomatic until fructose or sucrose is ingested (usually from fruit, fruit juice, sweetened cereal, or table sugar). It usually presents during infancy when sugar-containing feeds are introduced, but some patients (who are less sensitive) can present at older ages as well. Clinical features include jaundice, hepatomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, and convulsions. Acute ingestion causes symptomatic hypoglycemia. Chronic intake results in failure to thrive, hepatic disease, kidney failure, and death.
 
Reducing substances are seen in the urine during an episode (Benedict's test positive) as fructose is a reducing sugar. Reduced levels of aldolase B activity in the liver and demonstration of two pathogenic variants in ALDOB on molecular genetic testing give a definitive diagnosis.
 
Treatment involves complete cessation of all sources of sucrose, fructose, and sorbitol from the diet.
 
The image summarizes the metabolic pathways involved in the metabolism of fructose.


Other options:

Option B: Fructokinase converts fructose to fructose-1-phosphate, the deficiency of which can give rise to essential fructosuria. Essential fructosuria is a benign, asymptomatic defect of intermediary metabolism characterized by the intermittent appearance of fructose in the urine.

Option C: Glucose-6-phosphatase is located in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and catalyzes the hydrolysis of glucose-6-phosphate to glucose and phosphate. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to von Gierke disease characterised by hypoglycemia, growth retardation, and hepatomegaly.

Option D: Hexokinases catalyse the first step in glucose metabolism, i.e, phosphorylation of intracellular glucose.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old male patient complains of intermittent epigastric pain that is worse with food intake for 5 months. Physical examination is remarkable for mild epigastric tenderness. Endoscopy reveals gastric ulcers and urease breath test is positive. Which of the following is not a recommended treatment regimen for eradicating the causative organism?

PPI- Proton pump inhibitor
questions.solution:
PPI + amoxicillin + nitroimidazole is not a recommended treatment regimen for eradicating the causative organism in this patient.

The clinical vignette with epigastric pain, melena, weight loss, and a positive urease breath test is suggestive of a gastric ulcer due to H. pylori. Among the options listed PPI + amoxicillin + nitroimidazole is not a standard treatment regimen. The corrected regimen(concomitant regimen) here would be PPI + clarithromycin + amoxicillin + nitroimidazole

Commonly used first-line treatment regimens for H. pylori are:

questions.text: A man presents with pain and swelling of the right knee and ankle joints for the past week. He has a history of diarrhea 4 weeks ago. On examination, he has conjunctivitis and the following skin lesions are seen. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with acute arthritis and conjunctivitis following a recent infection and the given image showing keratoderma blennorrhagica point to the diagnosis of reactive arthritis or Reiter's syndrome. 

Reactive arthritis (ReA) is non-purulent arthritis following enteric or urogenital infection. It occurs most commonly in the age group 18-40 years and is associated with HLA-B27. Bacterial triggers for ReA are caused by Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter, and Chlamydia trachomatis.

It is characterized by a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. Patients develop arthritis which is asymmetric and additive, involving large weight-bearing joints like the knee and ankle.

Extraarticular manifestations of reactive arthritis include:

  • Keratoderma blennorrhagica presents as vesicles and pustules that lead to hyperkeratotic lesions/crusting on the palms and soles.
  • Oral ulcers: superficial, transient, and often asymptomatic.
  • Circinate balanitis refers to vesicles that rupture to form painless superficial erosions on the glans penis.

Other options:

Option A: Ankylosing spondylitis is commonly seen in young adults. It has a strong association with the HLA-B27 genetic marker. Patients will present with lower lumbar back pain which is insidious in onset. It is accompanied by low-back morning stiffness that improves with activity.

 

 

X-ray showing the characteristic bamboo-spine appearance in ankylosing spondylitis:

 

Option B: Psoriatic arthritis is an asymmetrical oligoarthritis. It is associated with nail pitting, onycholysis, dactylitis, and enthesitis. There is pronounced telescoping of the digits. Axial involvement may also occur.

Radiological features include:

  • Pencil-in-cup deformity at the distal interphalangeal joint, as shown in the image below.
  • Marginal erosions with adjacent bony proliferation known as whiskering.

 

Option C: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis usually presents with swelling and pain in the small joints of the hands. Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints are commonly involved.

Related Pearl: Uveitis Associated with HLA B-27-associated Arthritis

  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Psoriatic arthritis
  • Reiter’s syndrome
  • Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) (previously known as juvenile rheumatoid arthritis)

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought with an unprovoked Category-III dog bite. He was not immunized previously. After washing the wound, and vaccination, you have decided to give immunoglobulin. Your hospital provides equine rabies immunoglobulin. The maximum dose that can be given is ______
questions.solution:
The maximum dosage of equine rabies immunoglobulin that can be given is 40 IU/kg body weight.

Rabies immunoglobulin is provided in 2 types and their doses should be:

  • Human rabies immunoglobulin (hRIG): 20 IU/kg body weight.
  • Equine rabies immunoglobulin (eRIG): 40 IU/kg body weight.

Rabies immunoglobulin is administered only once at or as soon as possible after the initiation of post-exposure vaccination. Beyond the seventh day after the first dose of vaccine, rabies immunoglobulin is not indicated because an active antibody response to the vaccine has already occurred.

The use of monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a “cocktail” containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus as alternatives for RIGs in PEP is under study.

Management of category III bite:

A category III wound is single or multiple transdermal bites, scratches, or licks on broken skin. It includes contamination of mucous membrane with saliva from licks or contacts with bats. 

  • In previously unimmunized patients, Immediate vaccination and rabies immunoglobulin administration is needed with local wound treatment. 
  • The wound and adjoining area should be cleaned with plenty of soap and water, preferably under running water for at least 15 minutes to minimize the risk of contracting rabies. 
  • After cleaning, the wound should be treated with virucidal agents like alcohol or tincture iodine.
  • If the wound needs suturing, it should be done 24-48 hours after the incident with minimum sutures. Immediate suturing may spread the virus into deeper tissues. 

Post-exposure prophylaxis in previously unimmunized patients

  • Essen regimen:
    • 5 dose regimen: One intramuscular dose each on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28 days 
  • Zareb regimen:
    • 4 dose multisite regimen, 2 intramuscular doses on day 0, and 1 intramuscular dose each on days 7 and 21 
  • Intradermal regimen:
    • 2 site regimen, two intradermal doses on days 0, 3, 7, and 28. 

Zero by 30 : is the Global strategic plan to end human death from dog mediated rabies by 2030.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of 3 intramuscular (IM) or 3 intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP or PrEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient came with complaints of a painful and swollen right knee, and difficulty in walking. After examining the knee joint, aspiration is done. On synovial fluid examination using compensated polarized microscopy, positive birefringent rhomboid-shaped crystals are seen. What is the composition of the crystals deposited in this disorder?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and synovial fluid analysis showing positive birefringent, rhomboid-shaped crystals are suggestive of pseudogout. There is the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate in this disorder.

Pseudogout is a condition that occurs due to the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals (CPPD). It presents with features similar to acute gout and predominantly affects the elderly. This is attributable to the increased levels of inorganic pyrophosphate in diseased or aging cartilage which promotes CPP crystal nucleation and their deposition.

Acute attacks of CPPD present with joint swelling and pain, affecting the knee (most common), wrist, shoulders, elbows, and hands. It also has systemic features of inflammation including fever, chills, and elevated CRP. Chronic CPPD commonly presents as polyarticular arthritis resembling osteoarthritis (pseudo-osteoarthritis). It affects atypical joints such as metacarpophalangeal, wrist, elbow, and ankle joints causing severe damage.

X-ray or ultrasonography of the joint shows chondrocalcinosis, which is punctate or linear radiodense deposits in the joint menisci or articular cartilage. Detection of rod-like or rhomboid crystals in synovial fluid or articular cartilage is diagnostic of pseudogout.

The below image shows rhomboid-shaped and positive birefringent calcium pyrophosphate crystals in pseudogout.

 

Other options:

Option A: Monosodium urate crystal deposition is seen in gout. Synovial fluid analysis on polarizing microscopy shows needle-shaped, negative birefringent crystals, as shown below.

 

Option C: Calcium apatite crystal deposition occurs in areas of tissue damage (dystrophic calcification), hypercalcemic or hyperparathyroid states (metastatic calcification). The crystals appear as shiny intra- or extra-cellular non-birefringent globules.

Option D: Calcium oxalate crystal deposition occurs in primary oxalosis and secondary to chronic renal disease. The crystals have variable shapes and variable birefringence to polarized light.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man was brought by his father to your clinic with the complaints that he has become very irritable, excessively talkative, and spends around 12 hours playing video games for the past 8 days. However, he attends his online classes regularly. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms occurring for 8 days, without causing occupational impairment (still attends his online classes regularly) point toward a diagnosis of hypomania. 

Diagnostic criteria for hypomania:

  • A distinct period of persistently elevated/irritable mood, increased energy levels, and activity lasting for at least 4 consecutive days.
  • During this period, ≥3 of the following symptoms should be present to a significant degree:
    • Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity
    • Decreased requirement for sleep
    • Excessive talkativeness
    • Flight of ideas
    • Distractibility
    • Increase in goal-oriented activity or psychomotor agitation
    • Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for adverse outcomes such 
  • The episode is associated with a change in functioning that is atypical of the individual when asymptomatic and is observed by others.
  • The episode is not severe enough to cause marked deterioration in social or occupational functioning or to necessitate hospitalization. No psychotic episodes are seen.
  • The episode is not attributable to the use of a substance or to another medical condition.

Other options:

Option A: In mania, the symptoms should be present for at least 1 week and symptoms should be severe enough to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning. Psychotic features may also be seen in mania.

Option B: Dysthymia is also called a persistent depressive disorder. It is defined as a subaffective or subclinical depressive disorder that is insidious in onset and intermittent or persistent in the course. It lasts for at least 2 years. 

Option C: Cyclothymic disorder is a mild form of bipolar type II disorder. It is characterized by hypomania and mild depression.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presented with oliguria, hypertension, facial puffiness, and dark-colored urine as shown below for 3 days. The urine is positive for albumin. He had a history of throat infection 2 weeks back. On microscopic examination, enlarged, pale glomeruli and epithelial humps are seen. Which of the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: C3 level increases and ASO level increases
C3 level decreases and ASO level  increases
C3 level decreases and ASO level  decreases
C3 level  increases and  ASO level  decreases

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given in the question is suggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Decreased levels of C3 and elevated levels of ASO titers are seen in acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. 

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis(PSGN) is characterized by the sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency. It usually occurs following a throat infection by nephritogenic strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococci. It can also occur after streptococcal skin infection or pyoderma.

The typical patient develops an acute nephritic syndrome following:
  • 1 to 2 weeks after an antecedent streptococcal pharyngitis or
  • 3 to 6 weeks after streptococcal pyoderma

The pathogenesis involves circulating antibodies elicited by streptococcal antigens reacting with normal glomerular antigens and complement activation by directly deposited streptococcal antigens causing the immunologic injury. In this immune complex-mediated APSGN, we see the following in most patients:

  • Decrease in the serum complement (C3) level (levels normalize in 6 to 8 weeks)
  • ASO titer is increased
Microscopic Findings in PSGN:
  • Light microscopy: Enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with diffuse mesangial and endothelial proliferation and leukocyte infiltration.
  • Immunofluorescence: Granular deposits of IgG and complement C3 along the glomerular basement membrane(GBM)and in the mesangium. 
  • Electron microscopy: Electron-dense deposits, or humps, are observed on the epithelial side of the GBM.

Below is the image showing light microscopy findings of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old married woman with 10 weeks of amenorrhea presents with painless vaginal bleeding. Her urinary pregnancy test is positive but her ultrasound shows an empty uterus and no gestational sac was found in the adnexa. An ectopic pregnancy is suspected. All of the following  are features in favor of a clinical diagnosis of cervical pregnancy, except _______.

choices.text: Enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus
A fully opened internal cervical os
Products of conceptus attached within endocervix

questions.solution:
All the given options are in favor of a clinical diagnosis of cervical pregnancy except fully opened internal cervical os.

A closed internal cervical os is one of the clinical diagnostic criteria for cervical pregnancy, not an open one.

Cervical pregnancy is a type of ectopic pregnancy where implantation occurs in the cervical canal at or below the internal os. Thinning and distension of the cervical canal occur due to erosion of the walls by the trophoblasts. The morbidity and mortality are high due to profuse bleeding.

Rubin's diagnostic criteria for cervical pregnancy:

  • Uterine bleeding without cramping pain following a period of amenorrhea
  • A soft, enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus
  • Products of conception are entirely confined within and firmly attached to the endocervix
  • A closed internal cervical os
  • A partially opened external cervical os

Ultrasound examination reveals the pregnancy in the cervical canal and an empty uterine cavity.

Management medical and surgical therapy. Methotrexate therapy or feticidal KCl injection may be considered in a few selected cases. Surgery includes a hysterectomy, as it is often required to stop bleeding. Uterine artery embolization with gel foam can also be used to control hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presents with abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting for 3 days. On examination, there is tenderness in the right iliac fossa. Blood investigations revealed a white blood cell count of 11 x 10^9 cells/L. The Alvarado score is 6. What is the next best step in management in this patient?
questions.solution:
The next best step in the management of this patient is adjunctive CT.

The clinical vignette of a young male patient with vomiting, fever, and abdominal pain is indicative of acute appendicitis. As the Alvarado score is 6 and a CT scan is recommended when the score is equivocal (5-6), adjunctive CT is the right answer.

Acute appendicitis is one of the most common causes of acute abdominal pain with a peak incidence in the teens and early second decade of life. Its incidence is equal among males and females before puberty; at age 25, the male to female ratio increases to 3:2 and then in the subsequent decades, its incidence in males is lesser.

Its incidence is found to be lesser in individuals with high dietary fibre intake. Obstruction of the lumen seems to be essential for the development of appendiceal gangrene and perforation. This can occur either by a faecolith/appendicolith - which consists of inspissated faecal material, calcium phosphates, bacteria and epithelial debris - or by a stricture, which is found to be the aetilogy in the majority of cases.

Sometimes, the lumen can also be narrowed by lymphoid hyperplasia, leading to luminal obstruction. Even with the obstruction present, continued mucus secretion and inflammatory exudates increase intraluminal pressure, obstructing the lymphatic drainage, leading to oedema, mucosal ulceration and bacterial translocation to the submucosa. If this condition progresses, ischemia of the appendix occurs followed by more bacterial invasion through the muscularis propia and submucosa, producing acute appendicitis.

The patient often gives a history of poorly localised colicky abdominal pain, which is first noticed in the periumbilical region. Central abdominal pain is associated with anorexia, nausea and one or two episodes of vomiting that follow the onset of pain. There may be history of similar discomfort that settled spontaneously. The symptoms in the order of pain followed by vomiting and fever constitute Murphy’s triad of appendicitis.

With progressive inflammation, the parietal peritoneum in the right iliac fossa becomes irritated, producing more intense, constant, localised somatic pain which increases on coughing or sudden movement.

Some of the clinical signs of appendicitis include pyrexia, localized tenderness in the right iliac fossa, muscle guarding, rebound tenderness. Pointing sign, Rovsing's sign, Psoas sign, Obturator sign are some of the signs to be elicited in a patient with appendicitis.

The Alvarado scoring system is the clinical scoring system used in the diagnosis of appendicitis.

Since the patient has a score of 6, CT is recommended (score: equivocal). In children, ultrasound is the imaging of choice.

Other options:

Option A: A score of 7 and above would be strongly predictive of acute appendicitis, the traditional treatment for which would be an appendicectomy.

Option C: Conservative management with bowel rest, IV antibiotics, often metronidazole, and 3rd generation cephalosporin can be made in an uncomplicated appendicitis patient (absence of appendicolith, perforation, or abscess). However, since the score indicates unconfirmed appendicitis, an adjunctive CT is recommended.

Option D: Since the diagnosis of appendicitis is essentially clinical, there is no scope for an abdominal X-ray.

If the score is 7 or higher, surgery is recommended.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient presented with a painless mass in the parotid region. Examination revealed a 5-cm rounded, well-demarcated tumor. Biopsy of the tumor revealed myoepithelial cells intermingled with myxoid, mucoid, and cartilaginous areas. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and histopathological findings are suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma of the parotid gland.

Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms and the parotid gland is most commonly involved. They are benign tumors that consist of a mixture of ductal (epithelial), myoepithelial, and mesenchymal cells. Therefore they are also termed mixed tumors.

Pathology:

Gross features:

  • The tumors are rounded, well-demarcated, measuring <6 cm.
  • They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate.
  • The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma.

On microscopy epithelial and mesenchymal components are visible. Epithelial components resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells that are arranged in the form of ducts, acini, irregular tubules, or sheets of cells. These components are dispersed in the mesenchymal components consisting of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing cartilage or bone.

The image below shows pleomorphic adenoma of the salivary gland consisting of mixed epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right).

Other options:

Option A: Warthin tumor is the second most common salivary gland neoplasm. Histologically, the tumor shows epithelial and lymphoid elements. The epithelium typically consists of a double layer of oncocytic epithelial cells. The inner layer contains columnar cells while the outer layer contains cuboidal cells.

Option C: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is the most common primary malignant tumor of the salivary gland, commonly affecting the parotid gland. Histology shows mucinous, intermediate, and squamous elements, with small to large mucus-filled vacuoles.

Option D: Adenoid cystic carcinoma involves minor salivary glands, commonly the palatine glands. Histology shows tumor cells, organized in a cribriform growth pattern, resembling swiss cheese.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: During your labor room postings, a vaginal examination of a primigravida female revealed the anterior cervix having soft consistency and showing 3 cm dilatation and a cervical length of 3 cm. You would assign a Bishop score of 1 to which of these cervical parameters in this patient?
questions.solution:
Among the given parameters, cervical length of 3 cm is given a score of 1 whereas a score of 2 is given for all the other parameters.

The Bishop score is a scoring system used to assess labor induction outcomes. It is based on the station of the head, dilation, effacement (or length), position, and consistency of the cervix noted by doing a vaginal examination.

Note: In the modified Bishop score (1991), the effacement is replaced by the cervical length in cm.

From the data given in the question:

  • Length of the cervix is 3 cm, hence score = 1
  • Position of the cervix is Anterior, hence score = 2

questions.text: A 2-day-old infant is brought with yellowish discoloration of the skin and rash. The mother gives a history of fever and pharyngitis during her pregnancy. On examination, chorioretinitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and hemorrhagic purpuric eruptions were noted with no cardiovascular abnormality. On a non-contrast CT scan, the following image is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above non-contrast CT image shows periventricular calcifications and ventriculomegaly. The above clinical vignette and the CT image are suggestive of the diagnosis of congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection.

The most common congenital infection is congenital CMV infection. It is mostly asymptomatic, but symptoms may occur in cases of primary maternal infection in pregnancy. 

The clinical manifestations are hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. They can also develop hemorrhagic purpuric eruptions due to dermal erythropoiesis giving the appearance of a blueberry muffin baby. One of the long-term sequelae is sensorineural hearing loss.

Laboratory findings include direct hyperbilirubinemia, elevated hepatic transaminases, and thrombocytopenia. A non-contrast CT scan shows periventricular calcifications, ventriculomegaly, and hypoplastic cerebellum. Diagnosis can be made prenatal or postnatal. Prenatal diagnosis includes the detection of IgM antibodies in the mother along with observing for fetal abnormalities through ultrasound. Antibody positivity in the mother along with abnormalities in the baby highly suggests intrauterine infection. Detection of fetal infection can also be done by the detection of the virus through the amniotic fluid polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Postnatal diagnosis involves the isolation of the virus from the urine or saliva via the DNA PCR or culture within the first 3 weeks of life.

Histopathological detection will reveal characteristic owl eye inclusion–bearing cells.

Below is the image showing the blueberry muffin baby.

Option A- Congenital rubella syndrome is due to the rubella virus. It is characterized by cataracts, salt and pepper retinopathy; sensorineural deafness; microcephaly; blueberry muffin baby; and congenital heart diseases like patent ductus arteriosus, ventricular septal defect, and pulmonary artery stenosis. Sensorineural deafness is the most common single complication in patients with congenital rubella syndrome.

Below is the image showing salt and pepper retinopathy.

Option B- Congenital syphilis is due to Treponema pallidum. It can be differentiated into early signs at <2 years of age and late signs during the first 2 decades. Early signs are characterized by painful osteochondritis resulting in pseudoparalysis of Parrot, periostitis, mucocutaneous rash characterized by maculopapular rash or vesiculobullous lesions, snuffles (persistent rhinitis), and condylomatous lesions. Radiographs show demineralization of the medial proximal tibial metaphysis called Wimberger lines. Late signs are characterized by dental anomalies like Hutchinson's teeth, saddle nose, interstitial keratitis, and Clutton's joints (unilateral or bilateral painless joint swelling especially the knee joint).

Below is the image showing Hutchinson's teeth.

Option C- Congenital toxoplasmosis is due to Toxoplasma gondii. It is characterized by a classic triad of chorioretinitis, microcephaly, and intracerebral calcifications. Blueberry muffin baby appearance is also seen in this condition. On a CT scans of the brain, there are calcifications around caudate nucleus and basal ganglia, choroid plexus, and subependyma.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the fast-twitch muscle fibers?

choices.text: They have larger diameter  than  slow twitch fibres
Fast twitch fibres are designed for power
Fast twitch fibres have less myoglobin than slow twitch fibres
More capillaries are present in vicinity of fast twitch fibres

questions.solution:
Among the given options, The false statement is that, fast fibres have more capillaries in the vicinity.

Skeletal muscle fibres are broadly classified as "slow-twitch" or type 1 and "fast-twitch" or type 2 muscle fibres. Based on differential myosin heavy chain (MYH) gene expression, fast-twitch fibres are further classified into three major subtypes - type 2A, type 2X, and type 2B, although humans do not appear to have MYH4-expressing type 2B fibres.

The differences between the fast-twitch and the slow-twitch fibres are:

      Fast-twitch muscle fibres    Slow-twitch muscle fibres
They are twice as large in diameter when compared with slow-twitch fibres. Their diameter is half as large as compared to fast-twitch fibres.
Over a short duration, they can achieve twice as much maximal power compared to slow-twitch fibres and are organised for power. They play a major role in and are organised for endurance; have considerably more myoglobin and far more mitochondria than fast-twitch fibres.
Enzymes involved in aerobic metabolism are less active. Enzymes involved in aerobic metabolism are more active.
Lesser number of capillaries in the vicinity. More number of capillaries in the vicinity.

For example, the gastrocnemius muscle has a higher number of fast-twitch fibres, which gives it the capability of forceful and rapid contraction. In contrast, the soleus muscle has a higher preponderance of slow-twitch muscle fibres and therefore is used to a greater extent for prolonged lower leg muscle activity.

questions.text: Given below is a dissected compartment of the leg. The nerve supplying the muscle given below does not supply which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
The deep peroneal nerve supplies the peronius tertius muscle. It does not supply the tibilais posterior muscle. Tibialis posterior is supplied by the tibial nerve.

The above image shows the anterior compartment of the leg. The deep peroneal nerve is the nerve of the anterior compartment of the leg and the dorsum of the foot. It is one of the two terminal branches of the common peroneal nerve arising between the neck of the fibula and peroneus longus. It accompanies the anterior tibial artery.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) presents to the emergency room with fever, headache, and generalized tonic-clonic seizures. MRI is done for the patient, which is given below. What is the standard treatment for the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of seizures in a patient with HIV and the MRI showing multiple ring-enhancing lesions suggest a diagnosis of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin is the standard treatment in this patient. 

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is one of the most common AIDS-defining opportunistic CNS infections and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL. It is caused by Toxoplasma gondii. It is usually a reactivation of latent tissue cysts. 

Clinical manifestations include altered mental status, seizures, weakness, cerebellar signs, meningismus, cranial nerve manifestations, etc.

The diagnosis is usually based on the MRI findings of multiple lesions in multiple locations. However, a single lesion may also be present. These lesions are associated with inflammation and central necrosis, which show ring enhancement on contrast MRI. Sometimes, an eccentric nodular area of enhancement is seen within the ring called the eccentric target sign, which is typical of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Surrounding edema is usually present.

Differential diagnosis: Other conditions having single or multiple enhancing mass lesions in the HIV-infected patient include

  • Primary CNS lymphoma
  • TB, fungal or bacterial abscesses. 

Treatment:

  • Standard treatment is sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. 
  • Alternative regimens are clindamycin + pyrimethamine, atovaquone + pyrimethamine, and azithromycin +pyrimethamine + rifabutin.

Prophylaxis:

  • Primary prophylaxis is to prevent the first occurrence of the toxoplasmosis infection, given to patients with IgG antibodies to toxoplasma and CD4+ T cell count <100/μL. A single double-strength tablet of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX) is given. The same regimen also offers primary protection against Pneumocystis jirovecii. 
  • Secondary prophylaxis/ maintenance therapy is to prevent the recurrence of toxoplasmosis infection if CD4+ T cell counts are <200/μL. Sulfadiazine/ pyrimethamine and leucovorin are given. Secondary prophylaxis is discontinued if the CD4+ T cell counts are >200/μL for 6 months.

Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester is diagnosed with uncomplicated malaria and her blood smear was found to be positive for plasmodium falciparum. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Falciparum malaria during the second and third trimesters of pregnancy should be treated with Artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT).

Treatment of uncomplicated P. falciparum malaria during the first trimester of pregnancy consists of Quinine. Quinine can induce hypoglycemia, so pregnant patients are advised to eat regularly while on this treatment regimen. During the second and third trimesters, area-specific ACT is the preferred treatment option. 

  • For all states except north-eastern states: Artesunate and Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine
  • For north-eastern states: Artemether and Lumefantrine

Chloroquine (option C) is used for the treatment of P. vivax malaria during pregnancy. Primaquine (option D) is contraindicated in pregnant patients.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman who was treated for COVID-19 one month back now presents with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose and suppuration of the left eye. Culture of discharge on Sabouraud agar would reveal colonies showing:

choices.text: Broad hyphae with acute angle branching
Septate hyphae with acute angle branching

questions.solution:
Microscopy showing broad aseptate hyphae with irregular branching is suggestive of Mucor.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus oryzae (most prevalent), mucor, and lichtheimia. It is seen in patients with diabetes mellitus, leukemias, lymphomas, long-term corticosteroid use, severe burns, and immunodeficiencies.

The common clinical form is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis in which there is an invasion of the blood vessels in the nasal cavity, eyes, and brain causing thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. The blackish discoloration is due to arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene.

Diagnosis can be made by staining them with 10% potassium hydroxide and culture. On Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, they appear as grey-white colonies with a thick cottony, fluffy surface. Under the microscope, they appear as irregularly branched broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores). 

Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis. Surgical debridement and control of underlying predisposing causes should also be done.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.
